Which of the following is the most appropriate management to initiate in this patient before her pregnancy?

choices.text: Start the patient on a high dose of folic acid daily
Start the patient on standard folic acid daily
Stop carbamazepine now and throughout pregnancy
Switch the patient to valproic acid

questions.solution:
This patient is taking carbamazepine and is planning to get pregnant. The AEDs most known to carry teratogenic effects are carbamazepine, phenytoin, and valproic acid.    

Carbamazepine use during pregnancy is associated with congenital malformations, including cleft lip and palate and neural tube defects (e.g. spina bifida). These findings can also be seen in patients taking phenytoin during pregnancy. In addition, gestational phenytoin use can lead to fetal hydantoin syndrome, characterized by midfacial hypoplasia, microcephaly, cleft lip and palate, digital hypoplasia, as well as intellectual and behavioral abnormalities. Valproic acid can lead to congenital cardiac defects, neural tube defects, cleft lip and palate, intellectual disability, and behavioral problems.    

The precise mechanism by which these medications induce these teratogenic effects is not entirely understood; however, studies suggest AEDs cause folate deficiency and increase the number of oxidative metabolites in the fetus.    

The use of AEDs in pregnancy includes a carefully balanced decision considering the increased risk of teratogenicity and seizure recurrence. It is recommended to continue using an AED in pregnancy, but the patient must be given a high dose of folic acid (4mg) before and throughout pregnancy to decrease this risk. The exception to this recommendation is valproic acid, which carries severe teratogenic effects.   

Option Analysis

✅ Start the patient on a high dose of folic acid daily:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Start the patient on standard folic acid daily:
Incorrect: All women planning to get pregnant should start using the regular dose of folic acid, which is 0.4 mg. However, patients with an increased risk of folate deficiency like this patient taking carbamazepine should take a high dose (4mg) of folic acid. 
❌ Stop carbamazepine now and throughout pregnancy:
Incorrect: Stopping the use of antiepileptic medication carries an increased risk of recurrent seizures and can result in adverse effects on the fetus and the mother. Stopping the patient’s anti-epileptic medication is inappropriate.  
❌ Switch the patient to valproic acid :
Incorrect: Valproic acid is the most teratogenic antiepileptic medication, and its use is contraindicated during pregnancy. 
❌ No intervention is needed :
Incorrect: Carbamazepine is a teratogenic medication, and a high dose of folic acid is needed to decrease the risk of the fetus developing congenital malformations.

questions.text: A 2-day-old boy is being evaluated in the newborn nursery. He was born at 40 weeks gestation to a primigravid mother who received consistent prenatal care. The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and the patient is currently being breastfed. Length and weight are at the 35th percentile. Vitals are within normal limits for age. Physical examination demonstrates a newborn sleeping comfortably. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The abdomen is soft without organomegaly. Genitourinary examination demonstrates a circumcised penis of normal size. The right testis is located within the inguinal canal, and the left testis is palpable in the scrotum. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this neonate?

choices.text: Reassurance and monitoring for spontaneous descent

questions.solution:
Cryptorchidism is a common congenital condition characterized by incomplete/partial descent of the testis into the scrotum. Approximately 80% of cryptorchid testes descend by the third month of life, and therefore, reassurance and monitoring for spontaneous descent is appropriate.

Orchiopexy is necessary after four months of persistent cryptorchidism to avoid the complications as documented below:

  •  Testicular torsion: when malpositioned in the inguinal canal, the unfixed testis becomes prone to mobility, blunt trauma, and in particular, testicular torsion. 
 
  •  Testicular cancer: studies suggest the elevated temperature of the abdominal cavity promotes malignant transformation. Another theory postulates an underlying hormonal condition that predisposes some males to both cryptorchidism and testicular cancer. 
 
  •  Subfertility/infertility: Males with a history of undescended testes are at increased risk of low sperm counts, poorer quality sperm, and lower fertility rates than males with normally descended testes. This decreased fertility occurs secondary to increased temperatures in the abdomen and inguinal canal, which impairs spermatogenesis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reassurance and monitoring for spontaneous descent:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emergent surgical correction:
Incorrect: Orchiopexy is a surgical procedure to reposition undescended or ectopic testes. Surgery is recommended after four months of age for congenitally undescended testes.
❌ Pediatric urology referral:
Incorrect: Indications for referral to a pediatric urologist include undescended testis (unilateral or bilateral) between 4 and 12 months of age, as well as for difficulty differentiating between undescended, retractile, or ectopic testis.
❌ Karyotype analysis:
Incorrect: Bilateral non palpable testes in a newborn male requires immediate evaluation at the time of birth. Karyotype analysis is helpful in differentiating a virilized genotypic female from an undervirilized genotypic male. This patient has unilateral cryptorchidism.
❌ Electrolyte monitoring:
Incorrect: Bilateral nonpalpable testes in a newborn male requires immediate evaluation at the time of birth, because the differential diagnosis includes developmental sex disorders, such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). CAH requires electrolyte monitoring due to salt wasting, which can lead to a potentially fatal adrenal crisis in neonates.This patient has unilateral cryptorchidism.

questions.text: A 5-day-old boy is brought to the office for his first postnatal visit. The patient was born at 34 weeks gestation to a 28-year-old via normal vaginal delivery. The patient’s parent otherwise had an uncomplicated pregnancy and took prenatal vitamins regularly. The patient currently breastfeeds every 2-3 hours with adequate elimination. Height, weight, and head circumference are at the 50th percentile, adjusted for the gestational age. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an open, soft, and flat anterior fontanelle. Red reflex is present bilaterally. Abdomen is soft and nontender. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Genitourinary examination shows a palpable right testis in the scrotum and a poorly rugated hypoplastic left scrotum. The left testis is palpable in the inguinal area. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Advise the parents that the testes will descend after 2 years of age
Start hormonal treatment with gonadotropin-releasing hormone

questions.solution:
This infant has a normally palpable right testis in the right scrotum and a poorly rugated left scrotum with the left testis palpable in the inguinal area. The abnormal or partial descent of unilateral/bilateral testes is known as cryptorchidism.   

The testes develop in the abdominal cavity during the first trimester and normally begin to descend into the scrotum (via the inguinal canal) guided by the gubernaculum during the third trimester of pregnancy.  



Cryptorchidism is the most common birth defect of the male genitalia. Most cryptorchid testes are undescended but some may be absent or atrophied. Risk factors include prematurity, low birth weight (<2.5 kg), or small for gestational age. The cryptorchid testes usually descend by the age of 6 months (therefore, this infant should be monitored for this duration). Surgical correction by orchiopexy (pinning of the testes) should be done ideally before 1 year of age if the testes fail to descend by 4-6 months. Untreated cases are at increased risk of impaired spermatogenesis (infertility), seminoma, and testicular torsion. Serum inhibin B levels are decreased, while FSH and LH levels are increased. Serum testosterone is decreased in bilateral cryptorchidism but normal in the unilateral variant.  

Option Analysis

❌ Immediate surgical correction by orchiopexy:
Incorrect: Immediate surgical correction is not appropriate at this age as most testes descend spontaneously by the age of 6 months. Therefore, the patient should be closely monitored for this duration.
❌ Advise the parents that the testes will descend after 2 years of age:
Incorrect: Most of the testes that have not descended by the age of 6 months are unlikely to descend spontaneously and require surgical correction by orchiopexy before the age of 2 years (ideally 1 year).
❌ Start hormonal treatment with gonadotropin-releasing hormone:
Incorrect: The use of hormonal treatment for the descent of testes is controversial, and it is not indicated at this time in this patient.
✅ Monitor for spontaneous descent:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform a scrotal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Imaging, such as an ultrasound, is not routinely indicated for the identification of a nonpalpable testis as it does not alter the need for surgical correction. It can be used in patients with evidence of other gonadal abnormalities, such as gonadal dysgenesis.

questions.text: A 1-hour-old infant is evaluated in the nursery for atypical genitalia. The infant was born at 38 weeks’ gestation via vaginal delivery, and the pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother did not experience any personal signs of virilization and took regular prenatal vitamins during the pregnancy. She did not use alcohol or recreational substances during pregnancy. There is no family history of consanguinity. Family and surgical histories are non-contributory. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 35/min, blood pressure is 69/42 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The newborn's length is 49 cm (32nd percentile), weight is 3100 g (30th percentile), and head circumference is 33 cm (12th percentile). Physical examination of the genitalia reveals bifid scrotum and hypospadias. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), testosterone, and dihydrotestosterone (DHT) levels are normal. Electrolyte levels are within normal levels. Karyotype results later return as 46,XY. Which of the following is the best test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This newborn presents with atypical genitalia, a 46,XY karyotype, and normal gonadotropins, testosterone, and dihydrotestosterone (DHT), suggesting the most likely diagnosis is partial androgen insensitivity syndrome. Molecular genetic testing is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis.        

Atypical genitalia can present as cryptorchidism, hypospadias with micropenis, or bifid scrotum in karyotypic males, or clitoromegaly, posterior labial fusion, single genitourinary opening, or inguinal hernia in karyotypic females. Conditions that affect DHT synthesis or function include disorders of testosterone synthesis, 5-alpha-reductase deficiency, and partial androgen insensitivity syndrome. In these disorders, Sertoli cell function remains intact, and anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) production is normal, resulting in absent Mullerian duct development.        

The presentation of partial androgen insensitivity syndrome is variable, ranging from a predominantly female phenotype with mild virilization to a predominantly male phenotype with hypospadias and bifid scrotum. In addition to clinical features, the diagnosis requires a 46,XY karyotype. Serum testosterone and DHT should be measured to determine whether there is a defect in DHT synthesis or if androgen insensitivity is more likely. Normal levels of gonadotropins, testosterone, and DHT raise suspicion for partial androgen insensitivity. Molecular genetic analysis should be performed to confirm the diagnosis, which is made when a mutation in the androgen receptor gene is identified.    

Option Analysis

❌ Adrenocorticotrophin (ACTH) stimulation test  :
Incorrect: The ACTH stimulation test is used to identify congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). However, this patient’s examination and labs are not suggestive of CAH. With normal hormone levels and electrolytes, this patient most likely has partial androgen insensitivity syndrome. The next test should be molecular genetic analysis 
❌ Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) :
Incorrect: AMH can help determine the etiology of atypical genitalia in patients with a 46,XY karyotype. However, with normal hormone levels, AMH would not provide additional diagnostic information. This patient most likely has partial androgen insensitivity syndrome, and the most appropriate next step is molecular genetic testing. 
❌ Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) :
Incorrect: TSH is used to diagnose thyroid disorders, which are not typically associated with ambiguous genitalia. This patient’s exam findings are consistent with atypical genitalia. Given the normal hormone levels, normal electrolytes, and 46,XY karyotype, partial androgen insensitivity syndrome is the most likely diagnosis. Molecular genetic testing is required to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP)  :
Incorrect: 17-OHP can help diagnose congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) in patients with atypical genitalia. However, the clinical and laboratory findings in this patient are more consistent with partial androgen insensitivity syndrome, making molecular genetic testing the most appropriate next step. 
✅ Molecular genetic analysis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn, delivered at 37 weeks' gestation via an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery, is noted to have atypical genitalia. The mother reports a personal history of a right ovarian mass discovered during pregnancy. Pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 33/min, blood pressure is 69/44 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The newborn's length is 49 cm (32nd percentile) and weight is 3,200 g (47th percentile). Physical exam reveals clitoromegaly and a single urogenital opening. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Laboratory results show normal serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone and electrolyte levels. Chromosomal analysis later reveals a 46,XX karyotype. Which of the following findings on history is most strongly associated with this condition?

choices.text: Family history of short stature in females

questions.solution:
This newborn has atypical genitalia in the context of a 46,XY karyotype, with normal electrolyte and 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. Given the maternal history of a right ovarian mass, these findings are potentially related to a maternal androgen-producing tumor. These tumors, which can be adrenal, abdominal, or pelvic in origin, often present with elevated testosterone levels and maternal virilization.    

Infants with atypical genitalia can present with cryptorchidism, hypospadias, micropenis, bifid scrotum in karyotypic males, and clitoromegaly, posterior labial fusion, a single genitourinary opening, or inguinal hernia in karyotypic females. Placental aromatase deficiency and maternal androgen-secreting tumors, such as luteomas, Krukenberg, and Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors of the ovaries, can produce maternal virilization. Signs of maternal virilization include hirsutism, acne, frontal balding, clitoromegaly, and deepening of the voice. Excess androgens passed through the placenta can result in virilization of karyotypic female (46,XX) infants, presenting as ambiguous genitalia.    

The diagnosis of androgen excess disorders in infants includes history and physical examination to assess for virilization and signs of atypical genitalia. The initial laboratory evaluation includes obtaining a karyotype and measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP). If 17-OHP is normal, and maternal virilization is present, placental transmission of excess androgens should be considered as a potential cause of atypical genitalia. The next step is maternal testing for testosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS), and androstenedione. If these levels are elevated, and ultrasound imaging of the pelvis, abdomen, and adrenal glands reveals a mass, a maternal androgen-producing tumor can be diagnosed.   

Option Analysis

❌ Family history of infertility :
Incorrect: Family history of infertility is found in various causes of ambiguous genitalia, such as partial androgen insensitivity syndrome. This condition presents with atypical genitalia, a 46,XY karyotype, and normal or elevated sex hormones (e.g., luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, testosterone). This patient's findings are likely secondary to a maternal androgen-producing tumor associated with maternal virilization.
❌ History of consanguinity  :
Incorrect: A history of consanguinity raises suspicion for autosomal recessive disorders such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), which presents with atypical genitalia and elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP) levels. This patient has normal 17-OHP and normal electrolyte levels, making CAH unlikely. This patient's findings are likely secondary to a maternal androgen-producing tumor associated with maternal virilization. 
✅ Maternal virilization :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Prenatal exposure to lithium  :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to lithium is associated with congenital heart diseases, but it is not known to cause atypical genitalia. This patient's findings are more likely secondary to a maternal androgen-producing tumor associated with maternal virilization. 
❌ Family history of short stature in females :
Incorrect: Short stature in a female with characteristic features may suggest Turner syndrome, but this condition is diagnosed by a 45,X karyotype and is not linked to family history or atypical genitalia. In this case, the findings are more likely due to a maternal androgen-producing tumor causing virilization.

questions.text:
A 4-hour-old infant, delivered by vaginal delivery at 37 weeks’ gestation, is evaluated in the newborn nursery for atypical genitalia. The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. There is no family history of consanguinity. The mother did not show signs of virilization prenatally and took only regular prenatal vitamins during the pregnancy. Family and surgical history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 64/36 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical exam, there is a right-sided inguinal hernia, and the genitalia appear as shown below. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are unremarkable. 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP) is elevated before and after the adrenocorticotrophin (ACTH) stimulation test. Laboratory results one week after birth are shown below. A karyotype is confirmed as 46,XX. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value      Results     
 Sodium      133 mEq/L    
 Potassium      6.5 mEq/L     
 Chloride      103 mEq/L     
 Bicarbonate      17 mEq/L    
 Glucose      50 mg/dL    


“Ambiguous genitalia” by Tantbirojn et al. Licensed under CC BY 2.0.  Reproduced from Wikimedia
questions.solution:
This newborn has atypical genitalia and a right-sided inguinal hernia. Labs show elevated 17- hydroxyprogesterone (OHP), hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, along with a 46,XX karyotype. These findings are consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).         

Atypical genitalia refers to external genitalia that are not phenotypically male or female. Examples include cryptorchidism, hypospadias with micropenis, or bifid scrotum in karyotypic males or clitoromegaly, posterior labial fusion, single genitourinary opening, or inguinal hernia in karyotypic females. The appearance of the external genitalia is not diagnostic of a particular disorder and often does not distinguish among the various disorders of sex development (DSD).        

A karyotype should be ordered during the initial diagnostic workup. The most common cause of 46,XX DSD is CAH. This is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by impaired steroidogenesis in the adrenal glands, leading to androgen excess. 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause. Classic CAH typically presents with virilization of female external genitalia at birth and normal genitalia in karyotypic males. Elevated 17-OHP and a positive ACTH stimulation test are suggestive of CAH. Additional lab findings that support a diagnosis of classic CAH include elevated plasma renin activity, hyperkalemia, and hyponatremia. An abdominal ultrasound may reveal enlarged adrenal glands.   

Option Analysis

✅ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Gonadal dysgenesis  :
Incorrect: Patients with gonadal dysgenesis can present with atypical genitalia, a 46,XY karyotype, elevated gonadotropins, and low testosterone levels. However, this patient has a 46,XX karyotype, elevated gonadotropins, elevated testosterone, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, which are more consistent with congenital adrenal hyperplasia.  
❌ Maternal androgen-producing tumor  :
Incorrect: Karyotypic females born to mothers with androgen-producing tumors, such as luteomas, may have atypical genitalia, and the mothers usually develop virilization. However, maternal virilization was not present in this vignette. This patient has a 46,XX karyotype, elevated gonadotropins, elevated testosterone, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, making congenital adrenal hyperplasia the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome  :
Incorrect: Patients with partial androgen insensitivity syndrome may have atypical genitalia with a 46,XY karyotype, along with normal gonadotropins and testosterone. This patient has a 46,XX karyotype, elevated gonadotropins, elevated testosterone, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, making congenital adrenal hyperplasia the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ Placental aromatase deficiency  :
Incorrect: Karyotypic females with placental aromatase deficiency are born with atypical genitalia, and the mothers usually develop virilization. In this case, maternal virilization is not present. This patient has a 46,XX karyotype, elevated gonadotropins, elevated testosterone, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, making congenital adrenal hyperplasia the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old presents to your office with a complaint of left-sided scrotal mass accompanied by dull-aching pain in the scrotal area. They first noticed a small swelling in the area two months ago, which gradually increased in size, and now their left scrotum feels heavy, especially when they stand. They state “Honestly, it feels a bit like a bag of worms.” Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a warm, non-tender, non-fluctuant left scrotal mass that does not transilluminate. The swelling increases in size with the Valsalva maneuver and disappears on lying down. Right scrotum and penis appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a left-sided scrotal mass that feels like a “bag of worms,” does not transilluminate, and increases in size with Valsalva; varicocele is the most likely diagnosis. Varicocele is defined as dilation of the pampiniform plexus, which is the venous drainage network of the testes.

Left-sided varicocele is more common due to drainage of the left gonadal vein into the left renal vein at a perpendicular angle. The effect is compounded by the compression of the left renal vein between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery (nutcracker effect), increasing the intravascular pressure in the left gonadal vein and the dilation of the pampiniform plexus. A right-sided varicocele should always raise suspicion for retroperitoneal pathology (e.g. renal cell carcinoma), especially if it is non-diminishing on recumbent position.

Affected patients may be asymptomatic, but they can present with soft, unilateral scrotal mass that does not transilluminate, dull-aching scrotal pain, and/or infertility. A bag-of-worms-like appearance is seen on scrotal examination.

In contrast, a hydrocele is thought to result from an imbalance of fluid secretion and reabsorption in the tunica vaginalis, leading to fluid accumulation around the testes and spermatic cord. Affected patients present with a soft, non-tender fullness in the hemi-scrotum that transilluminates well. Inflammatory conditions, like epididymitis, and torsion can precipitate the development of hydrocele.



Option Analysis

❌ Bacterial sequestration in the epididymis:
Incorrect: Bacterial sequestration in the epididymis causes epididymitis. Affected patients present with a gradual onset of scrotal pain (not a mass) that is accompanied by dysuria, urgency, or frequency. It is often preceded by urethral discharge in sexually active individuals. Common organisms are N. gonorrhea and E. coli.
❌ Fluid in the tunica vaginalis:
Incorrect: Fluid in the tunica vaginalis results in the formation of a hydrocele. Affected patients usually present with a soft, non-tender fullness in the hemi-scrotum that transilluminates. This patient’s swelling did not transilluminate, making hydrocele less likely.
❌ Cystic dilation of epididymis:
Incorrect: Cystic dilation of the epididymis results in a spermatocele. It appears as a soft, round mass in the head of the epididymis that is located on the superior aspect of the testicles. Contrary to this patient’s presentation, a spermatocele does not enlarge with the Valsalva maneuver and is usually asymptomatic.
✅ Dilation of pampiniform plexus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neoplasia of left testes:
Incorrect: Testicular cancer is the most common cancer of young men and presents as a firm, non-tender nodule. It is discovered by the patient in most cases as a painless mass. Although similar to a varicocele in that it does not transilluminate, its size does not change with position as is observed in this patient.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to his cardiologist for a follow-up appointment after being prescribed a new medication several weeks ago. Symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and lower extremity swelling have improved. However, he has noticed that his chest wall has been more tender than usual. Moreover, the patient has had difficulty achieving an erection. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for bilateral gynecomastia. Which medications were most likely prescribed to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of heart failure, presents several weeks after initiating a new medication. His history and physical examination demonstrate gynecomastia and sexual dysfunction, which are concerning for antiandrogenic side effects. Of the medications listed, only spironolactone carries this side effect profile.    

Spironolactone works primarily as a competitive aldosterone receptor antagonist in the cortical collecting tubule. It induces diuresis while preserving plasma potassium levels. In addition to this mechanism, spironolactone carries moderate anti-androgen effects via the blockade of androgen receptors. This blockade can result in gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, erectile dysfunction, loss of libido, and mood changes in men. When used in women, anti-androgen effects can result in breast enlargement and menstrual disturbances.  

Despite these side effects, spironolactone’s anti-androgenic effects make it a useful medication in treating several clinical conditions and heart failure. It is often used to treat acne vulgaris and hirsutism in women and acts as hormone therapy for transgender females. 

Option Analysis

✅ Spironolactone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic often prescribed for treating heart failure and hypervolemia. It does not carry anti-androgenic properties that would cause gynecomastia and erectile dysfunction.
❌ Carvedilol:
Incorrect: ꞵ-blockers are often employed in treating heart failure and can cause depression. However, they are not known to cause gynecomastia. 
❌ Milrinone:
Incorrect: Milrinone is another medication often used in the treatment of heart failure and pulmonary hypertension that works via activation of protein kinase A and inhibition of PDE3, which leads to increased inotropy and chronotropy. 
❌ Eplerenone :
Incorrect: Eplerenone, like spironolactone, works as a competitive aldosterone antagonist. However, it lacks the anti-androgenic properties associated with spironolactone.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the clinic to evaluate nocturia and difficulty urinating. The patient has had these symptoms for a year, and it has been worsening. Currently, the patient wakes up three times a night to urinate. In addition, the patient noticed that it takes longer than usual for him to start urinating. Digital rectal examination reveals symmetrically enlarged prostate without nodularity. Urinalysis is within normal limits, and urinary culture is negative. The physician decided to start the patient on tamsulosin and finasteride. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of finasteride?

choices.text: Inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone
Blocks androgen receptors in the prostate gland
Relaxes the smooth muscles in the prostate gland and prostatic urethra
Inhibits testosterone production in the scrotum

questions.solution:
This patient with urinary flow obstruction (urinary hesitancy and straining) and irritative symptoms (frequency and nocturia) most likely have benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). It is a common disease in the elderly that occurs due to overgrowth of the prostate gland, leading to obstruction of the prostatic urethra and urinary symptoms. Finasteride is sometimes used in the treatment of BPH.

Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is an androgen that stimulates the growth of the prostate gland and is also associated with male pattern hair loss (i.e. androgenetic alopecia). Finasteride inhibits the conversion of testosterone to DHT by blocking the action of enzyme 5-alpha reductase, leading to decreased growth and, ultimately, shrinkage of the prostate gland, thereby reducing the blockage on the urethra. However, these effects usually take months to develop; therefore, finasteride's effects will only be seen after continuous use for a long period. Finasteride can also be used in the treatment of androgenetic alopecia.

Side effects of finasteride are common and include decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and gynecomastia. In addition, some patients may also experience orthostatic hypotension. Finally, patients taking finasteride at high doses may develop infertility, which in severe cases, may be irreversible.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blocks androgen receptors in the prostate gland:
Incorrect: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist usually used in metastatic prostate cancer. It is not frequently used in benign prostatic hyperplasia because of its feminization effects. Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor.  
❌ Relaxes the smooth muscles in the prostate gland and prostatic urethra:
Incorrect: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonists (e.g. tamsulosin) are the first-line treatment of BPH, and they work via relaxing the smooth muscles in the prostatic urethra and prostate glands, thereby resolving the urinary blockage. However, finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor, not an alpha-1 receptor antagonist.  
❌ Inhibits testosterone production in the scrotum:
Incorrect: Certain medications inhibit testosterone synthesis (e.g. ketoconazole). However, finasteride does not inhibit testosterone synthesis and sometimes increased testosterone levels can be seen in patients taking finasteride.  
❌ Inhibits the synthesis of gonadotropins:
Incorrect: Use of Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (e.g. Leuprolide) can lead to suppression of production of gonadotropins, leading to decreased testosterone production. However, finasteride does not inhibit the synthesis of gonadotropins.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the primary care office because of a weak urinary stream. This has been going on for the past six months and is gradually worsening to the point that he has to strain to urinate. The patient has urinary frequency and urgency but no incontinence or pain with micturition. He was treated two weeks ago with antibiotics for a presumed urinary tract infection. He also states that he has had difficulty maintaining erections for the past six months. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include atorvastatin and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, non-tender prostate with a rubbery texture. The rest of the examination is noncontributory. His recent HbA1c was 5.6%. Urinalysis is shown below. Prostate-specific antigen is 5.5 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s symptoms? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Urinalysis    
 Specific gravity     1.013    
 Glucose     negative    
 Blood     negative    
 Leukocyte esterase     negative    
 Nitrites     negative    
 Leukocytes     1-2/hpf    
 Erythrocytes     1-2/hpf
questions.solution:
The findings of irritative (urinary frequency, urgency) and obstructive symptoms (weak urinary stream and straining on micturition) in combination with a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, non-tender prostate with rubbery texture on digital rectal examination (DRE) make benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) the most likely diagnosis. The patient’s difficulty maintaining an erection indicates erectile dysfunction. Tadalafil, a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor, is the most appropriate medication for this patient.   

PDE-5 is responsible for the breakdown of cGMP and is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors with a resultant decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to smooth muscle relaxation (by enhancing NO activity). The net result is pulmonary vasodilation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis. Common indications include erectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension. Tadalafil, however, can also be used in the management of BPH. PDE-5 is highly expressed in the lower urinary tract and supporting vasculature. Tadalafil, due to its slightly different structure than other medications in its class, can also affect PDE-5 in the lower urinary tract. This decreases smooth muscle cell proliferation in the prostate and relaxes the smooth muscle in the prostate, bladder, neck, and supporting vasculature, thereby relieving the irritative and obstructive urinary symptoms.   

Option Analysis

❌ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole :
Incorrect: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is an antibiotic often used to treat urinary tract infections (UTI). These can present with suprapubic pain, dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency, with or without systemic toxicity. Urinalysis would show positive leukocyte esterase, more significant pyuria (white blood cells), and possibly nitrites. This patient’s urinalysis does not indicate UTI. 
❌ Prostatectomy :
Incorrect:  Although a prostatectomy is a management option for BPH, it is not usually pursued until medical treatment or transurethral techniques are proven ineffective or unavailable. 
❌ Sildenafil :
Incorrect: Sildenafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor and is usually used to manage erectile dysfunction. It does not provide symptomatic improvement of BPH. 
✅ Tadalafil  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ceftriaxone :
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone is an antibiotic often used to treat UTIs. These can present with suprapubic pain, dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency, with or without systemic toxicity. Urinalysis would show positive leukocyte esterase, more significant pyuria (white blood cells), and possibly nitrites. This patient’s urinalysis does not indicate UTI.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents for a follow-up regarding persistent urinary symptoms. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with mild benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH) after reporting difficulty initiating urination, a weak urinary stream, and nocturia twice per night. At that time, he had no hematuria, dysuria, or systemic symptoms. The International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) was 7, and a digital rectal examination revealed a symmetrically enlarged prostate without nodules. Urinalysis was unremarkable at that time, and the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level was within normal limits. The patient was advised to make lifestyle modifications, including reducing evening fluid intake, avoiding caffeine and alcohol, and performing pelvic floor exercises. At today’s visit, he states the symptoms are now interfering with his daily activities. A repeat IPSS score is 14. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Continue lifestyle modifications and reassess in three months
Refer for transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)

questions.solution:
This patient’s BPH has progressed from mild to moderate benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH), as reflected by the increasing International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) score and interference with daily activities. While lifestyle modifications are first-line management for mild symptoms, pharmacologic therapy is indicated for moderate symptoms that do not respond to conservative measures. Alpha-blockers such as tamsulosin are first-line medications that relax the smooth muscle in the bladder neck and prostate, improving urinary flow and providing symptom relief.       

Behavioral and lifestyle changes, such as reducing evening fluid intake, avoiding caffeine and alcohol, and performing pelvic floor exercises, are first-line treatments for mild BPH (IPSS 0-7) and can help alleviate lower urinary tract symptoms. Pharmacologic treatments include alpha-blockers (e.g., tamsulosin) that work by relaxing smooth muscle, PDE-5 inhibitors (e.g., tadalafil) that can be used in patients with concurrent erectile dysfunction, 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (e.g., finasteride) that reduce prostate size, and anticholinergics to treat irritative symptoms like urinary urgency. Combination therapy, such as an alpha-blocker with a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor, is effective for moderate-to-severe symptoms in patients who have an enlarged prostate. Surgical options, including transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), are reserved for severe cases (IPSS ≥ 20) or in patients with complications such as urinary retention or bladder stones. Oncology and urology consultations are important for patients with suspected prostate cancer or those requiring advanced therapies, such as radiation or prostatectomy.   

Option Analysis

❌ Continue lifestyle modifications and reassess in three months:
Incorrect: Continuing lifestyle modifications alone is insufficient in this case because the patient’s symptoms have progressed from mild to moderate severity, as evidenced by the increased IPSS score and ongoing impact on daily activities. Pharmacologic intervention is required to provide effective symptom relief.
✅ Start an alpha-blocker:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor:
Incorrect: While 5-alpha reductase inhibitors are beneficial for reducing prostate size, they are most effective in patients with significant prostate enlargement (greater than 30 mL) or an elevated PSA level. This patient does not have evidence of significant prostate enlargement, making an alpha-blocker a more appropriate first-line treatment for immediate symptom relief.  
❌ Perform a transrectal ultrasound (TRUS):
Incorrect: A transrectal ultrasound is not necessary at this stage as the patient’s symptoms can be adequately managed with pharmacologic therapy. Imaging studies are generally reserved for cases where there is uncertainty about the diagnosis or if surgical planning is needed.  
❌ Refer for transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP):
Incorrect: TURP is a surgical procedure typically indicated for patients with severe BPH symptoms (IPSS ≥20) or complications such as urinary retention or bladder stones. This patient has moderate symptoms without complications, making pharmacologic management the most appropriate next step.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the physician to discuss his hair loss. The patient first noticed the hair loss two years ago, which has progressed since then. His father and brother also had early hair loss. Physical examination reveals hair loss consistent with male pattern hair loss (i.e. androgenetic alopecia). The physician decided to start the patient on finasteride in addition to a ketoconazole shampoo. Which of the following best describes ketoconazole's role in treating this patient’s hair loss?

choices.text: Decreased testosterone synthesis by inhibiting 17,20 lyase enzyme
Decreased conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone by inhibiting the 5-alpha reductase enzyme
Direct stimulation of the growth of hair follicles
Increased blood flow to the hair follicles
Killing the fungi in the hair scalp

questions.solution:
This patient has androgenetic alopecia and was given finasteride and ketoconazole shampoo to decrease hair loss. Ketoconazole is an antifungal medication that has anti-androgen effects. These effects are due to two main mechanisms:

  • Ketoconazole inhibits the synthesis of testosterone by inhibiting the enzyme 17, 20 lyase, which is needed for the biosynthesis of testosterone
  • Ketoconazole also has competitive inhibition effects on androgen receptors.
Because of these anti-androgen effects, ketoconazole shampoo can be used to treat androgenetic alopecia (i.e. male pattern hair loss). It is often used with finasteride to produce greater effects and decrease hair loss.

Male patients taking ketoconazole to treat chronic fungal infections can experience side effects related to the anti-androgen effects of ketoconazole. These side effects include impotence, decreased libido, gynecomastia, oligospermia, and infertility.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased testosterone synthesis by inhibiting 17,20 lyase enzyme:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone by inhibiting the 5-alpha reductase enzyme:
Incorrect: 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (e.g. finasteride) are effective in treating androgenetic alopecia. However, ketoconazole does not inhibit 5-alpha reductase enzymes.  
❌ Direct stimulation of the growth of hair follicles:
Incorrect: Ketoconazole has no direct effect on the growth of hair follicles.  
❌ Increased blood flow to the hair follicles:
Incorrect: Minoxidil is one of the treatment options for hair loss for various causes. It increases the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) mRNA, increasing the blood flow to the hair follicles, and promoting their growth. Ketoconazole has no such effect.  
❌ Killing the fungi in the hair scalp:
Incorrect: The use of ketoconazole in androgenetic alopecia is due to its anti-androgen effects, not antifungal effects.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the primary care office because of trouble with vision. Over the past two weeks, the patient has been experiencing intermittent episodes of blue-tinted vision, which resolve within a few hours each time. He woke up today with blurry vision in the right eye. There is no eye pain, conjunctival redness, or headache. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type II diabetes mellitus, and erectile dysfunction. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows afferent pupillary defect, decreased visual acuity, and optic disc edema in the right eye. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibition of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in renal tubule
Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 in the endothelial cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a transient, bluish visual discoloration, afferent pupillary defect, decreased visual acuity, and optic disc edema in the right eye, together with a history of erectile dysfunction, is most likely due to an adverse effect of a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor (e.g., sildenafil, vardenafil, tadalafil). These agents are first-line medical therapy for erectile dysfunction. They can also be used to treat pulmonary hypertension.    

PDE-5 is responsible for the breakdown of cGMP and is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors with a resultant decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to smooth muscle relaxation (by enhancing NO activity). The net result is pulmonary vasodilation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis.    

Therefore, PDE-5 inhibitors are usually indicated in the treatment of erectile dysfunction (enhances the erectile response to sexual stimulation), pulmonary hypertension (reduces pulmonary vascular resistance), and benign prostate hyperplasia (only tadalafil specifically). Common side effects include facial flushing, headache, dyspepsia, hearing loss, and hypotension (when used with nitrates or alpha-adrenergic blockers). Sildenafil cross-reacts with PDE-6 in the retina and can cause transient blue vision (as seen in this patient). Rarely, non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) can occur.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase :
Incorrect: Statins act by inhibiting hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase, leading to a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and an increase in LDL recycling. Common side effects include hepatotoxicity, gastrointestinal discomfort, and rash. The blue-tinted vision seen in this patient is not associated with stains. 
❌ Inhibition of mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase :
Incorrect: Metformin (used for diabetes mellitus) inhibits gluconeogenesis by inhibiting mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase. Side effects include weight loss, gastrointestinal upset, and possibly lactic acidosis. Blue-tinted vision is not associated with metformin. 
❌ Inhibition of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in renal tubule :
Incorrect: Sodium-glucose co-transporter two inhibitors (e.g. canagliflozin) act on the renal tubule to prevent the reabsorption of glucose. Common adverse effects include urinary tract infections, vulvovaginal candidiasis, hypotension, and acute kidney injury. They are not associated with visual disturbances. 
❌ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-3 in platelets :
Incorrect: Antiplatelet phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitors (e.g., cilostazol) inhibit platelet aggregation via increased cAMP in platelets. Common side effects include dizziness, headaches, palpitations, and gastrointestinal disturbance. They do not affect vision. 
✅ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 in the endothelial cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the clinic with a concern about developing prostate cancer. He has been experiencing worsening urinary frequency, difficulty initiating urination, and waking up three to four times per night to urinate over the past year. There is no associated hematuria, weight loss, or back pain. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, managed with lisinopril. He has no family history of prostate cancer and does not smoke or drink alcohol. He has a co-worker who was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer, and the patient is worried he needs screening. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft, non-tender, and without palpable bladder distension. A digital rectal examination (DRE) reveals a nontender symmetrically enlarged prostate without nodules. Urinalysis is negative for infection, and there is no hematuria. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Engage in shared decision-making regarding whether to pursue prostate cancer screening
Order prostate biopsy to rule out malignancy
Repeat DRE and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing in 6 months
Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the prostate

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms consistent with benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH) and expresses concern about prostate cancer screening. Although BPH and prostate cancer both affect the prostate, BPH does not increase the risk of prostate cancer, and no specific monitoring or screening for prostate cancer is recommended in patients with BPH.        

Patients with BPH can be asymptomatic or they can present with storage or irritative symptoms and/or voiding symptoms. Storage symptoms include urinary frequency, urgency, ոоϲtսriа, and incontinence. Voiding symptoms include slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping), hesitancy, and terminal dribbling. On digital rectal exam (DRE) in patients with BPH, the prostate is symmetrically enlarged and smooth.        

BPH is not associated with systemic symptoms and does not increase the risk of prostate cancer. In contrast, patients with prostate cancer may present with similar urinary symptoms, but they often have red-flag signs such as unintentional weight loss, bone pain, or hematuria if advanced. On DRE, prostate cancer may be suggested by an asymmetric gland, nodules, or induration. Additionally, a persistently elevated or rapidly rising PSA level is concerning for malignancy, particularly when coupled with abnormal DRE findings or a family history of prostate cancer.       

The current guidelines for screening for prostate cancer in men aged 55 to 69 years recommend discussion and shared decision-making regarding screening with PSA and/or DRE. Routine screening, such as with annual PSA testing, is not recommended as it has not demonstrated a significant mortality benefit and can lead to overdiagnosis and overtreatment. During discussions on shared decision-making, the patient’s risk factors (e.g., age, family history) and personal preferences should be discussed to help make an informed choice about whether to pursue PSA screening. Shared decision-making should include discussions about the benefits, risks, and limitations of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing and treatments.   

Option Analysis

❌ Check prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels annually:
Incorrect: Routine PSA testing is not advised. PSA levels should only be checked if, after a discussion and shared decision-making, the patient chooses to proceed with screening. 
✅ Engage in shared decision-making regarding whether to pursue prostate cancer screening:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Order prostate biopsy to rule out malignancy:
Incorrect: A prostate biopsy is an invasive procedure and should only be performed if there is a high clinical suspicion of prostate cancer. Indications for a biopsy include persistently elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels, abnormal findings on DRE (e.g., nodules or asymmetry), or symptoms that suggest advanced disease (e.g., unexplained weight loss, or bone pain).  
❌ Repeat DRE and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing in 6 months:
Incorrect: Routine follow-up with DRE and PSA testing at fixed intervals, such as every six months, is not recommended unless clinical concerns require ongoing monitoring. These tests should only be performed as part of a shared decision-making process or if there is evidence of progression in symptoms or risk factors.  
❌ Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the prostate:
Incorrect: A multiparametric MRI is a diagnostic tool used to evaluate prostate lesions when prostate cancer is strongly suspected, such as in patients with elevated prostate-specific antigen or abnormal DRE. However, it is not a screening test and should not be performed in asymptomatic patients or in those with symptomatic benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH) without signs of prostate cancer.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the office because of erectile dysfunction. The patient reports a gradual decline in his ability to sustain an erection over the past several years. He used to wake up with erections, but no longer does. The patient retired from the army eight years ago. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, peripheral neuropathy, post-traumatic stress syndrome (PTSD), stable angina, and a prior myocardial infarction. Ophthalmologic evaluation six months ago revealed diabetic retinopathy, which was treated with photocoagulation. Current medications include metformin, escitalopram, aspirin, nitroglycerin, and atorvastatin. He drinks two to three drinks per week and has a 25 pack per year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased vibration sensation in both feet and a reduced pedal pulse on the left side. The patient requests a prescription of sildenafil. Which of the following is the most important consideration in prescribing sildenafil to this patient?
questions.solution:
Phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitors are first-line medications for the management of organic erectile dysfunction. Its use, however, is contraindicated in patients on nitrates (in this case, nitroglycerin).   

Nitrates are converted to nitric oxide, which promotes the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). An increase in cGMP leads to vascular smooth muscle relaxation. However, PDE-5, normally responsible for the breakdown of cGMP, is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors with a decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells. This results in cGMP accumulation, leading to excessive vasodilation and profound hypotension when used with nitrates. Their use together is absolutely contraindicated.   

Option Analysis

✅ Current use of nitroglycerin :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Peripheral neuropathy :
Incorrect: Peripheral neuropathy is not a contraindication to PDE-5 inhibitors. In fact, according to some studies, sildenafil has shown to decrease the symptoms of diabetic peripheral neuropathy. 
❌ Current use of atorvastatin :
Incorrect: There is no significant interaction between atorvastatin and PDE-5 inhibitor. 
❌ Diabetic retinopathy :
Incorrect: Although PDE-5 inhibitors are associated with temporary bluish visual discoloration due to the cross reactivity with PDE-6 inhibitors in the retina, this medication is not contraindicated in patients with diabetic retinopathy. 
❌ Current use of escitalopram :
Incorrect: Serotonin syndrome is an important consideration in prescribing a new serotonergic medication to a patient currently taking a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). However, sildenafil is not a serotonergic drug, so there is no concern regarding this patient’s use of escitalopram.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A few hours ago, he was playing basketball with his friends when he first developed mild abdominal pain. The pain increased gradually, and since then, the patient had increasing nausea and three episodes of vomiting. The patient has had similar, milder episodes in the past that resolved with rest. The review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a soft, nontender, and nondistended abdomen. There is marked swelling, erythema, and tenderness of the right hemiscrotum. The pain is worsened when the right testis is elevated, and the scrotum does not transilluminate. Cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. Physical examination of the left hemiscrotum and testis is unremarkable. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has acute-onset severe abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting, in combination with diffuse right scrotal swelling, erythema, tenderness, a negative Prehn sign (pain that does not resolve with the elevation of testicles), and an absent cremasteric reflex; this presentation is consistent with testicular torsion, which occurs as a result of the twisting of the spermatic cord.

Testicular torsion is one of the most common causes of acute scrotal pain in infants and post pubertal individuals. It occurs due to the insufficient fixation of the testis to the tunica vaginalis, leading to hypermobility, which allows for the twisting of the testis around the spermatic cord, cutting off its blood supply. Testicular torsion may occur after an inciting event (e.g., trauma, vigorous physical activity) or spontaneously.

Testicular torsion typically presents as an acute onset of scrotal pain with a negative Prehn sign. Some patients may present with diffuse lower abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting. Physical examination shows a tender, enlarged, high-riding testes with its long axis oriented transversely instead of longitudinally due to the shortening of the spermatic cord (“bell clapper deformity”). Cremasteric reflex is typically absent.





Diagnosis is based on physical examination and doppler ultrasound for confirmation. Treatment includes surgical correction (orchiopexy) or manual detorsion if the surgery is not possible. Delay in detorsion by a few hours may lead to testicular nonviability and infertility. If the testis is not viable, orchiectomy should be performed.

Option Analysis

✅ Twisting of the spermatic cord:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dilation of the pampiniform plexus:
Incorrect: Dilation of the pampiniform plexus results in a varicocele. It is more common on the left side, presents with dull abdominal pain that gets worse with standing, and feels like “a bag of worms” on physical examination. Cremasteric reflex is normal in cases of varicocele.
❌ Bacterial infiltration of the epididymis:
Incorrect: Acute epididymitis can result from the bacterial infiltration of the epididymis. It is characterized by localized testicular pain with tenderness and swelling on palpation of the affected epididymis (posterior testis). The pain is usually relieved by the elevation of testes (positive Prehn sign), unlike this patient. Dysuria and/or urethral discharge can also be present.
❌ Twisting of the appendix testis:
Incorrect: Testicular appendage torsion can present with acute onset testicular/abdominal pain. The swelling and tenderness, however, is localized to the head of the affected testes (unlike diffuse tenderness/swelling). Cremasteric reflex is typically present. A “blue dot” sign is often visible on physical examination, and the scrotal skin and testicles are usually normal-appearing and minimally tender.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A hydrocele can result from an accumulation of fluid between the layers of tunica vaginalis due to a  persistently patent processus vaginalis. Although scrotal swelling is apparent on the affected side, it does not cause acute severe testicular pain, and it transilluminates well.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of testicular pain and swelling. The patient was running when he felt sudden onset groin pain. Since then, he experienced severe scrotal pain with associated nausea and vomiting. He has had similar episodes of pain over the past two months that have all self-resolved without intervention. He has no significant past medical history and has received all age-appropriate vaccinations. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 141/80 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates an uncomfortable adolescent male in significant pain. Examination demonstrates an edematous and erythematous right scrotum. Stroking of the right inner thigh does not result in elevation of the right testis. The pain is worsened with elevation of the scrotum, and the scrotum does not transilluminate. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical fixation of the bilateral testicles
Surgical fixation of the right testicle

questions.solution:
This adolescent male presents with acute right-sided scrotal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The physical examination reveals an absent cremasteric reflex and negative Prehn sign, suggestive of testicular torsion. The most common abnormality associated with testicular torsion is known as the "bell clapper" deformity, where the testicle lacks the normal attachment to the tunica vaginalis, allowing for increased mobility and susceptibility to torse.

The most appropriate initial step when testicular torsion is suspected is immediate urologic consultation, as delays in surgical management may result in loss of the testicle from ischemia. Detorsion and fixation of both the affected testis and the contralateral uninvolved testis should be performed (termed an orchiopexy), since inadequate fixation is typically a bilateral defect. Prolonged periods of ischemia (>8 hours) may lead to infarction of the testis with necrosis, requiring removal of the affected testis (termed an orchiectomy).

Additional management includes ultrasonographic evaluation of blood flow to the testes, analgesia, and peri-operative clearance blood work. If surgical consultation is not immediately available, patients should undergo a trial of manual detorsion--wherein the testicle is rotated medial to lateral in one or two full 360 degree turns with the hope of restoring blood flow to the testicle.    

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical fixation of the bilateral testicles:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical fixation of the right testicle:
Incorrect: Although surgical fixation of the right testicle is emergent, bilateral fixation is almost always required, since inadequate gubernacular fixation is typically a bilateral defect.
❌ Ceftriaxone and doxycycline:
Incorrect: Antibiotic treatment for epididymitis in those under age 35 includes coverage for sexually transmitted infectious etiologies. Patients with epididymitis experience pain relief with elevation of the testis (Prehn sign), whereas patients with testicular torsion experience pain with any testicular manipulation.
❌ Reassurance and monitoring:
Incorrect: A hydrocele is a collection of peritoneal fluid between the parietal and visceral layers of the tunica vaginalis, and it is typically managed with reassurance if patients are asymptomatic. Although hydrocele is an potential cause of testicular swelling, it is almost always painless.
❌ Biopsy:
Incorrect: Testicular cancer can present as a firm, nontender nodule or mass that does not transilluminate. This young patient, in contrast, has severe, acute testicular pain, making another etiology more likely.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of persistent severe right testicular pain that started one hour ago. The patient has had similar episodes occurring in the right testicle in the past; however, each episode lasted for only a few minutes and resolved spontaneously. The pain was sharp and localized to the right testicle, radiating to the lower abdomen. Temperature is 37ºC (98.6°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 125/92 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. The patient appears uncomfortable. The right testicle is high-riding with a transverse lie. There is marked scrotal erythema and swelling. Cremasteric reflex is absent on the right. The left testicular examination is within normal limits. Urology is emergently consulted and takes the patient to the operating room. During the surgery, the right testicle is determined to be viable and lacking a normal attachment to the tunica vaginalis. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Detorsion of the right spermatic cord

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with intermittent testicular torsion that has progressed to acute testicular torsion. Given the history of recurrent episodes and the absence of a normal attachment of the right testicle to the tunica vaginalis (i.e. bellclapper deformity), orchiopexy of both testicles is indicated to prevent future episodes of torsion and preserve testicular viability. 

When testicular torsion is suspected, obtaining an emergent surgical consult is crucial, and manual detorsion should be attempted as an interim measure. Manual detorsion involves rotating the testicle in an "open book" motion, first in a medial-to-lateral direction, aiming to restore blood flow and alleviate pain. If unsuccessful, a lateral-to-medial rotation attempt can be made. Regardless of the success of the detorsion procedure, emergent surgical consultation should be pursued. Surgical intervention involves exploration of the scrotum for detorsion and fixation with orchiectomy reserved for cases of nonviable testes. Because the anatomical anomalies predisposing to torsion occur bilaterally, contralateral orchiopexy can be considered intraoperatively.    

Option Analysis

❌ Orchiopexy of the right testicle:
Incorrect: The patient's history of recurrent torsion and the anatomical anomaly discovered intraoperatively suggests potential bilateral involvement, necessitating bilateral orchiopexy. 
❌ Orchiectomy of the right testicle:
Incorrect: Orchiectomy of the right testicle is not warranted because it is still viable and further torsion can be prevented with the appropriate intervention. 
✅ Orchiopexy of both testicles:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Detorsion of the right spermatic cord:
Incorrect: Detorsion without orchiopexy addresses the acute torsion but does not prevent future episodes of torsion. Orchiopexy of the bilateral testicles is warranted. 
❌ Orchiectomy of both testicles:
Incorrect: Orchiectomy of both testicles is not appropriate for this patient with right testicular pain and a viable right testicle.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe right testicular pain that started one hour ago. He reports associated nausea and vomiting that started after the pain began. He was at soccer practice earlier that day, which he states was particularly strenuous. He is currently sexually active with two partners and uses protection inconsistently. He denies dysuria and penile discharge. Temperature is 37ºC (98.6°F), heart rate is 106/min, blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient appears to be in distress due to pain. Urinalysis is negative. Which of the following physical examination findings would be expected given the likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Pain relief with elevation of the right scrotum
Marked diffuse swelling and tenderness of the right scrotum

questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden onset severe right testicular pain, nausea, and vomiting following strenuous physical activity, suggesting acute testicular torsion. A distinctive feature of testicular torsion is the finding of marked diffuse swelling and erythema of the scrotum.

Acute testicular torsion typically presents in adolescent males with sudden, severe, unilateral testicular pain often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The pain often begins during sleep or following physical activity. Risk factors include increased vascularity, inflammation or trauma of the testicle, abnormal fixation of the testes, and rapid growth in the patient.

Clinically, the affected testicle may appear high-riding and assume a horizontal or transverse orientation due to twisting of the spermatic cord. On examination, there is typically marked diffuse tenderness and swelling of the scrotum. A key diagnostic feature is the absence of the cremasteric reflex on the affected side, where stroking the upper inner thigh fails to elicit the normal elevation of the testicle. In patients with diffuse scrotal pain and absent cremasteric reflex on the affected side, a presumptive diagnosis of testicular torsion can be made. 
     



Option Analysis

❌ Pain relief with elevation of the right scrotum:
Incorrect: Pain relief with elevation of the scrotum (also known as Prehn’s sign) is associated with epididymitis, not testicular torsion. This patient with acute testicular pain after vigorous exercise more likely has testicular torsion. 
✅ Marked diffuse swelling and tenderness of the right scrotum:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Positive right-sided cremasteric reflex:
Incorrect: Positive right-sided cremasteric reflex would be unlikely in the setting of acute testicular torsion of the affected side. The cremasteric reflex, which involves the elevation of the testicle when the inner thigh is stroked, is typically absent on the side of testicular torsion due to twisting of the spermatic cord.  
❌ Absent left-sided cremasteric reflex:
Incorrect: An absent left-sided cremasteric reflex would not be expected in a patient with right-sided testicular torsion. 
❌ Purulent urethral discharge:
Incorrect: In this patient with acute testicular pain associated with nausea and vomiting that occurred after strenuous exercise, testicular torsion is more likely than an STI with urethritis and/or epididymitis, which can present with purulent urethral discharge.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent episodes of left testicular pain that have occurred several times over the past month. Each episode lasts for a few minutes and resolves spontaneously. During these episodes, the pain is sharp and localized to the left testicle. The pain during these episodes causes significant discomfort, leading to limitations in his daily activities. He denies trauma, fever, or urinary symptoms. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses protection inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Both testicles are non-tender and lie in a normal, vertical orientation. No swelling or discoloration is noted. The cremasteric reflex is present bilaterally. There is no urethral discharge. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent episodes of testicular pain that resolve spontaneously; this is consistent with intermittent testicular torsion. In acute testicular torsion, patients experience persistent scrotal pain swelling and erythema from sustained twisting of the spermatic, and urgent surgical treatment is necessary to prevent ischemia of the testicle. With intermittent torsion, patients have brief periods of torsion followed by spontaneous detorsion, leading to transient pain that resolves on its own and recurs. Doppler ultrasonography allows for real-time assessment of blood flow to the testicles during these episodes or shortly thereafter. It can confirm the diagnosis by showing signs of altered blood flow during an episode or normal flow following detorsion. Additionally, doppler ultrasonography can reveal coiling of the spermatic cord, known as the “whirlpool sign,” seen with testicular torsion. Ultrasonography also helps to distinguish intermittent torsion from other causes of testicular pain, such as epididymitis and inguinal hernia.

If intermittent testicular torsion is diagnosed, treatment is similar for patients with acute testicular torsion. A surgeon with pediatric urologic expertise should be urgently consulted to evaluate the patient and make a decision regarding operative exploration and repair.   

Option Analysis

❌ 10-day course of levofloxacin:
Incorrect: Levofloxacin is an antibiotic used to treat epididymitis, which can masquerade as testicular torsion as it also presents with pain and tenderness of the scrotum or testicle. Epididymitis is usually caused by infection, and patients frequently report a gradual onset of pain with dysuria and tenderness of the epididymis found on exam, as opposed to the recurrent, self-resolving pain this patient has experienced over the past month.  
❌ Immediate surgical exploration:
Incorrect: While surgery is necessary for patients with acute testicular torsion, in patients with intermittent torsion without current symptoms, ultrasound should first confirm the diagnosis and the need for surgical intervention. 
✅ Doppler ultrasonography:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Scrotal support and regular follow-up:
Incorrect: This conservative approach does not address the potential underlying issue of intermittent torsion and the need to prevent future episodes of torsion in order to protect the testicles from damage. 
❌ Ibuprofen for pain management :
Incorrect: Non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can help manage pain; however, this option does not prevent future episodes of torsion. Diagnostic imaging is necessary to guide appropriate management.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset severe left testicular pain that started three hours ago while he was asleep. He reports associated nausea and vomiting following the start of the pain. He does not have dysuria. Temperature is 37ºC (98.6°F), heart rate is 106/min, blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient is in distress due to pain. The left testicle is high-riding with a transverse lie. There is marked scrotal erythema and swelling. Cremasteric reflex is absent on the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe antibiotics, analgesia, and schedule follow-up in one week
Apply ice packs, scrotal support, and reassess in 24 hours
Obtain emergent urology consultation and perform manual detorsion
Advise bed rest and observe for spontaneous resolution of symptoms

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe acute scrotal pain associated with nausea and vomiting and is found to have a high riding testicle with vertical lie, swelling, erythema, and an absent cremasteric reflex. These are classic signs and symptoms of acute testicular torsion, which is considered a urological emergency. Obtaining emergent urology consultation and performing manual detorsion is the appropriate treatment.

Immediate intervention is required for testicular torsion in order to attempt to salvage the testicle. Manual detorsion serves as a temporizing measure that can restore blood flow before definitive surgical intervention. This procedure involves rotating the testicle in a medial-to-lateral direction, akin to the motion of "opening a book.” When testicular torsion is suspected, emergent urology consultation is critical for definitive management, typically involving surgical exploration and detorsion with possible orchiopexy to prevent recurrence.    

Option Analysis

❌ Prescribe antibiotics, analgesia, and schedule follow-up in one week :
Incorrect: Immediate surgical treatment is necessary for testicular torsion; delay in treatment puts patients at risk for permanent testicular damage or loss due to prolonged ischemia. 
❌ Apply ice packs, scrotal support, and reassess in 24 hours:
Incorrect: Immediate surgical treatment is necessary for testicular torsion; delay in treatment puts patients at risk for permanent testicular damage or loss due to prolonged ischemia. 
✅ Obtain emergent urology consultation and perform manual detorsion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Order Doppler ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Many cases of testicular torsion, such as this one, do not require imaging to confirm the diagnosis if the history and physical examination are pathognomonic. For equivocal cases, color Doppler ultrasonography should be obtained urgently. 
❌ Advise bed rest and observe for spontaneous resolution of symptoms:
Incorrect: Immediate surgical treatment is necessary for testicular torsion; delay in treatment puts patients at risk for permanent testicular damage or loss due to prolonged ischemia.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS after a high-speed motor vehicle accident. He was the restrained driver of a vehicle when he was struck from the driver’s side by another car traveling at 55 mph. The patient has pelvic pain and lower abdominal pain. The patient's Glasgow Coma Scale is 15. He has severe pelvic pain. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 154/88 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Examination of the abdomen reveals a distended abdomen with suprapubic tenderness and ecchymosis across the pelvis. Examination of the pelvis demonstrates diffuse tenderness to palpation with associated crepitus and laxity. A high-riding prostate is noted on digital rectal examination. Pulses are 2+ and symmetric in the lower extremities. Neurologic exam is grossly intact. Which of the following best explains the prostatic examination findings in this patient?

choices.text: Injury of the posterior wall of the bladder

questions.solution:
This trauma patient has a likely bladder injury and a high-riding prostate due to a posterior urethral injury caused by a pelvic fracture. The secondary survey in a patient with pelvic fractures includes assessment of the anterior and posterior urethra. In a patient who is biologically male, the posterior urethra can be assessed by palpating for a high-riding prostate gland on digital rectal examination.  

Blunt force trauma, penetrating trauma, and iatrogenic injuries are the most common causes of bladder injury which can lead to concurrent pelvic fractures and urethral injuries. The secondary survey is done after the initial stabilization and acute management to assess the location and extent of the injuries. Following the primary survey, the secondary survey includes a detailed physical examination, laboratory evaluation, and Focused Assessment With Sonography in Trauma (FAST).    

Patients with a bladder injury may report symptoms of suprapubic pain, dysuria, hematuria, and difficulty voiding. Physical examination can reveal suprapubic tenderness or mass, with ecchymosis across the anterior pelvis or perineum. Gross hematuria and perineal swelling may occur. Signs of urethral injury include urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus, penile swelling or ecchymosis, and a high-riding prostate. Laboratory evaluation may reveal low hemoglobin and hematocrit if there is internal bleeding from a pelvic fracture, along with microscopic or gross hematuria. The FAST exam helps distinguish between an intraperitoneal vs. extraperitoneal bladder injury.
