Free fluid within the peritoneal cavity suggests the rupture occurred at the bladder dome whereas a lack of free fluid suggests the injury occurred in an area of the bladder below the peritoneal reflection with leaking urine into the perivesical space.  

Option Analysis

✅ Posterior urethral injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Penile fracture:
Incorrect: A penile fracture can be associated with an injury to the anterior urethra. This patient’s high-riding prostate indicates damage to the posterior portion of the urethra.
❌ Injury of the bladder dome:
Incorrect: Injury of the bladder dome may cause urine to leak into the peritoneum. This injury pattern would not affect the positioning of the prostate gland.
❌ Injury of the posterior wall of the bladder:
Incorrect: Injury to the posterior wall of the bladder will cause urine to leak into the perivesical space. It would not cause a high-riding prostate unless the posterior urethra was also injured.
❌ Prostatic hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Bleeding within the prostate gland is typically detected on imaging and would not result in a high-riding prostate.

questions.text: A 23-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the office because of chronic episodic pelvic pain. The pain begins 2-3 days before menses and continues throughout the menses after which it subsides. Menarche was at age 14. She has a regular menstrual cycle of 25 days with 5-6 days of moderate bleeding. Medical history is significant for recurrent migraine headaches with aura. She is not sexually active. Physical examination shows a fixed anteverted uterus and nodularity in the posterior cul-de-sac. The physician offers surgical therapy, which the patient declines at this time. Which of the following is the most appropriate option to treat this condition medically?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of chronic episodic pelvic pain, immobile (fixed) uterus and posterior cul-de-sac nodularity highly suggests the diagnosis of endometriosis.

Endometriosis is defined as implantation of endometrial glands and stroma outside the endometrium that grows and triggers an inflammatory response. It is a chronic condition that requires optimal approach for the management of related symptoms based on their severity. Patients with mild pain are usually managed with combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and as-needed non-steroids anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). For those with contraindications to combined OCPs (see table), progestin-only pills (POP) are an acceptable alternative, which act by inhibiting the growth of endometrial tissue.  

 

Laparoscopic resection of ectopic endometrial tissue is considered the gold standard and is both diagnostic and therapeutic. However, those with mild symptoms or those who decline surgery (as this patient) should be treated with medical therapy. Other medical treatment options which are reserved for patients with severe or recurrent symptoms include danazol, GnRH analogues, and aromatase inhibitors.  

Option Analysis

❌ Combined estrogen-progesterone oral contraceptive pills:
Incorrect: Combined OCPs act indirectly by suppressing ovarian hormones secretion, thereby reducing endometriosis disease activity. Although combined OCPs are the first-line agents in managing endometriosis-related pain, they are contraindicated in this patient due to the history of migraine headache with aura.
✅ Progestin-only pills:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Clomiphene:
Incorrect: Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that is used for ovulation induction. It works by inhibiting the negative feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary gland, thereby increasing follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). While endometriosis does predispose to infertility, this patient is not sexually active and is not planning for pregnancy at this time.
❌ Danazol:
Incorrect: Danazol inhibits mid-cycle surges of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) and prevents steroidogenesis in the corpus luteum. Although it is effective in treating endometriosis-related pain, it is not the preferred option due to its androgenic side effects (acne, edema, weight gain, hirsutism and gynecomastia).
❌ Anastrozole:
Incorrect: Anastrozole acts by inhibiting aromatase, the enzyme that converts androgens to estrogens, thereby regulating estrogen formation in the endometriotic lesions. Its off-label use for treating endometriosis-related pain is reserved for women with severe refractory pain because of limited data and the risk of osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the office due to difficulty conceiving. Menarche was at age 11 years, and her menstrual cycle has been irregular since then. She has been sexually active with her male partner for the past 3 years and has never used any form of contraception. The patient has gained 10kg (22 lbs) weight over the last year and has been unable to lose weight despite changes in her diet. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Her BMI is 32 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination shows scant thick hair along the jawline and hyperpigmented, velvety plaques under her axilla. Pelvic examination reveals normal external genitalia and a mobile and nontender uterus with no adnexal masses. TSH, LH and prolactin levels are within normal limits. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the best approach to manage this patient’s infertility?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with infertility, obesity and irregular menses, together with examination findings of hirsutism (hair growth on the chin) and acanthosis nigricans (hyperpigmented, velvety plaque under her axilla) is typical of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis as per Rotterdam criteria. Clomiphene citrate is the most appropriate option for ovulation induction in this patient.


Management options for PCOS in general include:

  •  Weight loss through diet and/or exercise 
  •  Metformin to increases insulin sensitivity 
  •  Spironolactone to treat hirsutism, but since it is teratogenic, some form of contraception is required. 
  •  Oral contraceptives to regulate the menstrual cycle 
  •  Clomiphene citrate or letrozole to induce ovulation 


Option Analysis

❌ Spironolactone:
Incorrect: Sprinolcatone is an antiandrogen that can be used to treat hirsutism in patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome. It is a teratogenic drug and should be avoided in women who desire pregnancy. It does not help in ovulation induction.
❌ Ovarian drilling:
Incorrect: Laparoscopic ovarian drilling involves puncturing a cystic ovary, thereby reducing ovarian secretion of androgens and proteins. The end-result is an increase in LH and FSH secretion, which leads to ovulation. It is the second-line option for ovulation induction in patients who fail to respond to clomiphene citrate or letrozole.
✅ Clomiphene citrate:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Bariatric surgery:
Incorrect: Although bariatric surgery can help with the restoration of ovulatory cycles, and improvements in insulin resistance, hyperandrogenemia, and hirsutism, it is not recommended in this patient with BMI <40 kg/m2.
❌ Progestin-releasing intrauterine device:
Incorrect: Progestin-releasing intrauterine device is an alternative treatment for endometrial protection in patients who choose not to or cannot take combined oral contraceptives. However, it does not help with ovulation induction.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to involuntary loss of urine and chronic constipation. The leakage of urine occurs in coughing, sneezing, or lifting heavy weights. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. The patient has had two forceps-assisted vaginal deliveries. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. Pelvic examination reveals dribbling of urine when asked to cough and a mass at the vaginal opening. Post void residual urine is 40ml. Urinalysis is negative for leukocyte esterase or nitrites. She undergoes a paravaginal defect repair. During the procedure, a nerve passing through the obturator foramen is injured. The patient is most likely to develop sensory loss over which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient has stress urinary incontinence, constipation, and a mass per vaginum. She most likely has pelvic organ prolapse (POP) complicated by stress urinary incontinence. POP management involves pelvic floor exercises, mid-urethral sling placements, or surgery to repair the pervaginal defect.    

The obturator nerve is formed from the second, third, and fourth lumbar roots. It courses through the pelvis, posterior to the psoas major muscle, and the sacrum until it enters the obturator canal within the obturator foramen. In the thigh, it divides into anterior and posterior divisions. Both divisions supply motor innervation to the adductor muscles of the thigh. The anterior division carries sensory input from the hip joint and the medial thigh, while the posterior division carries input from the knee joint.    

The obturator nerve can be injured during surgeries that involve dissection in the obturator fossa. These include pelvic resection surgeries for endometriosis, pelvic lymph node dissection in gynecological malignancies, pervaginal defect repairs, and retropubic sling placements for pelvic organ prolapse. It can also be compressed by pelvic tumors or injured by pelvic trauma. A diagnosis of obturator neuropathy is primarily clinical. Symptoms include sensory loss over the medial aspect of the thigh and weakness in leg adduction.   

Option Analysis

✅ Medial thigh :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior thigh :
Incorrect: The cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve supplies the anterior thigh. It exits the pelvis and passes along the femoral canal. It does not traverse through the obturator canal.   
❌ Medial leg :
Incorrect: The medial leg is innervated by the cutaneous branches of the saphenous nerve, a branch of the femoral nerve. It does not originate in the pelvis and is not likely to be damaged in this patient.   
❌ Medial foot :
Incorrect: The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the medial aspect of the foot. It is the branch of the common peroneal nerve and is unlikely to be injured in pelvic surgeries.   
❌ Posterior perineum :
Incorrect: The pudendal nerve provides sensory innervation to the perineum and the lower one-third of the vagina. It passes along the ischial spine and through the pudendal canal. It does not course through the obturator foramen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain. The pain began 6 hours ago and has become more severe over the last 2 hours. Past medical history includes seasonal depression and placement of a progestin-releasing IUD a month ago. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Bimanual examination reveals a tender, palpable left adnexal mass and visible IUD strings at the vaginal orifice. The urine pregnancy test is negative. The total leukocyte count is 8000/mm3. A transabdominal ultrasound reveals a hyperechoic adnexal mass with the decreased arterial flow. An explorative laparotomy is performed. The infundibulopelvic ligament is ligated during the procedure, and the pathological specimen is removed.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with acute onset of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and a tender adnexal mass with the decreased arterial flow. These findings are suggestive of ovarian torsion, which necessitates urgent intervention.    

Ovarian torsion is a common gynecological emergency among women of reproductive age, although it can occur in any age group. Clinical symptoms include sudden onset abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting with or without an adnexal mass. The most important risk factor for adnexal torsion is the presence of ovarian cysts or tumors, particularly those greater than 5 cm in size. Ovarian tumors are more common amongst women of reproductive age as most benign tumors (functional cyst, corpus luteum cysts) are associated with hormonal changes and ovulation induction therapy. Pathogenesis of ovarian torsion involves rotation of the ovary around the axis of its ligamentous attachment, the infundibulopelvic ligament. The presence of a large ovarian mass increases the likelihood of torsion.    

The infundibulopelvic ligament/suspensory ligament of the ovary attaches the superior pole of the ovary to the pelvic sidewall and contains the ovarian vessels. Rotation around its axis can impair the blood supply to the ovaries, which are detected as decreased blood flow on a doppler USG. Compression of the blood vessels impairs lymphatic and venous drainage and impedes arterial supply. Ovarian edema can progressively worsen and result in ischemia, local hemorrhage, and infarction complications.   

Option Analysis

✅ Ovarian torsion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ectopic pregnancy :
Incorrect: An extrauterine pregnancy is unlikely to cause abdominal pain as her last menstrual period was two weeks ago, and she has a negative pregnancy test.   
❌ Tubo-Ovarian abscess :
Incorrect: A tubo-ovarian abscess would cause fever and leukocytosis, neither of which are present in this patient. In addition, an abscess usually appears as an anechoic or hypoechoic fluid collection on ultrasound.   
❌ Uterine perforation :
Incorrect: Placement of IUDs can result in complications such as uterine perforation. It may present with severe, acute onset abdominal pain as seen in this patient. However, it is more likely to occur at the time of placement or immediately after and is unlikely in this case.   
❌ Endometriosis :
Incorrect: Endometriosis classically presents with chronic pelvic pain, infertility, and dysmenorrhea. This patient's acute onset of symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for a follow-up appointment. She was diagnosed with uterine fibroids eight months ago and prescribed several medications to treat associated menorrhagia. However, these medications have been largely ineffective. The patient continues to experience several days of painful and heavy bleeding every menstrual cycle. Past medical history is notable for irritable bowel syndrome, asthma, and migraine attacks with aura. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 112/67 mmHg, and pulse is 62/min. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged, asymmetric uterus. No cervical motion tenderness is elicited. After learning about the different treatment options, the patient decides to pursue surgical resection of the uterine fibroids. Which of the following treatments would be most effective in preoperatively reducing the size of her fibroids?
questions.solution:
This patient is scheduled for a myomectomy and was started on a medication preoperatively to help to reduce the size of her uterine fibroids. Among the answer choices, continuous leuprolide therapy would be most effective in achieving this effect.

Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist that can be administered in either a continuous or pulsatile pattern. When given in a constant pattern, the medication can cause down regulation of GnRH receptors in the pituitary. These changes lead to decreased secretion of FSH, LH, and sex hormones (e.g., testosterone and estrogen). As a result, continuous administration can help treat endometriosis, uterine fibroids, prostate cancer, and precocious puberty. Leuprolide is typically given preoperatively for 3-months to reduce the size of uterine fibroids before surgical resection. Furthermore, continuous leuprolide can be used in vitro fertilization techniques to prevent premature ovulation.

On the other hand, pulsatile therapy of leuprolide mimics the physiological secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus. In other words, the drug binds and activates GnRH receptors, thereby increasing the downstream synthesis of LH, FSH, and sex hormones. This administration method was historically used to induce ovulation and treat infertility but is rarely used today due to the availability of better alternatives (e.g. clomiphene).  

Option Analysis

❌ Estrogen-progesterone combined oral contraceptive therapy:
Incorrect: Combined oral contraceptives can be used to treat menorrhagia secondary to uterine fibroids. This patient's combined oral contraceptives are contraindicated given her history of migraine with auras. Furthermore, combined oral contraceptives are mainly ineffective in reducing the size of fibroids.  
✅ Continuous leuprolide therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tranexamic acid therapy:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic that can be used to treat heavy menstrual bleeding secondary to uterine fibroids. TXA does not alter uterine fibroid size and therefore would have unlikely been prescribed to this patient.  
❌ Tamoxifen therapy:
Incorrect: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. This medication is an estrogen receptor antagonist in the breast but serves as an agonist in the bones, uterus, and endometrium. As a result, this medication is not typically used to reduce the size of uterine fibroids preoperatively.  
❌ Pulsatile nafarelin therapy:
Incorrect: Nafarelin is a GnRH agonist, a class of medications that can treat conditions including endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and prostate cancer. If a GnRH agonist is given in a continuous pattern, it downregulates GnRH receptors in the pituitary gland, reducing FSH, LH, and sex hormone secretion. These changes can cause fibroids to shrink. In contrast, a GnRH agonist given in a pulsatile pattern increases FSH and LH secretion, leading to fibroid enlargement.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 2, presents to the office for evaluation of amenorrhea. Menarche was at age 12, and she had a regular 28-day cycle with no dysmenorrhea until four months ago when her cycle stopped. Past medical history is significant for two missed abortions, the last of which was six months ago, managed via dilation and curettage. She has a healthy five-year-old girl and a three-year-old boy born via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is not taking any medications currently. Family history is significant for hypothyroidism in her mother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 22 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Speculum examination shows moist vaginal mucosa with no abnormalities. Urine beta-HCG is negative. FSH, TSH, and prolactin levels are normal. A progesterone withdrawal test is performed with no withdrawal bleeding. An estrogen/progesterone withdrawal test is performed. Bleeding is absent again. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of secondary amenorrhea, a history of an intrauterine procedure (dilation and curettage), routine laboratory findings, and absence of bleeding on progesterone challenge test and estrogen/progesterone withdrawal test make the diagnosis of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome) most likely.

A 10-day medroxyprogesterone test (progestin challenge) assesses uterine function. It involves administering 10 milligrams of medroxyprogesterone daily for ten days to see if that induces menstrual bleeding. A healthy uterus should bleed. If there’s no bleeding, estrogen is given to thicken the uterine lining, and medroxyprogesterone is added. Failure to bleed strongly suggests endometrial scarring.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is a disorder caused by disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Common risk factors include stress, anorexia nervosa, and excessive exercise.  The condition is most commonly seen in young athletes. The cause of amenorrhea in this patient with normal lifestyle habits and a healthy body mass index is unlikely. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels and absence of bleeding on the progesterone challenge test suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Endometriosis:
Incorrect:  Endometriosis presents in women of reproductive age with pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia (due to lesions in the posterior cul-de-sac). This patient has had none of these complaints, making this diagnosis less likely.  
✅ Asherman syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Primary ovarian insufficiency:
Incorrect: Accelerated follicular depletion can be due to primary ovarian insufficiency or secondary to follicular atresia due to other causes (radiation, chemotherapy, autoimmune). It commonly presents with irregular menstrual cycles, hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and elevated FSH levels, none seen in this patient. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels and absence of bleeding on the progesterone challenge test suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Although amenorrhea can be seen in hypothyroidism, it is usually accompanied by fatigue, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and other findings not seen in this patient. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels make this cause less likely. The absence of bleeding on progesterone challenge tests suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of moderate to severe pelvic pain that is crampy and occurs recurrently during menstruation. She also experiences headaches and nausea during menstruation. Her first menstruation occurred nine months ago. She has no vaginal discharge and no acyclic vaginal bleeding. The patient has missed several school days each month due to her symptoms. She is not sexually active and has no significant past medical history. She has no known allergies. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing adolescent girl with a benign abdominal examination. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy adolescent girl with menarche 9 months ago presents with recurrent crampy pelvic pain during menstruation and can be diagnosed with primary dysmenorrhea. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, naproxen, or celecoxib are considered first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea.    

Primary dysmenorrhea is a clinical diagnosis and can be made in patients with symptoms and history that are consistent with primary dysmenorrhea and without underlying evidence of pelvic abnormalities. NSAIDs are considered first-line treatment. They can be started a day or two before menses are expected. Acetaminophen can be tried in patients who cannot tolerate or are allergic to NSAIDs. Hormonal therapies can be considered when first-line treatments fail to control symptoms (e.g. oral contraceptive pill, progestin implant, depot medroxyprogesterone acetate). Choice of hormonal therapy should be based on patient preference and eligibility, and the side effects of the different therapies. In addition, patients may also consider alternative and complementary therapies such as exercise, heat therapy, dietary supplements, and smoking cessation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ibuprofen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Progestin-only implant:
Incorrect: Hormonal therapies can provide pain relief for patients with primary dysmenorrhea; however, NSAIDs are considered first-line treatment. Hormonal agents can be started if conservative treatment with ibuprofen and other NSAIDs fails. 
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen can be used in patients who have contraindications to or cannot tolerate NSAIDs. NSAIDs are considered first-line treatment.
❌ Combined oral contraceptive pill:
Incorrect: Hormonal therapies can provide pain relief for patients with primary dysmenorrhea. However, these agents should be considered if conservative treatment with ibuprofen or other NSAIDs fails. 
❌ Intramuscular depot medroxyprogesterone acetate:
Incorrect: Hormonal therapies can provide relief to patients with primary dysmenorrhea. However, these agents should be considered if conservative treatment with ibuprofen or other NSAIDs fails.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman comes to her physician’s office for evaluation of a 6-month history of amenorrhea with associated vaginal dryness and hot flashes. She has been attempting to conceive for the past year without success. Her past medical history is significant for Hashimoto thyroiditis for which she takes daily levothyroxine. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 24 kg/m2. Hair growth and pattern are normal, and breast development is normal. Pelvic examination is normal and there is no evidence of bleeding, masses, or cervical motion tenderness. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

Estradiol
<5 pg/mL  
Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)  
65 mU/mL (60 U/L)  
Luteinizing hormone  
60 mU/mL (60 U/L)  
Total testosterone  
25 ng/dL  
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)  
2.3 μU/mL (2.3 mU/L)  
Prolactin
18 ng/mL (18 µg/L)  
Human chorionic gonadotropin  
Negative
questions.solution:
This patient presents with 6 months of signs and symptoms of estrogen deficiency (e.g., vaginal dryness, hot flashes, amenorrhea, and infertility), and laboratory testing revealed elevated luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone levels and a low estradiol level. This presentation in a 33-year-old woman is consistent with a diagnosis of primary ovarian insufficiency.

Premature ovarian insufficiency (POI) is characterized by the loss of normal ovarian function before the age of 40. Patients typically present with signs and symptoms of estrogen deficiency (such as hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and amenorrhea). The diagnosis is supported by laboratory results that demonstrate low estradiol and elevated levels of FSH and LH. The elevated gonadotropins (FSH and LH) indicate that the dysfunction is at the level of the ovaries rather than pituitary or hypothalamic level. POI can be secondary to autoimmune disease, which is the most likely etiology in this patient who has a history of autoimmune thyroid disease (Hashimoto thyroiditis). Genetic abnormalities and toxin exposure (chemotherapy, radiation therapy) can also be the cause of POI. Most cases are idiopathic.  

Option Analysis

✅ Primary ovarian insufficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea occurs from low energy availability (decreased caloric intake, excessive energy expenditure, or both) and/or stress. It is characterized by amenorrhea with normal or low serum gonadotropin concentrations and low serum estradiol concentrations. This patient has elevated levels of FSH and LH.  
❌ Polycystic ovarian syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome typically have signs of hyperandrogenism (such as hirsutism), oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea, and obesity. Laboratory testing may reveal elevated testosterone levels. This patient shows no evidence of hyperandrogenism and has a normal serum total testosterone level and normal BMI, making PCOS unlikely.  
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Patients with hypothyroidism may have irregular menstrual cycles or amenorrhea; however, this patient has a normal TSH on thyroid replacement therapy.  
❌ Prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma:
Incorrect: A prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma typically presents with galactorrhea and menstrual irregularities. Patients with prolactinomas typically have prolactin levels that are way above normal. This patient has a normal prolactin level.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with several hours of nausea, vomiting, and severe left lower quadrant colicky abdominal pain that started after she returned from jogging earlier that morning. The patient reports a similar issue a few years ago requiring surgery for “untwisting” the ovary. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.7 ºC (99.9 ºF), pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 156/91 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. Beta hCG is negative. Abdominal exam reveals moderate tenderness to palpation at the left lower quadrant of the abdomen with guarding and no rebound. A transvaginal ultrasound is performed and shows a left adnexal mass with a whirlpool sign. Laparoscopy confirms left adnexal torsion. The ovary is viable and there is no evidence of ovarian cyst or neoplasm. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden and severe left lower abdominal pain that began after jogging. She has what sounds like a history of adnexal torsion. The diagnosis of adnexal torsion is confirmed with transvaginal ultrasound. Since this has occurred before and there is no ovarian pathology on laparoscopy, laparoscopic detorsion is the most appropriate management.  

Patients with adnexal torsion generally present with sudden onset abdominal or pelvic pain, which is often intermittent/colicky. Beta hCG will be negative in most patients. Transvaginal (pelvic) ultrasound is the best diagnostic modality for making the diagnosis. An asymmetrically enlarged ovary with absent Doppler flow indicates adnexal torsion. A whirlpool sign (twisted pedicle) may also be seen. If pelvic ultrasound is consistent with adnexal torsion, diagnostic laparoscopy should be performed for laparoscopic detorsion in most cases.

If a benign mass is found and the adnexa is viable, then cystectomy is typically performed along with detorsion. If the adnexa is viable and there have been multiple recurrent torsions and no ovarian or adnexal pathology, then oophoropexy may be considered, to prevent recurrences. It also may be considered in cases of torsion where the patient does not have a contralateral ovary. However, there is no long-term efficacy data on this approach. If ovarian malignancy is suspected, then oophorectomy with salpingectomy should be performed. If the adnexa is non-viable and necrotic, then it should be removed. 

Option Analysis

❌ Oophoropexy  :
Correct: Oophoropexy may be considered in patients with adnexal torsion who have only one ovary to prevent recurrence from occurring in that remaining ovary. It may also be considered in patients with 2 or more episodes of adnexal torsion. However, there are no studies on the long-term efficacy of this approach.
❌ Oophorectomy:
Incorrect: Oophorectomy should be considered if there is adnexal pathology like a large cyst or neoplasm and/or the ovary is non-viable with evidence of necrosis. This patient has a viable ovary without pathology, therefore the next best step is detorsion.
❌ Oophorectomy and salpingectomy:
Incorrect: Oophorectomy can be considered if there is adnexal pathology and/or non-viable adnexa. If adnexa are non-viable, salpingectomy can be performed, especially if there is a potential malignant mass seen. This patient has viable adnexa with no adnexal pathology and thus the ovary can be salvaged.
❌ Cystectomy:
Incorrect: If there is a large cyst noted on the torsed ovary, then it can be excised as it may have been the cause of torsion. 
✅ Detorsion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding that began 2 years ago and has been worsening during the past 6 months. Her periods previously lasted  5 days and now last 9 to 11 days. She often uses more than 100 tampons per month and soaks through pads at night. She reports constant aching pelvic pain that significantly worsens with menstruation. The pain is partially relieved with naproxen but interferes with her daily activities. She denies postcoital bleeding but has occasional spontaneous intermenstrual spotting. She also has mild dyspareunia. She does not have changes in urination or bowel habits, fever, or vaginal discharge. Her medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes controlled by diet. She has had 3 uncomplicated pregnancies and deliveries. Her last PAP smear 9 months ago was normal. Family history is significant for a sister with fibroids. Abdominal exam reveals mild lower abdominal tenderness without rebound. Pelvic examination reveals a mobile, soft, tender uterus, uniformly enlarged to 12 cm, and no adnexal tenderness or masses. hCG is negative. Which of the following findings on ultrasound will help confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Hypoechoic, well-circumscribed mass within the myometrium
Homogeneously hypoechoic pelvic mass with posterior acoustic enhancement
Complex cystic pelvic mass with echogenic components
Myometrial cyst, with a heterogeneous myometrium and asymmetric myometrial thickness

questions.solution:
This 41-year-old patient who presents with prolonged, heavy menstrual bleeding, constant aching pelvic pain that worsens with menstruation, intermenstrual spotting, dyspareunia and pelvic examination findings of a uniformly enlarged soft tender uterus likely has adenomyosis. The pelvic ultrasound findings of a myometrial cyst, heterogeneous myometrium, and asymmetric myometrial thickness supports the diagnosis of adenomyosis. However, definitive diagnosis can only be made by pathologic evaluation of a hysterectomy specimen.  

Adenomyosis is a benign uterine condition characterized by the presence of ectopic endometrial stroma and glands in the myometrium. The presence of this ectopic tissue in the myometrium causes it to appear heterogeneous. Varying amounts in different areas create the asymmetric thickness, while the cysts represent dilated endometrial glands. These characteristic ultrasound findings help to differentiate adenomyosis from other causes of chronic pelvic pain and bleeding such as leiomyomata and endometriosis. Other ultrasound findings may include striated projections from the endometrium, an obscured endometrial echo border and a globally enlarged uterus. In addition, affected areas of the myometrium may show diffuse vascularity with color doppler.  

Most cases of adenomyosis are diagnosed in parous women in their 40s and 50s, with regression noted following menopause. Adenomyosis can be seen in association with leiomyomata, endometriosis and even endometrial hyperplasia. A possible explanation is that all four are considered estrogen dependent diseases, with growth and symptoms influenced by higher tissue estrogen levels.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hypoechoic, well-circumscribed mass within the myometrium:
Incorrect: This is a typical ultrasound finding for an intramural leiomyoma. Leiomyomata can be subserosal, intramural or submucosal. Although they can cause pain and bleeding, the presence on pelvic examination and a uniformly enlarged uterus, rather than an irregularly shaped uterus, suggests adenomyosis.
❌ Homogeneously hypoechoic pelvic mass with posterior acoustic enhancement :
Incorrect: This is a classic ultrasound description of an endometrioma seen with endometriosis, also known as a chocolate cyst. Although endometriosis can cause pain, dyspareunia, and bleeding, pelvic examination, findings of nodularity, adnexal tenderness, and/or masses would be expected. This patient’s exam is most consistent with adenomyosis.
❌ Complex cystic pelvic mass with echogenic components:
Incorrect: This would be the finding of a benign cystic teratoma with the echogenic components representing hair, teeth, and fat. They can present with pain but are not associated with this bleeding pattern. Also, this patient does not have an adnexal mass but rather an enlarged tender uterus, findings seen with adenomyosis.  
✅ Myometrial cyst, with a heterogeneous myometrium and asymmetric myometrial thickness:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Thickened fluid-filled tubular structure:
Incorrect: This is a classic description of a hydrosalpinx seen in patients with a history of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Pelvic inflammatory disease can cause pelvic pain but is not typically associated with the severe abnormal vaginal bleeding seen in this patient. This patient’s history and pelvic examination are consistent with a diagnosis of adenomyosis and not PID.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman, gravida 0, presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of chronic dysmenorrhea. The patient has been having increasingly painful menstrual cycles for the past five years with associated low back pain. She is currently in a relationship and has also been having significant discomfort with sexual intercourse. Gynecologic history is notable for menarche at age 13 and an episode of gonorrhea for which she was treated with antibiotics. She also has a history of anxiety and depression for which she takes sertraline daily. Family history is significant for painful menstruation and infertility in her mother. Vital signs are within normal limits, and body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Abdominal exam is unremarkable, and pelvic examination is within normal limits. Which of the following clinical elements is the strongest risk factor for the likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient, presenting with chronic dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and a family history of dysmenorrhea and infertility most likely has endometriosis. Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial stroma or glands outside of the endometrial cavity. One of the strongest risk factors for this condition is a first-degree relative with endometriosis. The fact that this patient’s mother had dysmenorrhea and infertility is suggestive of a diagnosis of endometriosis in her mother.

The key clinical feature of endometriosis is pelvic pain, including the 4 D’s: dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dyschezia, and dysuria. Patients often also have low back pain during menses; and they may experience chronic, non-cyclic pelvic pain and/or infertility related to the inflammation and subsequent pelvic adhesions caused by the disease. Risk factors for developing endometriosis include a first-degree relative with endometriosis; early menarche, specifically occurring before age 11; shorter menstrual cycles; and heavy menstrual bleeding.

Physical examination is often non-specific but may reveal abdominal or pelvic tenderness; uterosacral ligament nodularity; and occasionally, palpation of an adnexal mass suggestive of an endometrioma.

Option Analysis

✅ Family history:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of sexually transmitted infection (STI):
Incorrect: A history of STI is not a risk factor for the development of endometriosis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. However, STI’s can predispose patients to pelvic inflammatory disease and subsequent infertility.
❌ Sertraline use:
Incorrect: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) use is not a risk factor for the development of endometriosis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.
❌ Age at menarche:
Incorrect: Early menarche, defined as menses beginning at or before age 11, is a risk factor for endometriosis (which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient). This patient’s menstrual cycles began at age 13.
❌ Body mass index (BMI):
Incorrect: Lower, rather than higher (as seen in this patient), BMI is associated with an increased risk of endometriosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the clinic for a 3-month follow-up for chronic vulvar pruritus and soreness. She has been compliant with treatment with a medium-potency topical corticosteroid but continues to be symptomatic. The only body area affected is the genitals. The patient has not had any recent use of new soaps, detergents, or fabric softeners. She is not currently sexually active. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension, which is well-controlled with lisinopril. Her family history is unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there are violaceous, flat-topped papules and plaques on the vulvar skin, with a fine, white, reticulated pattern on the surface. There is a large erosive lesion in the vaginal introitus and yellow vaginal discharge, which were not present at the last clinic visit. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for diagnosing this patient's condition?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of chronic vulvar pruritus and soreness along with her physical examination findings (violaceous, flat-topped papules and plaques with Wickham striae) is consistent with lichen planus. However, she continues to have symptoms despite corticosteroid therapy and has developed additional vaginal erosions and discharge. The next step is to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other potential causes of her symptoms with a biopsy.        

There are several chronic vulvar skin disorders which can cause similar symptoms and physical findings. These include contact dermatitis, atopic dermatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, psoriasis, lichen simplex chronicus, lichen sclerosus, and lichen planus. Most of these can be diagnosed clinically, by evaluating the patient’s history for potential contact exposures (e.g., soaps, medications), history of skin conditions in other body regions (e.g., psoriasis, eczema), types of symptoms (e.g., pruritus, pain), and duration of symptoms. From there, the physical examination can provide additional clues, particularly the type, appearance, and location of vulvar lesions, and involvement of other locations (e.g., vagina). The following table differentiates the 3 types of lichen diagnosis.  



Though a clinical diagnosis is usually sufficient, additional testing should be considered on a patient-by-patient basis to rule out other potential or concurrent diagnoses. If sexually transmitted infections are a possibility, appropriate testing (e.g., NAAT) should be performed. Microscopy may also be a consideration if fungal infections, such as candidiasis, need to be ruled out. Vulvar biopsy should be performed if there is concern for malignancy (e.g. atypical lesion characteristics), if the diagnosis is uncertain, or when symptoms and exam findings do not improve despite appropriate therapy. 

Option Analysis

✅ Biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Pathergy testing:
Incorrect: A positive pathergy test can be used to help diagnose Behcet disease; however, this patient does not have oral aphthous ulcers, eye findings, or a family history of the disease, making this condition unlikely. A biopsy would be the most helpful next step in determining the diagnosis of this patient.  
❌ Potassium hydroxide preparation:
Incorrect: A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to diagnose fungal infections, like candidiasis, by revealing fungal hyphae. While candidiasis can cause vulvar itching and irritation, the presence of violaceous, flat-topped papules and plaques with a white, reticulated pattern is not typical of this condition. These findings are typically seen with lichen planus. 
❌ Allergy testing:
Incorrect: Allergic contact dermatitis is a common cause of vulvar itching and irritation and should be considered, especially with a history of new product use. However, this patient does not report any recent changes in detergents, soaps, or other products, and the physical examination findings are atypical for contact dermatitis. The exam findings are typically seen with lichen planus. 
❌ Nucleic acid amplification testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia:
Incorrect: While these STIs can cause vulvar irritation and vaginal discharge, this patient is not currently sexually active, and physical examination findings do not fit these diagnoses. The exam findings are typically seen with lichen planus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 0, presents to the clinic with worsening right lower quadrant pelvic pain over the past 5 months. She notes that, over the same time period, menstrual cramping and intercourse have become more painful. She has no gastrointestinal symptoms other than occasional pain with defecation. Past medical history is notable for a laparoscopic appendectomy at age 8, and the patient takes no medication. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mmHg. The exam shows tenderness and fullness in the right adnexa. Urine pregnancy test is negative, and office urinalysis is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Malignant epithelial invasion through the basement membrane

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with an endometrioma. Patients typically present with abdominal/pelvic pain frequently related to menstruation (dysmenorrhea) and sexual intercourse (dyspareunia). Dyschezia, dysuria, and prolonged pelvic pain are also common. Additionally, although an endometrioma and hemorrhagic cyst can have a similar appearance on ultrasound, symptoms of a hemorrhagic cyst should resolve over one or two months, while pain from an endometrioma persists and often worsens over time. An endometrioma is caused by the ectopic implantation of endometrial tissue on or within the ovary, leading to a cystic adnexal mass containing endometrial fluid. It is sometimes referred to as a “chocolate cyst” because it is typically filled with thick brown fluid. Surgery is often required.

In patients with a suspected endometrioma, history and exam including pain symptoms, abnormal bleeding, adnexal fullness or tenderness, and/or risk factors for cancer should prompt the physician to order a pelvic ultrasound. A pelvic ultrasound is typically able to establish the diagnosis. Diagnostic features of different types of adnexal masses are detailed in the table below.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Ectopic endometrial tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Unruptured ovarian follicle:
Incorrect: A simple ovarian cyst typically originates from an unruptured ovarian follicle. Often, these cysts are asymptomatic until they get quite large or rupture. The duration of pain caused by a large, unruptured ovarian follicle is variable. It can last from a few days to several weeks, depending on the size of the cyst and whether it undergoes any changes such as further enlargement, rupture, or resolution. This patient’s chronic presentation is more consistent with an endometrioma. 
❌ Bleeding ovarian follicle:
Incorrect: A ruptured hemorrhagic cyst typically originates from bleeding within an ovarian follicle. The associated pain usually has an acute onset and slowly resolves over several months, unlike the patient’s presentation of chronic worsening pelvic pain.  
❌ Abnormal growth of smooth muscle:
Incorrect: An adnexal mass can actually be a pedunculated uterine leiomyoma. These patients may experience pelvic pressure, unilateral pain, or abnormal uterine bleeding. The patient’s presentation is more consistent with an endometrioma. 
❌ Malignant epithelial invasion through the basement membrane:
Incorrect: Malignant tumors are much more common in postmenopausal patients, and patients may also have a relevant family history. Malignant tumors are often asymptomatic, but can present with pain, bloating, early satiety, and/or abdominal distension.

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulligravid woman presents to the clinic with infertility. She and her partner have been trying to conceive for 12 months without success despite regular unprotected intercourse. She has regular menstrual cycles, coming every 29 to 30 days, lasting 4 days, with average flow, and without significant dysmenorrhea. Review of systems is negative. Past medical history is notable for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) six years ago. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or drugs. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. The head, neck, thoracic, and abdominal exams are normal. Pelvic exam shows adnexal fullness on the left side. A urine pregnancy test is negative, and standard serum hormone testing is within normal limits. A pelvic ultrasound shows an adnexal mass. Considering the most likely diagnosis, the adnexal mass is most likely to have which of the following characteristics?

choices.text: 4 cm tubular cystic structure adjacent to the ovary, with incomplete septations
12 cm cystic structure within the ovary, without loculations or internal echoes
3 cm solid mass adjacent to the ovary, with Doppler flow connecting to the uterus
3 cm heterogeneous mass adjacent to the ovary, with Doppler flow within the mass
7 cm cystic mass within the ovary, with multiple loculations and mural nodules

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), infertility, and the presence of an adnexal mass are suspicious of a hydrosalpinx, which is a collection of inflammatory fluid within the fallopian tube. A hydrosalpinx indicates tubal damage, often from a prior pelvic infection or another inflammatory process, such as endometriosis. The tube may either be blocked entirely, or it can leak inflammatory fluid into the uterus, preventing pregnancy. Serum hormone testing is normal. On ultrasound, a hydrosalpinx typically appears as a dilated, tubular structure adjacent to the ovary; the structure may also appear to have incomplete septations which represent thickened endosalpingeal folds.
 

Hydrosalpinx on imaging: Transvaginal ultrasound shows an anechoic, tubular structure with incomplete septations.  
The diagnostic work-up of an adnexal mass is guided by the patient’s history and physical exam, but it should always include a pelvic ultrasound to better characterize the mass. A pregnancy test is required in all premenopausal patients to exclude an ectopic pregnancy. Additional testing, such as serum testing for patients with infertility or abnormal uterine bleeding, may also be indicated. If an adnexal mass is discovered incidentally on imaging, the need for further investigation should be based on the patient’s symptoms and specific ultrasound findings. Diagnostic features of different types of adnexal masses are detailed in the table below.
 
     

Option Analysis

✅ 4 cm tubular cystic structure adjacent to the ovary, with incomplete septations :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 12 cm cystic structure within the ovary, without loculations or internal echoes :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with cystadenoma. However, in a young woman with a history of PID and infertility, hydrosalpinx is more likely.  
❌ 3 cm solid mass adjacent to the ovary, with Doppler flow connecting to the uterus :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a pedunculated uterine leiomyoma. Patients with fibroids often present with bulk symptoms or abnormal uterine bleeding, which this patient lacks. Additionally, with the patient’s history of PID and infertility, hydrosalpinx is more likely.  
❌ 3 cm heterogeneous mass adjacent to the ovary, with Doppler flow within the mass :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with an ectopic pregnancy. The patient’s urine hCG test is negative, which rules out ectopic pregnancy. Additionally, with her history of PID and infertility, hydrosalpinx is more likely. 
❌ 7 cm cystic mass within the ovary, with multiple loculations and mural nodules :
Incorrect: These findings concern ovarian malignancy, which is more common in postmenopausal patients. In a young woman with a history of PID and infertility, hydrosalpinx is more likely.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old nulligravid woman presents to the clinic with a 4-month history of amenorrhea. Her cycles had always been regular, coming once every 28 to 30 days; however, 8 months ago, her cycles became longer and irregular, coming every 30 to 45 days. She mentions that penetrative sex has become painful recently. Family history is notable for breast cancer in her grandmother at age 58 and the patient has a brother and uncle both with intellectual disability. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 114/74 mm Hg, and body mass index is 22 kg/m2. Neurologic, skin, neck, thoracic, and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. On pelvic exam, there is a loss of vaginal rugae, otherwise, the cervix appears normal, the uterus and adnexa have normal contours and are non-tender to palpation. Lab results are shown in the table below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s amenorrhea?
 
 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistry    
 Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)     45 IU/L    
 Estradiol (E2)     low    
 Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)     2.9 mU/L    
 Prolactin (PRL)     13 ng/mL    
 Urine     
 Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG)     negative
questions.solution:
The patient in the vignette presents with secondary amenorrhea secondary to primary ovarian insufficiency (POI), consistent with her relevant symptoms - irregular cycles, vaginal atrophy, and dyspareunia - in the setting of high follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and low estradiol (E2).

For patients with POI, the hypothalamus and pituitary gland are functioning normally, but the ovaries are not. The pituitary can secrete FSH, but the ovaries cannot respond to or secrete E2 (E2 is low). Therefore, there is no negative feedback on the pituitary, causing FSH levels to rise. Ultimately, this results in a high FSH (> 20 IU/L) with low E2.

Low estrogen levels can cause vasomotor symptoms, such as hot flashes, and vaginal dryness that can contribute to dyspareunia (ie, painful sex). Over time, a hypoestrogenic state can lead to loss of bone mineral density (BMD) and increased risk of cardiovascular disease. Additional findings on history and exam can also suggest a cause of POI. For example, a history of chemo- or radiation therapy, stigmata of Turner syndrome, and a family history of Fragile X syndrome (an X-linked disorder that can cause intellectual disability is strongly associated with POI). These patients require hormone replacement therapy, BMD monitoring, and psychological support.       

Option Analysis

✅ Ovarian insufficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hypothalamic suppression:
Incorrect: Hypothalamic suppression is characterized by low or normal FSH and low E2. Typically, history will suggest relative energy deficiency, such as disordered eating, intense athletic training, and a low BMI. This patient’s FSH is abnormally elevated. 
❌ Pituitary necrosis:
Incorrect: Pituitary ischemia and necrosis can occur, following a massive postpartum hemorrhage, leading to a panhypopituitarism known as Sheehan syndrome. Patients with Sheehan syndrome will have low or normal levels of the pituitary hormones (FSH, TSH, prolactin) and a low E2 level. This patient’s FSH is abnormally elevated, and her history is inconsistent with Sheehan syndrome. 
❌ Adhesive disease:
Incorrect: Intrauterine adhesive disease, known as Asherman syndrome, can develop after intrauterine surgery and/or infection (e.g., a dilation and curettage for a septic pregnancy loss). These patients present with normal lab results because the problem is anatomic: either the endometrium is unable to respond to estrogen due to extensive scar tissue, or adhesions are obstructing the menstrual outflow tract. 
❌ Neoplasm:
Incorrect: Benign and malignant hormone-secreting tumors can cause secondary amenorrhea. Estrogen-secreting ovarian tumors will present with very high estrogen levels, while androgen-secreting tumors present with signs of hyperandrogenemia on physical exam, including acne, hirsutism, and possibly virilization. This patient has low levels of estrogen and no signs of hyperandrogenism.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute heavy vaginal bleeding. She has had occasional light post-coital spotting over the past 6 months. Today, after intercourse, she developed heavy bleeding and has soaked through 4 pads in the past 2 hours. Her last menstrual period was 6 years ago, and her last cervical cancer screening was negative 10 years ago. Past medical history is notable for two prior abnormal pap smears in her 30s that resolved spontaneously without treatment. She takes no medication. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 92/56 mmHg. A pelvic exam shows a large friable cervical mass extending to the vaginal wall that is actively bleeding. An IV is placed, fluids are given, and the gynecologic surgeon is emergently consulted. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Pack the vagina with hemostatic gauze
Transfer to the operating room for emergency hysterectomy
Continue IV fluids and await recommendations from the gynecologic surgeon

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute postmenopausal bleeding from cervical cancer and is hemodynamically unstable. The management priority is to stabilize the patient by addressing the airway, breathing, and circulation, and stopping the hemorrhage. If the bleeding originates from the cervix or vagina, applying direct pressure by packing the vagina with hemostatic-laden gauze will reduce acute blood loss.

Acute hemorrhage is an uncommon presentation of postmenopausal bleeding. If it occurs, consider trauma and malignancy. It may also be seen in patients with an underlying coagulopathy or in patients who are on anticoagulation therapy. 

Direct pressure can also be used to stop hemorrhaging vulvar lesions. Uncontrolled uterine bleeding can be treated with uterine curettage or by placing a uterine tamponade balloon. IV estrogen can also be used for uterine bleeding if the patient is stable enough to tolerate several additional hours of bleeding. Acute management of malignancy-associated acute postmenopausal bleeding should focus on stabilization, rather than addressing the underlying cancer.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pack the vagina with hemostatic gauze:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Start IV estrogen:
Incorrect: IV estrogen is used to treat stable patients with acute uterine bleeding. It takes several hours to work, so it isn’t suitable for unstable patients. It isn’t effective at treating non-uterine bleeding, which is the case in this patient.  
❌ Transfer to the operating room for emergency hysterectomy:
Incorrect: The primary treatment for advanced-stage cervical cancer is radiation, not surgery. While a gynecologic surgeon may ultimately need to perform surgery to stop the bleeding, the best first step in the ED is to control the hemorrhaging by packing the vagina. 
❌ Continue IV fluids and await recommendations from the gynecologic surgeon:
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically unstable and delay in staunching the hemorrhage is inappropriate. The best step is to pack the vagina with hemostatic gauze. It is appropriate to wait for specialist recommendations after the hemorrhage is controlled, and the patient is stabilized. 
❌ Perform loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) :
Incorrect: A LEEP procedure is used to excise abnormal tissue from the cervix. While a specialist may use electrocautery to help control the hemorrhage, a LEEP is not an appropriate treatment for patients like this one with advanced-stage cervix cancer. The hemorrhage should be emergently controlled by packing the vagina.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents with two episodes of vaginal spotting over the past two weeks.  Past medical history is notable for estrogen-receptor-positive breast cancer two years ago, treated surgically and with adjuvant tamoxifen, which she still takes daily. The patient’s last cervical cancer screening was 3 years ago, and she has never had an abnormal screening test. Vital signs are within normal limits, and body mass index is 27 kg/m2. Pelvic exam shows loss of vaginal rugae, and a small, mobile uterus; the adnexa are not palpable. Pelvic ultrasound shows endometrial thickness of 7 mm and homogeneous myometrial echotecture; the adnexa are not visualized. A saline infusion sonohysterogram (SIS) shows a freely mobile filling defect. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with postmenopausal bleeding that is likely due to an endometrial polyp, identified on the saline infusion sonohysterogram (SIS). Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that has antagonist activity in the breast, but agonist activity in the uterus. The most common uterine pathology seen in tamoxifen users is endometrial polyps. While they are most often benign, they can be malignant and should be removed. This is best accomplished through an operative hysteroscopy and excisional biopsy.

In the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, malignancy must always be ruled out. Most often, this is done with a pelvic ultrasound; an endometrial thickness of ≤ 4 mm effectively rules out endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer. If the endometrial thickness is ≥ 5 mm, the patient requires tissue sampling. A blind endometrial biopsy (e.g. with a pipelle in the office) is decent at identifying diffuse pathology, such as endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN); however, it may miss focal lesions, such as polyps.

Given this patient’s risk factors for a focal lesion, an SIS was performed in the office rather than a blind biopsy.  If the SIS had not shown evidence of a polyp and endometrial cancer needed to be ruled out, either an in-office endometrial biopsy or a hysteroscopy with directed biopsies would have been an appropriate next step.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Hysteroscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Office endometrial pipelle biopsy:
Incorrect: The patient’s SIS shows a focal lesion, so a blind biopsy is not the best choice, as it may miss the lesion. Hysteroscopy allows for both definitive diagnosis and treatment with a directed excisional biopsy. 
❌ Culture of endocervical secretions:
Incorrect: Cervical cultures are used to identify infectious agents causing genital tract infection. Acute cervicitis presents with postcoital bleeding and mucopurulent cervical discharge, which are not seen in this patient.   
❌ Hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (BSO) :
Incorrect: This patient is most likely presenting with an endometrial polyp secondary to her tamoxifen use. If there is concern for a hereditary cancer syndrome such as BRCA that warrants a BSO, this would need to be confirmed with genetic testing before proceeding with major surgery.  
❌ Repeat pap smear and colposcopy:
Incorrect: Colposcopy is used to evaluate cervical, or potentially vulvar or vaginal, lesions. The SIS is highly suggestive of an endometrial polyp; colposcopy is not helpful in the evaluation of endometrial lesions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, aborta 1, presents to the clinic with heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain. Her menstrual cycles are regular, coming once every 28 to 30 days and lasting for 7 days. She changes a pad every one to two hours for the first 3 to 4 days of her cycle. She also passes golf ball-sized clots on occasion. The pelvic pain is intermittent but worse around menses, and she has occasional deep dyspareunia. Review of systems is positive for occasional constipation and increased urinary frequency. Past medical history is notable for two uncomplicated vaginal deliveries and one early miscarriage managed with a dilation and curettage. Vital signs are within normal limits and body mass index is 23 kg/m2. Pelvic exam shows an asymmetrically enlarged uterus with an irregular contour. Urine pregnancy test and urinalysis are both negative. Pelvic ultrasound shows a myometrial mass distorting the endometrial cavity. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Encapsulated monoclonal proliferation of smooth muscle
Localized proliferation of endometrial tissue around a vascular core
Endometrial glandular growth within the myometrium
Invasive proliferation of smooth muscle into surrounding myometrium

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) that is most likely secondary to uterine leiomyomas, which are also known as uterine fibroids. Fibroids are common benign encapsulated monoclonal smooth muscle tumors with pathologic findings of encapsulated monoclonal proliferation of smooth muscle that can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and bulk symptoms (such as constipation or urinary frequency), depending on their size and location. On ultrasound, fibroids appear as uniform, well-encapsulated hypoechic round masses within the myometrium.        

An evaluation of AUB is warranted when a patient’s menstrual patterns fall outside the normal parameters described by the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO). The normal menstrual cycle should occur once every 24 to 38 days and last ≤ 8 days. Additionally, patients may experience random or cyclic intermenstrual bleeding. In either case, a pelvic ultrasound is warranted. Causes of AUB can be divided into structural and non-structural causes, which FIGO categorizes according to the acronym PALM-COEIN. The structural causes of AUB include endometrial polyps, adenomyosis, leiomyomas, and malignancy (or hyperplasia). The non-structural causes include coagulopathy, ovulatory dysfunction, endometrial dysfunction, iatrogenic, and not otherwise classified.        

Beyond a pelvic ultrasound to look for structural causes, further work-up of abnormal uterine bleeding is guided by the patient’s presentation and detailed in the table above.       

Option Analysis

✅ Encapsulated monoclonal proliferation of smooth muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Localized proliferation of endometrial tissue around a vascular core:
Incorrect: This describes an endometrial polyp, which would be suggested as a possible diagnosis when the pelvic ultrasound shows a thickened endometrial stripe, unlike the patient in the vignette. Postcoital spotting or intermenstrual bleeding would also be expected. 
❌ Endometrial glandular growth within the myometrium:
Incorrect: This describes adenomyosis, which would be suggested by a globally enlarged uterus with a smooth contour on pelvic exam. Ultrasound findings include a heterogeneous myometrium, asymmetrical thickening of myometrial walls, and myometrial cysts. 
❌ Invasive proliferation of smooth muscle into surrounding myometrium:
Incorrect: This describes a leiomyosarcoma. Uterine leiomyomas, also called fibroids, and leiomyosarcomas can have a similar presentation; however, leiomyosarcomas are extremely rare compared to benign uterine fibroids, making fibroids the more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Chronic endometrial inflammation:
Incorrect: This describes chronic endometritis, which can lead to endometrial dysfunction. These patients tend to have regular cycles with HMB or intermenstrual bleeding, and the ultrasound appears normal, unlike the sonographic findings in the vignette which are consistent with leiomyoma.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to her OB-GYN for evaluation of two months of vulvar burning and irritation and dyspareunia. She also notes ulcers in her mouth that cause discomfort while eating. She has not used any new soaps, detergents, or body products. She has regular menstrual cycles and is in a monogamous relationship with her partner, who underwent vasectomy for contraception. Medical history is notable for autoimmune hypothyroidism managed with levothyroxine and low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL) on routine cervical cancer screening at age 24 that resolved spontaneously. Cervical cancer screening has been normal since that time, including her most recent test 2 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. She appears well and is in no acute distress. On exam, multiple erythematous erosions are noted on the labia minora, vaginal vestibule, and oral mucosa. White, lacy striae are seen surrounding the erosions on the vulva, buccal mucosa, and palate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lichen planus refers to a chronic, T cell-mediated, inflammatory autoimmune condition affecting basal keratinocytes that can affect both mucosal and cutaneous surfaces, including the vulva. This condition should be suspected in patients who present with a combination of genital pain/burning and genital/vulvar and oral mucosal erosions. Both the vulvar and oral lesions can be surrounded by Wickham striae (i.e. white, lacy, reticular lines) as seen in this patient. Lichen planus is most commonly diagnosed in peri- and post-menopausal patients, many of whom also have other autoimmune disorders.        

Many vulvar skin disorders can be diagnosed based on history and exam findings alone. Vulvar disorders and the associated clinical findings are listed in the table below. If patients with vulvar lesions do not respond to empiric treatment, have atypical lesions, are immunocompromised, or have an uncertain diagnosis, then a biopsy is indicated to confirm the diagnosis. A biopsy is typically performed to confirm the diagnosis of lichen planus since it is a relatively uncommon condition.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lichen planus:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lichen simplex chronicus:
Incorrect: Lichen simplex chronicus results in intense pruritus that leads to a characteristic “itch-scratch” cycle that is typically worse at night. It often begins with contact dermatitis or vulvovaginal candidiasis. The skin usually appears erythematous, thick, and leathery with lichenified plaques. The combination of vulvar and oral erythematous erosions with white striae, as seen in this patient, makes lichen planus a more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Lichen sclerosus:
Incorrect: Patients with lichen sclerosus present with thin, fragile, hypopigmented vulvar epithelium that can lead to vulvar irritation and fissures, none of which are seen in this vignette. The combination of vulvar and oral erythematous erosions with white striae, as seen in this patient, makes lichen planus a more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Condyloma acuminata:
Incorrect: Condyloma acuminata refers to genital warts caused by low-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) subtypes. They appear as flesh-colored warty lesions that may be flat or pedunculated. The combination of vulvar and oral erythematous erosions with white striae, as seen in this patient, makes lichen planus a more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Herpes simplex virus:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause both genital and oral ulcers. However, the white, lacy striae on the vulva and oral mucosa, known as Wickham striae, are not seen in patients with herpes infection but, rather, are characteristic of lichen planus.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents to the gynecologist with a six-month history of progressively worsening vulvar pruritus. The pruritus is constant but worse at night. It recently has been disturbing her sleep. Her last menstrual period was three years ago. She has no abnormal bleeding or dyspareunia. She has been screened for cervical cancer according to standard guidelines, and all tests have been negative. Her most recent screening test was three years ago. Past medical history is notable for asthma controlled with a low-dose inhaled corticosteroid-formoterol as needed. Vital signs are within normal limits, and she appears well. On exam, the labia majora appear erythematous with thickened, leathery skin, and excoriations. The skin is not affixed to the underlying tissue, and no masses, ulcers, or pigmented lesions are noted. White vaginal discharge is present. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Potassium hydroxide (KOH) smear of vaginal discharge
No further evaluation is needed before beginning empiric treatment

questions.solution:
Lichen simplex chronicus refers to an inflammatory vulvar skin disorder characterized by intense pruritus that is often worse at night and associated with erythematous, thick, leathery skin as seen in this patient. Scaling, excoriations, and erosions can also be seen. The condition is often seen in middle-aged to older adults and is more common in people with a history of atopy (i.e. asthma). Lichen simplex chronicus often begins after an episode of intense pruritis and scratching that can be caused by acute contact dermatitis and/or a persistent underlying vulvovaginal candidiasis infection. For this reason, it is important to initially perform microscopy on a potassium hydroxide (KOH) smear, especially in the setting of vaginal discharge. If a candidal infection is the underlying cause, then it should be treated with antifungal agents along with corticosteroids to stop the “itch scratch” cycle.        

A vulvar biopsy may be helpful in some situations, though it is a more painful, invasive test that can usually be reserved for patients presenting with vulvar symptoms who have atypical lesions (e.g. ulcers, induration, new pigmentation, bleeding, affixed to underlying tissue), immune compromising conditions, concern for malignancy, or if the diagnosis remains uncertain. An overview of vulvar disorders and the associated clinical findings are listed in the table below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Potassium hydroxide (KOH) smear of vaginal discharge:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Vulvar colposcopy and biopsy:
Incorrect: Biopsies are invasive tests that can usually be reserved for patients when there is the presence of atypical lesions (e.g. ulcers, induration, new pigmentation, bleeding, affixed to underlying tissue), immune compromising conditions, concern for malignancy, or if the diagnosis is uncertain.  
❌ Pregnancy test:
Incorrect: A pregnancy test is not routinely indicated for vulvar symptoms without abnormal bleeding. This patient has been post-menopausal for three years, so a pregnancy test is unnecessary.  
❌ Human papillomavirus (HPV) testing:
Incorrect: The patient’s vulvar history and exam findings are consistent with lichen simplex chronicus rather than lesions that can be caused by HPV (condyloma acuminata, low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL) or vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)). 
❌ No further evaluation is needed before beginning empiric treatment:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms and exam findings are consistent with lichen simplex chronicus, which often begins with acute contact dermatitis or underlying vulvovaginal candidiasis. It is important to rule out underlying candidiasis when the diagnosis is suspected.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician due to significant pain during her menstrual cycles. The patient tells the physician that this started eight months ago and has been interfering with her activities of daily living. After an appropriate workup, the diagnosis of endometriosis is made. The physician decides to start the patient on a medication that has pro-androgenic effects and anti-estrogenic effects. Which of the following is the most likely medication used in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is diagnosed with endometriosis, a condition in which the endometrial gland grows outside the uterine cavity. Many options can be used in treating endometriosis, one of which is danazol.

Danazol is a synthetic androgen with androgen agonist and antagonist effects on estrogen. Danazol suppresses ovarian function through both direct and indirect effects. It directly inhibits ovarian function by inhibiting the ovary's steroidogenesis and indirectly decreases estrogen synthesis by decreasing the production of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the pituitary gland. It also has androgenic agonist effects, as it stimulates androgen receptors.

Danazol has been proven to be effective in treating endometriosis. By creating amenorrhea and hypoestrogenism, danazol causes atrophy and regression of the ectopic endometrial tissues. Its use in treating endometriosis has decreased pain and improved fertility.

However, it is not usually used as a first-line treatment option because of its androgenic side effects i.e. acne, voice changes (e.g., deepening of the voice, hoarseness), decreased breast size, and hirsutism. Additionally, it may lead to menstrual irregularities, flushing, and sweating. Sometimes, patients can have nausea, vomiting, and a rise in blood pressure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Danazol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Leuprolide:
Incorrect: Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist that can sometimes be used to treat endometriosis; it has no androgenic effects.  
❌ Combined oral contraceptive pills:
Incorrect: Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) are the first-line treatment of endometriosis and be efficacious in reducing pain. However, they have no androgenic effects.  
❌ Progestin-only pills:
Incorrect: Progestin-only pills can also be used in treating endometriosis, but they have no androgenic effects.  
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: NSAIDs are usually used to control pain in endometriosis patients; however, they do not directly influence the hormones in the body.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of pelvic, lower abdominal, and lower back pain during menstruation. The patient reports that she does not sleep well when the symptoms are present. Her first menstruation occurred six months ago, and the patient is otherwise healthy. She has not tried over-the-counter medication for her symptoms. She is not sexually active and has not noticed abnormal vaginal discharge, and she does not have vaginal bleeding at other times besides menses. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing adolescent with a benign abdominal examination. Which of the following factors, if present, would prompt evaluation for a pelvic pathology causing dysmenorrhea?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy adolescent who began having menstrual cycles 6 months ago presents with pelvic, abdominal, and lower back pain with menstruation. She has no signs and symptoms that would indicate a pelvic abnormality. Given that her history is consistent with primary dysmenorrhea, a clinical diagnosis can be made. However, if she were to report acyclic pelvic pain, or pelvic pain that is not associated with menstruation, then evaluation for pelvic abnormalities causing secondary dysmenorrhea should be pursued.    

Primary dysmenorrhea refers to painful menstruation in the absence of pelvic pathology. It is a clinical diagnosis that can be made in patients with recurrent, crampy, midline, pelvic pain. The pain typically starts right before or with the onset of menstruation and diminishes over 12 to 72 hours. It typically starts in adolescence, usually within the first 6 to 12 months of menarche. The pathophysiology is likely related to the increased release of inflammatory mediators like prostaglandins and leukotrienes during menses.    

Common symptoms include pelvic, lower back, and upper thigh pain or discomfort. Additional symptoms that are commonly associated with primary dysmenorrhea include headaches, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and poor sleep. Physical examination is typically unremarkable.
