The patient reports that both her mother and older sister had hysterectomies in their 40s for heavy bleeding and pelvic pain. Vital signs are stable, and body mass index (BMI) is 29 kg/m2. On exam, the uterus has an irregular contour, is mildly enlarged, and is tender to palpation. No adnexal masses are appreciated, and the cervix and vagina appear grossly normal. Which of the following should be performed next to confirm the most likely underlying pathology?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with postmenopausal bleeding and a prior history of heavy menstrual bleeding and with the physical exam findings of an enlarged uterus with an irregular contour. The most likely diagnosis is uterine leiomyomas or uterine fibroids. A pelvic ultrasound is the best next step in the evaluation. A pelvic ultrasound will be able to confirm the presence of uterine fibroids while simultaneously assessing the endometrial thickness, which can help exclude endometrial cancer.

The pathophysiology of fibroids is complex and likely to involve genetic, hormonal, and environmental factors. After menopause, smaller fibroids often shrink and disappear, and these patients are frequently asymptomatic. Sometimes, however, fibroids can degenerate, causing acute pain and bleeding as the fibroid breaks down. Uterine tenderness, peritoneal signs, and a low-grade fever may also be present. Symptoms are typically self-limited and resolve within several days to weeks.    

Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Endometrial biopsy:
Incorrect: The purpose of an endometrial biopsy is to rule out malignancy. A tender uterus with an irregular contour in a recently menopausal patient with a history of heavy menstrual bleeding most likely represents uterine fibroids, which are typically benign and best identified on ultrasound.  
❌ Sonohysterogram:
Incorrect: A sonohysterogram is best used to identify intracavitary lesions, such as endometrial polyps and submucosal leiomyomas. This patient’s enlarged uterus with an irregular contour suggests intramural or subserosal uterine fibroids, therefore, a regular pelvic ultrasound is more appropriate. 
❌ Colposcopy:
Incorrect: Colposcopy is recommended if the immediate risk of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 3+ is > 4%, which generally includes patients with a positive HPV screen or more advanced abnormalities on cytology. Patients with ASC-US and a negative HPV screen should undergo repeat co-testing in 3 years.  
❌ Pelvic MRI:
Incorrect: In general, an ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice for the female reproductive organs. A pelvic MRI may be used as a follow-up study for better characterization of specific findings or to assist with surgical planning, but they are often unnecessary.

questions.text:
A healthy 15-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with heavy menstrual bleeding. Her menses began this morning, and she has been soaking through a super tampon and pad (worn simultaneously) every 30 to 60 minutes for the past 8 hours. Her mother brought her to the ED after she passed a lemon-sized blood clot. The patient feels weak, exhausted, and has a headache, though she does not feel dizzy or nauseous. She has a history of easy bruising and heavy menstrual bleeding since menarche 2 years ago. She is not on regular medication and is not sexually active. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. On exam, she is alert, oriented, and easily conversant, though she appears pale and fatigued. On speculum exam, a large blood clot is removed from the vagina, and a slow, but steady flow of bright red blood is observed coming from the cervical os. A urine pregnancy test is negative, and serum labs are shown below. A bedside transabdominal/ pelvic ultrasound is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management to help control this patient’s bleeding? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistry    
 Hemoglobin     10.1 g/dL    
 Platelets     210,000/mm3    
 Prothrombin time (PT)     12 sec (normal 10 to 13)    
 International normalized ratio (INR)     1.0 (normal 0.8 to 1.1)    
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)     45 sec (normal 21 to 35)

choices.text: Combined IV estrogen and progestin therapy

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute uterine bleeding with stable vital signs. Her bleeding is likely secondary to a coagulation disorder based on her history of heavy menstrual bleeding since menses, easy bruising, and an elevated aPTT. Because she is relatively stable, an oral contraceptive pill (OCP) taper is an appropriate initial treatment, which typically controls bleeding within 48 hours. Alternatively, oral estrogen alone could be used, which typically controls bleeding within 10 hours. Estrogen stimulates clotting and endometrial growth, which stabilizes and compresses the bleeding endometrial vessels.       

When evaluating patients with acute uterine bleeding, the first step is to assess stability and address any acute hemorrhage, control the airway and breathing, and support the circulation, as needed. Because menstruation is a normal phenomenon, clinical judgment is required to determine if and how quickly uterine bleeding must be stopped.       
For patients with unstable vital signs and active, heavy uterine bleeding, a dilation and curettage (D&C) is often appropriate. A uterine tamponade balloon can be placed as a temporizing agent pre-operatively, or in the operative room following a D&C to help with hemostasis. Alternatively, high-dose IV estrogen or tranexamic acid can be used in unstable patients at low risk of thromboembolic disease. However, in stable patients, oral hormone therapy is typically adequate.    

Option Analysis

✅ Oral contraceptive pill taper:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Combined IV estrogen and progestin therapy:
Incorrect: IV estrogen alone can be used to treat unstable patients with acute uterine bleeding. Although this patient has very heavy bleeding, her vital signs are still within normal limits, so high-dose oral hormones are a more appropriate first step. 
❌ Uterine tamponade balloon:
Incorrect: Uterine tamponade balloons are used to control active hemorrhage in unstable patients. Placement of these balloons is extremely uncomfortable in nulliparous patients, and this patient is stable enough that she does not require immediate tamponade. 
❌ Dilation and curettage (D&C):
Incorrect: D&C is often the preferred treatment in unstable patients. It is also appropriate in patients who have not responded or have contraindications to hormone therapy. This patient has normal vital signs and is an appropriate candidate for oral hormones, which is the better first choice. 
❌ Uterine artery embolization (UAE):
Incorrect: UAE is an appropriate treatment for acute bleeding thought to be secondary to a uterine arteriovenous malformation. Pregnancy is generally not recommended after UAE, so this procedure is not appropriate for an adolescent.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a three-month history of progressively worsening vulvar pruritus that has not responded to over-the-counter antifungal treatment. She has no postmenopausal bleeding and is not sexually active due to vaginal discomfort since menopause. Past medical history is notable for a positive human papillomavirus (HPV) test on routine cervical cancer screening at age 30 that resolved spontaneously. She doesn’t take any daily medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, vulvar atrophy is prominent with thin, fragile, hypopigmented skin across the vulva. Colposcopy demonstrates leukoplakia and an atypical underlying vascular pattern. A biopsy of the fragile, hypopigmented skin shows hyperkeratosis and an inflammatory pattern. Which of the following is true regarding the most likely underlying condition?

choices.text: It is not typically associated with HPV.
It is typically associated with HPV types 6 and 11.
It is typically associated with HPV types 16 and 18.
It is associated with an increased risk of vulvar adenocarcinoma.

questions.solution:
This patient who presents with vulvar pruritus and atrophy; thin, fragile epithelium; and hypopigmentation has biopsy findings that confirm lichen sclerosis (LS). LS refers to a chronic vulvar dermatosis, that is not associated with HPV. It is characterized by severe inflammation and epithelial thinning. LS is associated with the development of differentiated-type vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), which is a precursor to vulvar squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).        

Many vulvar dermatoses can be diagnosed clinically, based on history and exam findings alone. Vulvar disorders and the associated clinical findings are listed in the table below. However, both differentiated-type VIN, which can be associated with LN and usual-type VIN (also known as HSIL, which is associated with oncogenic HPV), are precursors to vulvar SCC and must be ruled out via a vulvar biopsy +/- colposcopy in any patients with associated conditions. Biopsy is also recommended for atypical lesions, such as those with new pigmentation, induration, ulcers, irregular borders, bleeding, and/or are affixed to the underlying tissue.  



Option Analysis

✅  It is not typically associated with HPV.:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ It is typically associated with HPV types 6 and 11.:
Incorrect: HPV types 6 and 11 are associated with condyloma acuminata (i.e. genital warts), which would be suspected in the setting of skin-colored lesions on exam and papillomatosis and koilocytosis on biopsy. The findings in this patient are consistent with lichen sclerosis, which is not associated with HPV. 
❌ It is typically associated with HPV types 16 and 18.:
Incorrect: HPV types 16 and 18 are associated with pre-malignant high-grade intraepithelial lesions (HSIL), which is also known as usual-type vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN). The findings in this patient are consistent with lichen sclerosis, which is not associated with HPV.   
❌ It is malignant.:
Incorrect: The findings in this patient are consistent with lichen sclerosis, which is not malignant and is not associated with HPV. Lichen sclerosis can be associated with the development of differentiated VIN, which is considered a pre-malignant lesion and a precursor to malignant squamous cell carcinoma. 
❌ It is associated with an increased risk of vulvar adenocarcinoma.:
Incorrect: The findings in this vignette are consistent with lichen sclerosis, which is a dermatosis that is not associated with HPV. Lichen sclerosis is associated with differentiated-type vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), which is associated with an increase in the risk of squamous cell carcinoma (i.e. originating in the epithelium) and not adenocarcinoma (i.e. originating in a gland or organ).

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of dysuria and yellow penile discharge. He denies fever, back pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms. He states that he had unprotected sex with a new partner approximately three weeks ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable except for a mucopurulent discharge seen at the urethral meatus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) of first-catch urine

questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of dysuria with mucopurulent penile discharge after recent unprotected intercourse is suggestive of gonorrhea or chlamydia infection causing urethritis. Empiric treatment may be started based on history and physical examination. Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) performed on first-catch urine should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis. NAAT testing may also be performed on a specimen from a urethral swab.  

In men presenting with dysuria, urinalysis, and urine culture are the first-line diagnostic methods for a suspected urinary tract infection like urethritis. However, in cases of suspected STIs, first-catch urine or urethral swab should also be sent for nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) to identify the pathogens (Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae) and confirm the diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Urinalysis and urine culture:
Incorrect: These tests are performed to diagnose urinary tract infections.  In this patient who is sexually active and has mucopurulent penile discharge, a sexually transmitted infection is the most likely cause. NAAT should be performed on a first-catch urine or urethral swab sample.  
❌ Cystoscopy:
Incorrect: This invasive procedure involves visualizing the inside of the urethra and bladder. It would be more appropriate for evaluating for structural abnormalities that may be the cause of recurrent urinary tract infections or to detect lesions/masses when bladder cancer is suspected.  
❌ Serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing:
Incorrect: PSA testing is used in certain patients for screening for prostate cancer. It can also be used to monitor prostate cancer. PSA levels can be elevated in prostatitis, but should not be used to screen for it.  
✅ Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) of first-catch urine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous pyelogram:
Correct: This is an imaging test used to visualize and evaluate the kidneys and ureters. It is typically reserved for complex cases, like evaluating for structural abnormalities in cases of recurrent urinary tract infections or to work up certain types of kidney stones.

questions.text: A 28-year-old biologically male patient presents to the urgent care clinic for sexually transmitted infection testing. His partner tested positive for Chlamydia trachomatis yesterday, and they have recently had unprotected vaginal intercourse. He does not have current symptoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Chaperoned examination of the genital region is within normal limits. The patient is offered empiric treatment but declines, electing to wait until the test results are back. Which of the following symptoms is the patient most likely to exhibit if he has contracted his partner’s infection?
questions.solution:
The majority of patients who develop chlamydia infections are asymptomatic and have no signs or symptoms of infection. This patient with a known sexual exposure to Chlamydia trachomatis should be tested and encouraged to take empiric treatment, since symptoms are not likely to develop despite active infection and loss to follow up may occur. All sexual partners of people who have tested positive for Chlamydia should be tested and treated after a known exposure, regardless of symptom status.  

Chlamydia trachomatis is acquired through sexual contact with an infected person, and it is the most common bacterial sexually transmitted infection. The infection can also be passed from mother to infant during childbirth. Sexually active young people are at the highest risk of contracting chlamydia, as are men who have sex with men.   

When present, genitourinary symptoms of chlamydia in a biologically male patient can include urethral discharge, dysuria, pyuria, prostate swelling and pain, or testicular swelling and pain, depending on whether the infection is in the urethra, prostate, or testicle. In biologically female patients, chlamydia may lead to urethritis or cervicitis, causing dysuria, pyuria, vaginal discharge, and post-coital or non-menstrual vaginal bleeding. Both men and women may experience lower abdominal pain, and women may develop pelvic inflammatory disease. Lymphogranuloma venereum is an uncommon but invasive genital ulcer disease caused by chlamydia infection that can lead to lymphadenopathy and proctocolitis. Chlamydia may also infect non-genitourinary sites and can lead to conjunctivitis, pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and proctitis.  Pneumonia can occur in infected neonates.

Option Analysis

✅ No symptoms:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Testicular pain:
Incorrect: Chlamydia trachomatis can cause infection of the epididymis or testicles and can lead to testicular pain and swelling; however, this is rare.  The majority of patients with chlamydia infections are asymptomatic. 
❌ Lower abdominal tenderness:
Incorrect: Chlamydia infections can lead to lower abdominal tenderness in both men and women; however, the majority of patients with chlamydia infections are asymptomatic. 
❌ Prostate tenderness:
Incorrect: When Chlamydia trachomatis infects the prostate it can lead to prostatitis, presenting as a firm, tender, and edematous prostate; however, the majority of patients with chlamydia infections are asymptomatic.
❌ Urethral discharge:
Incorrect: Urethritis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis may present with urethral discharge, dysuria, or pyuria; however, the majority of patients with chlamydia infections are asymptomatic.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a skin rash. It began a week ago on his trunk and has spread to his entire body now. He also reports low-grade fever, malaise, sore throat, and headache. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. He has had three female sexual partners over the past year. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus managed with lifestyle modifications. Temperature is 37.2°C (99 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a full-body maculopapular rash as shown below. Several gray, mucosal patches are seen in the mouth. Cervical, axillary and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy is present. HIV testing is negative. The patient is administered an intramuscular dose of penicillin G and sent home. He later presents to the emergency department three hours later with a worsening rash, muscle pain, rigors, and chills. His temperature is now 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current symptoms?


Reproduced from Flickr
questions.solution:
This patient’s initial presentation with a diffuse maculopapular rash, oral lesions, and lymphadenopathy  (especially epitrochlear), in combination with a history of multiple sexual partners, is consistent with secondary syphilis. A single dose of intramuscular penicillin G-benzathine is the treatment of choice. The development of rigors, myalgias, further rise in the body temperature, increased respiratory rate, and hypotension within four hours of penicillin administration is most likely secondary to Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR).  

JHR is a short-lived immunologic response to antimicrobial treatment characterized by fever, onset of constitutional symptoms, and worsening of rash (if initially present). It typically begins two to eight hours after the initial dose of antibiotic is given and resolves spontaneously within 24 hours.    

The exact cause is unknown, but it is thought to result from accelerated phagocytosis by polymorphonuclear leukocytes followed by the release of bacterial toxins and/or lipoproteins and cytokines from killed organisms. Although the symptoms often resolve without intervention within 12 to 24 hours, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or other antipyretics can be used to decrease the severity. It can occur following the treatment of syphilis, Lyme disease, brucellosis, and enteric fever.  

Option Analysis

❌ Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome:
Incorrect: Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome is seen in some cases of AIDS or immunosuppression when the immune system starts to recover after the initiation of effective treatment of HIV or the removal of other causes of immunosuppression. A sudden increase in the inflammatory response produces nonspecific symptoms such as fever and in some cases a worsening of damage to the infected tissue. This patient was diagnosed with secondary syphilis and was subsequently started on an antibiotic therapy that triggered his current state. 
✅ Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute urticaria:
Incorrect: Acute urticaria refers to the development of dermal edema after the initiation of a new drug or exposure to an allergen. Presence of constitutional symptoms (rigors, myalgias, further rise in the body temperature, increased respiratory rate, and hypotension) is atypical.
❌ Procaine reaction:
Incorrect: Procaine reaction is a pseudo-anaphylactic reaction caused by unintentional intracapillary penetration of procaine penicillin during administration by intramuscular injection. Microembolization of the drug crystals can cause confusion and psychotic symptoms, which are not present in the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR). The acute onset of the reaction and its brief duration (30 min) also differentiate it from JHR.
❌ Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome:
Incorrect: Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome is an idiosyncratic reaction consisting of fever, rash, eosinophilia, and internal organ involvement and tends to occur between 2-6 weeks after starting a new medication (as opposed to this patient’s presentation within 4 hours of penicillin administration). The most commonly implicated drugs include anticonvulsants, sulfonamides, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine visit. She is feeling well and has no specific concerns. She is sexually active with both men and women and has been with the same female partner for the past two months. She uses oral contraceptives for birth control and regularly uses condoms. She is up-to-date on vaccinations. A routine pelvic examination is performed. Which of the following findings on the pelvic examination should prompt further evaluation for sexually transmitted infections?

choices.text: A small amount of clear cervical mucus
A moderate amount of thick, white opaque cervical discharge
Mild redness of the cervix without discharge
A palpable, smooth, and mobile ovary
A small amount of thin white vaginal discharge with a mild odor

questions.solution:
A moderate amount of thick, white opaque cervical discharge is indicative of purulent cervical discharge which can be associated with cervicitis. Further investigation for sexually transmitted infections (STI) such as chlamydia or gonorrhea should be pursued in this patient. Chlamydia trachomatis is a common bacterial STI that often presents with minimal or no symptoms but can cause mucopurulent cervicitis--characterized by purulent cervical discharge. Untreated chlamydia can lead to complications like pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), infertility, and chronic pelvic pain. Therefore, further testing, including nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) for chlamydia and gonorrhea, should be performed on all patients with purulent cervical discharge. 

When patients present with signs and symptoms indicative of a sexually transmitted infection, a thorough history should be performed. It allows the clinician to gather essential information about the patient's sexual behaviors, past medical history, and risk factors that may not be immediately apparent, such as having multiple sexual partners, inconsistent condom use, or history of previous STI infections or exposures. The physical examination helps identify findings that might indicate an underlying infection, such as cervical discharge, genital ulcers, or lymphadenopathy. 

In asymptomatic patients without symptoms or findings consistent with STIs, screening is recommended for high-risk patients to prevent complications from untreated STIs. History should include a detailed sexual, social, and past medical history to assess for risk factors that place patients at increased risk for ЅΤІs, such as history of prior ЅΤI and history of multiple sex partners. In certain patients SТІ ѕϲreening should be performed because the patient belongs to a risk group associated with a high prevalence of ЅΤIs or high morbidity from contracted ЅТІs. This includes patients 15-24 years old, men who have sex with men, and patients with HIV positive status.   

Option Analysis

❌ A small amount of clear cervical mucus:
Incorrect: This is a normal physiologic finding associated with the ovulatory phase of the menstrual cycle. No further workups are necessary.
✅ A moderate amount of thick, white opaque cervical discharge:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Mild redness of the cervix without discharge:
Incorrect: Mild erythematous changes of the cervix can be a normal finding and do not necessarily indicate pathology. It can be related to hormonal changes or benign cervical ectropion, where glandular cells of the cervix extend outward onto the vaginal portion of the cervix. No further workups are necessary.  
❌ A palpable, smooth, and mobile ovary:
Incorrect: Palpating a smooth, mobile ovary on bimanual examination is a normal finding. Ovaries should be assessed for size, tenderness, and mobility. In the absence of masses or significant tenderness, a smooth and mobile ovary is typically considered normal, and no further workup is necessary. 
❌ A small amount of thin white vaginal discharge with a mild odor:
Incorrect: A thin white vaginal discharge can be normal, particularly in the absence of a strong odor, itching, or irritation. This type of discharge is often seen with normal vaginal flora or in response to hormonal changes. It may be related to normal leukorrhea, which occurs throughout the menstrual cycle. No further workups are necessary.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a six-month history of fatigue. He has also had a 7.7-kg (17-lb) weight loss during this period despite having a normal appetite. The patient is sexually active with three female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. The remainder of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. An HIV screening test and confirmatory test are both positive. CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 550/mm<sup>3</sup> and viral load is 110 copies/mL. Treatment with lamivudine, didanosine, and indinavir is initiated. Which of the following adverse effects is this patient at greatest risk of developing due to this medication regimen?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has a positive HIV test and is started on highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Didanosine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) and predisposes patients to acute pancreatitis. Of note, individuals taking didanosine may not develop pancreatitis until after many months of use, presumably due to the chronic accumulation of toxic metabolic products. Pancreatitis occurs more frequently in patients with alcohol use disorder or hypertriglyceridemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperpigmentation of palms and soles:
Incorrect: Hyperpigmentation is an adverse effect of emtricitabine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), but not lamivudine, didanosine, or indinavir.  
✅ Acute pancreatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vivid dreams:
Incorrect: Vivid dreams are an adverse effect of efavirenz, a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). NNRTIs can cause additional central nervous system symptoms (e.g., confusion, insomnia) and Stevens-Johnson syndrome. This patient, however, is not taking an NNRTI.  
❌ Megaloblastic anemia:
Incorrect: Megaloblastic anemia is an adverse effect of zidovudine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), but not lamivudine, didanosine, or indinavir.  
❌ Obstructive crystalline nephropathy:
Incorrect: Obstructive crystalline nephropathy is an important adverse effect of acyclovir therapy, which can be avoided by adequate hydration.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man comes to the office for HIV testing. HIV differentiation assay and follow-up Western blot are performed and return positive. Additional laboratory results are shown below. The patient is started on tenofovir, abacavir, and efavirenz. Which of the following screening tests should be performed on this patient before starting this medication regimen?  

Laboratory Value
Result
Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL  
CD4 T-cell count  
45/mm3   
Platelet count  
200,000 mm3   
Serum

Creatinine
0.6 g/dL  
BUN
10 mg/dL  
Bilirubin 

Total
0.8 mg/dL  
Direct
0.2 mg/dL  
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)  
15 U/L  
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)  
17 U/L  
Random blood glucose  
127 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Abacavir is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV infection. Before initiating treatment with abacavir, all patients should be screened for HLA-B*5701. Abacavir is contraindicated in individuals who test positive for HLA-B*5701, as they are at high risk for developing an abacavir hypersensitivity reaction (AHR) on results from the direct binding of abacavir to the HLA-B*5701 molecule, which eventually alters the self-presentation of peptides to the immune system and leads to the development of delayed hypersensitivity reactions.

AHR typically presents with symptoms including fever, rash, gastrointestinal disturbances, dyspnea, and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise). Abacavir should be discontinued in patients who develop signs and symptoms of AHR that another etiology cannot explain.  

Option Analysis

✅ HLA-B*5701:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ DEXA scan:
Incorrect: Tenofovir can contribute to decreased bone mineral density, which usually stabilizes with continued use. However, a screening DEXA scan is not indicated before starting tenofovir.  
❌ Hepatitis C screening:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA screening is indicated in individuals successfully treated for HCV or spontaneously cleared the prior infection. HCV screening is not required before starting tenofovir, abacavir, or efavirenz therapy.  
❌ Tropism testing:
Incorrect: The tropism test helps decide whether a CCR5 blocker will be useful in controlling a patient's HIV. A tropism test is required before prescribing maraviroc, but not before prescribing tenofovir, abacavir, or efavirenz.  
❌ HbA1c:
Incorrect: If a patient on antiretroviral therapy (ART) has an abnormal random glucose level, then a fasting glucose level should be obtained. HbA1C is no longer recommended for the diagnosis of diabetes in patients with HIV on ART.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the office due to fever, right lower extremity swelling, as well as testicular pain and swelling for the past 5 months. The patient immigrated from India 5 years ago. The patient has no history of prior injuries or trauma. There is no history of similar swelling elsewhere in the body. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F) , pulse is 65/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Fine needle aspiration of the swollen lower extremity reveals the presence of slender, colorless, thread-like larvae with blunt heads. The findings raise suspicion for Wuchereria bancrofti infection. Which of the following is the first-line medication for the management of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right lower extremity and testicular swelling. Fine needle aspiration reveals the presence of parasites. In combination, these findings are suggestive of lymphatic filariasis caused by Wuchereria bancrofti. This patient should receive treatment with diethylcarbamazine (DEC).  

DEC has a narrow spectrum of activity and is the treatment of choice for Wuchereria bancrofti and Loa loa filarial worms. It has also been used for visceral larva migrans. The medication works by changing the cell membrane of these worms through an unknown mechanism, which makes it easier for the host immune system to target and remove the parasites. Side effects include itching, facial swelling, headaches, and in rare cases vision loss.  



Option Analysis

❌ Praziquantel:
Incorrect: Praziquantel increases the permeability of parasitic cellular membranes to calcium ions; thereby, leading to muscle paralysis and death. It is first-line therapy against most trematodes (flukes) and cestodes (tapeworms). It is not effective against Wuchereria bancrofti.  
❌ Melarsoprol:
Incorrect: Melarsoprol is a medication used for the treatment of sleeping sickness (also termed African trypanosomiasis). It is specifically used for second-stage disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense when the central nervous system is involved. It is not effective against Wuchereria bancrofti.  
❌ Pyrantel pamoate:
Incorrect: Pyrantel pamoate is the first-line treatment for intestinal nematode infections. It can be used as an alternative to bendazoles against pinworms. It is not effective against Wuchereria bancrofti.  
❌ Permethrin:
Incorrect: Permethrin is the first-line treatment for scabies, which present as intense pruritus that is associated with papules and burrows. It is not effective against Wuchereria bancrofti.  
✅ Diethylcarbamazine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a penile ulcer. The lesion is painless and began as a papule three days ago and developed an ulceration yesterday. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medication. Family history is noncontributory. The patient is sexually active with multiple partners and does not use condoms. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 1.2 cm ulcer close to glans penis with raised indurated margins and a nonexudative base. There are several bilateral enlarged inguinal lymph nodes that are nontender, firm, and rubbery. There are no surrounding vesicles or lesions. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the first-line treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Inhibition of peptidoglycan formation by binding D-Ala-D-Ala
Inhibition of initiation complex through binding of the 30S subunit

questions.solution:
This patient most likely developed a genital ulcer after unprotected sexual intercourse, raising suspicion of sexually transmitted disease. A solitary, painless ulcer with raised, indurated margins and a clean base is indicative of primary syphilis; the ulcer is termed as a chancre. Chancres are caused by Treponema pallidum, a Gram-negative spirochete. A single dose of penicillin G benzathine is standard therapy for most patients with primary syphilis.    

Penicillin is a β-lactam antibiotic that consists of a thiazolidine ring connected to a β-lactam ring which is attached to a side chain. This structure of the β-lactam closely resembles the D-ala-D-ala residue.    

Penicillin is a bactericidal (kills bacteria) drug that act to inhibit cell wall synthesis by the following steps:  

  1.  Binds to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) located in the bacterial cytoplasmic membrane 
  2.  Inhibits the transpeptidation reaction that cross-links the linear peptidoglycan chain constituents of the cell wall 
  3.  Activates the autolytic enzymes that cause lesions in the bacterial cell wall 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase:
Incorrect: Sulfonamides inhibit dihydropteroate synthase, thus inhibiting folate synthesis. Although they are effective against various Gram-positive and Gram-negative organisms, as well as Chlamydia and Nocardia species, they are not used in the treatment of syphilitic chancre. 
❌ Inhibition of DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones inhibit prokaryotic enzymes topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV.  They are very effective against Gram-negative bacteria, such as Enterobacteriaceae, Haemophilus, Legionella, Neisseria, Moraxella, and even Pseudomonas species, but not spirochetes.
❌ Inhibition of peptidoglycan formation by binding D-Ala-D-Ala:
Incorrect: Vancomycin inhibits cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors. It is effective against Gram-positive organisms for serious, multidrug-resistant organisms, including MRSA, S epidermidis, sensitive Enterococcus species, and Clostridium difficile.
❌ Inhibition of initiation complex through binding of the 30S subunit:
Incorrect: Aminoglycosides (e.g. gentamicin, amikacin, tobramycin) are bactericidal antimicrobial agents that inhibit protein synthesis by blocking the formation of the initiation complex, misreading of mRNA, and inhibiting translocation. They are effective against severe Gram-negative rod infections and are not indicated in first-line treatment of primary syphilis. 
✅ Block transpeptidase cross-linking of peptidoglycan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the college campus health clinic with a two-week history of dysuria, penile discharge, and posterior scrotal pain. He has no other symptoms. He has had five different female sexual partners in the past three months and no male sexual partners. He inconsistently uses condoms. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 124/85 mmHg. Genitourinary examination reveals thick, greenish-yellow, purulent urethral discharge. He does not have costovertebral tenderness or abdominopelvic tenderness. There is no joint pain or swelling. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Rash on the hands and feet

questions.solution:
This 20-year-old man with a history of multiple recent sexual partners presents with a two-week history of dysuria, purulent urethral discharge, and posterior scrotal pain. He has a combination of lower urinary symptoms (urethritis) and symptoms consistent with epididymitis which is most commonly caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection or chlamydial infection. Unilateral testicular swelling and tenderness would likely be seen on physical examination in patients with epididymitis from sexually transmitted infections.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most common cause of urethritis. Biologically male patients with urethritis may present with dysuria and/or urethral discharge; however, many male patients with urethritis from N. gonorrhoeae are asymptomatic. Patients with acute epididymitis commonly present with acute scrotal pain, unilateral testicular swelling, and tenderness, and they may have painful ejaculations.

In biologically female patients, the most common site of infection with N. gonorrhoeae is the cervix. Most patients with cervicitis from N. gonorrhoeae are asymptomatic; however, symptoms may include mucopurulent vaginal discharge, vaginal pruritis, and vaginal spotting. Patients also may have urethritis which is also typically asymptomatic. Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can result from cervicitis secondary to N. gonorrhoeae infections which can lead to ectopic pregnancy, infertility, and chronic pelvic pain. Patients with PID typically present with pelvic/abdominal pain, abnormal vaginal bleeding, dyspareunia and cervical motion tenderness on exam.

Extragenital infection with N. gonorrhoeae can occur and can result in proctitis (most commonly in males who have sex with males), pharyngitis (in patients who have exposure from oral sex), and conjunctivitis. Disseminated infection can result in two syndromes: septic arthritis or the triad of tenosynovitis, dermatitis and polyarthralgias.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Unilateral testicular swelling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rash on the hands and feet:
Incorrect: Dermatitis may be seen with disseminated gonococcal infection.  This patient has none of the other findings associated with disseminated gonococcal infection, which include arthralgias, arthritis, and tenosynovitis, making rash an unlikely finding.  
❌ Purulent ocular discharge:
Incorrect: Purulent ocular discharge, erythema of the conjunctiva, and swelling of the eyelids are findings associated with conjunctivitis from N. gonorrhoeae infection. This is an unlikely finding in this patient who has no ocular complaints.  
❌ Painful bowel movements:
Incorrect: Painful bowel movements and other rectal symptoms can be seen in patients with proctitis from N. gonorrhoeae. This complication of N. gonorrhoeae infection is most commonly seen in males who have sex with males, which is not the case for this patient.  
❌ Right upper quadrant pain:
Incorrect: Right upper quadrant pain can be seen with perihepatitis or Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome (FHCS), which is a severe complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) from N. gonorrhoeae seen almost exclusively in biologically female patients. FHCS in males is extremely rare.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a routine examination. She reports regular menstrual cycles and has no significant medical history. She has no concerns now. Upon further questioning, she states that she has had three sexual partners in the last year and has not consistently used condoms. Her last sexual encounter was with a new partner three months ago. She has no known history of sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Her last Pap smear one year ago was normal. Physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following STI screenings is recommended now?

choices.text: Chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV, and herpes simplex virus (HSV)
No screening is necessary at this visit

questions.solution:
The patient is a sexually active woman under the age of 25, making her eligible for routine yearly screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines. These infections are common among young, sexually active individuals who are, in many cases, asymptomatic. This makes regular screening crucial to prevent complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease, infertility, and further transmission. Additionally, because this patient is sexually active with multiple partners and inconsistent condom use, she should be screened for HIV and syphilis as well. 

HIV screening is recommended for all individuals aged 13 to 64 at least once in their lifetime, with more frequent testing for those with risk factors. Given that this patient has multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use, annual HIV screening is appropriate. Syphilis screening is also recommended for individuals at higher risk of infection, including those with multiple sexual partners. While syphilis is less common than chlamydia and gonorrhea, it should still be screened for in high-risk populations.    

Option Analysis

❌ Chlamydia and syphilis:
Incorrect: Chlamydia and syphilis screening is necessary for this patient given her age and risk factors; however, this option is incomplete as it omits the additional necessary testing for gonorrhea and HIV that are recommended for this patient based on her sexual history.  
✅ Chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV, and syphilis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chlamydia and gonorrhea:
Incorrect: This choice covers routine screening for STIs in young patients who are sexually active but misses the additional screenings for HIV and syphilis that are recommended for this patient given her risk factors.  
❌ Chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV, and herpes simplex virus (HSV) :
Incorrect: For this patient, chlamydia, gonorrhea, and HIV screenings are recommended, but routine screening for HSV in asymptomatic individuals is not recommended. HSV testing is reserved for patients with symptoms suggestive of genital herpes, those with recent exposure or for patients specifically requesting testing. 
❌ No screening is necessary at this visit:
Incorrect: This option is incorrect because the patient falls within the recommended age group for routine yearly chlamydia and gonorrhea screening. And given her sexual history, she warrants screening for additional STIs, including HIV and syphilis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the office for HIV testing. He recently learned that a previous sexual partner has tested positive for HIV infection. The patient is feeling well and has no acute symptoms. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies and asthma. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. An HIV screening test and confirmatory test are both positive, and the physician informs the patient that he should be started on a multidrug antiretroviral therapy that includes lamivudine. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of lamivudine?

choices.text: Prevents complementary DNA synthesis from RNA template
Inhibits cleavage of viral polyprotein precursors
Inhibits viral genome integration into host cell
Prevents entry of viral core into host cytoplasm
Inhibits attachment of the virus to target cell surface

questions.solution:
Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV infection. This class of medication is an essential component of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).

NRTIs are prodrugs converted by host cell kinases to triphosphates. They inhibit nucleotide-binding from reversing transcriptase and terminating DNA chain elongation, given the NRTI molecules lack a 3′-OH group. NRTIs have no effect on completed proviral DNA already incorporated into CD4+ cells, and as a result, cells that are already infected remain infected. Therefore, NRTIs can only slow down the progression of the disease but not cure it. Examples of NRTIs include zidovudine, stavudine, lamivudine, didanosine, abacavir, and tenofovir.

Apart from being used in HAART, NRTIs can also be used in children born to mothers infected by HIV to reduce the risk of vertical transmission. Moreover, lamivudine can be used in the treatment of hepatitis B infection.

Side effects of NRTIs include gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain), bone marrow suppression, central nervous system toxicity (e.g., insomnia, headache, and peripheral neuropathy), and metabolic effects (e.g. lactic acidosis). In addition, abacavir can sometimes lead to fatal hypersensitivity reactions, whereas didanosine can cause pancreatitis.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Prevents complementary DNA synthesis from RNA template:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits cleavage of viral polyprotein precursors:
Incorrect: Protease is an HIV enzyme that cleaves the polypeptide products of HIV mRNA into their functional parts. This enzyme is inhibited by protease inhibitors (e.g., ritonavir, indinavir).  
❌ Inhibits viral genome integration into host cell:
Incorrect: Integrase is an enzyme produced by HIV that incorporates the viral genome into host chromosomes. Integrase inhibitors (e.g. raltegravir) reversibly inhibit HIV integrase.  
❌ Prevents entry of viral core into host cytoplasm:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide is an antiviral fusion inhibitor that blocks viral attachment, penetration, and uncoating. It binds to the gp41 subunit of the HIV envelope glycoprotein, thereby preventing conformational changes and subsequent fusing of the virus with T-cells.  
❌ Inhibits attachment of the virus to target cell surface:
Incorrect: gp120 facilitates HIV attachment to the host cell by binding CD4 receptor and chemokine coreceptor CCR-5.  Maraviroc binds CCR-5 on the surface of T-cells/monocytes, thereby inhibiting interaction with gp120.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with a two-week history of fever, fatigue, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss of 5 pounds. He also reports sore throat, myalgias, and a non-pruritic maculopapular rash on the trunk. He has not travelled recently, had tick bites, or had exposure to sick contacts. Past medical history is significant for genital herpes. The patient has had multiple sexual partners and inconsistent use of condoms for several years. He does not use recreational substances. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Examination of the skin reveals a diffuse maculopapular rash on the trunk and extremities. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present bilaterally. Oral examination shows erythema of the pharynx without exudates or tonsillar swelling. There are no genital lesions or penile discharge. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Hemoglobin     12 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     40 %    
 Leukocyte count     3,100/mm3    
 Platelet count     150,000/mm3    
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)     58 U/L    
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)     78 U/L    
 Heterophile antibody     Negative
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is highly suggestive of acute human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, which typically manifests 2-4 weeks after exposure to the virus. The symptoms of fever, fatigue, night sweats, unintentional weight loss, sore throat, myalgias, and a maculopapular rash are characteristic of acute retroviral syndrome (ARS).   This patient’s history of multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use are significant risk factors for HIV infection.

Patients with early HIV infection are often asymptomatic. When symptoms are present, they are often non-specific and may include fever; headache; fatigue; night sweats; unintentional weight loss; and gastrointestinal symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Sore throat, myalgias, and arthralgias are also common symptoms. A key aspect of taking the history is identifying risk factors, including high-risk sexual behaviors (such as unprotected sex or multiple sexual partners), intravenous substance use, and occupational exposures (like accidental needlestick injuries). On physical examination, patients may have a generalized maculopapular rash; lymphadenopathy; pharyngeal erythema and edema; and painful mucocutaneous ulcers, particularly in the oral and genital regions. Needlestick marks or signs of other sexually transmitted infections may be present depending on the method of virus acquisition.    

Option Analysis

❌ Infectious mononucleosis:
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis can present similarly to human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) with fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and fatigue; however, this patient’s negative heterophile antibody test and lack of tonsillar swelling and exudates make HIV more likely.  
❌ Disseminated gonococcal infection:
Incorrect: Disseminated gonococcal infection can occur as a complication of untreated gonococcal infection; however, the rash is typically pustular and associated with joint and tendon pain and swelling. This patient's rash pattern and lack of joint and genitourinary involvement make disseminated gonorrhea less likely.  
✅ Acute human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Acute viral hepatitis:
Incorrect: Acute viral hepatitis can cause elevated liver enzymes and systemic symptoms, but it typically presents with significantly elevated liver enzyme (>1000 U/L), jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, vomiting, and dark urine, which are not reported in this case. 
❌ Streptococcal pharyngitis:
Incorrect: Patients with Streptococcal pharyngitis can present with sore throat and cervical lymphadenopathy. Patients typically have swollen tonsils, often with exudates. Severe systemic symptoms and rash are not typically present in adults with strep pharyngitis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the obstetrics/gynecology clinic for a routine well-patient visit. She has not been experiencing fever, pelvic or abdominal pain, or abnormal vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period started one week ago, and she has not been sexually active since. She has regular cycles. The patient is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms regularly. She does not drink alcohol or use other recreational substances. She lives in an apartment with one roommate and works as an accountant. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft and non-tender. The cervix appears normal and there are no palpable masses or adnexal tenderness. In addition to a pap smear what other testing is recommended at this time?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for gonorrhea and chlamydia

questions.solution:
This patient who is 24 years old and sexually active with one male partner should have yearly screening with nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for gonorrhea and chlamydia. Additionally, she should be screened at least once for HIV infection, and once for Hepatitis B and C infections. 

Factors such as the patient’s biological sex, pregnancy status, sexual practices, and HIV status all play a role in tailoring the screening for STIs based on risk factors. Sexually active femalеs who are <25 years old, regardless of their personal risk for specific ЅΤIѕ, should have yearly screening for gonorrhea and chlamydia. Testing for syphilis and trichomonas is recommended only for high-risk individuals, such as females receiving care in high-prevalence settings like STI clinics and females who are at high risk for infection (ie, multiple sex partners, transactional sex, drug misuse, history of SΤІ).    

Option Analysis

❌ Serologic herpes testing:
Incorrect: Serologic testing can be used to support a diagnosis of herpes in patients with genital ulcers. However, screening asymptomatic patients for herpes is not routinely recommended. 
❌ Syphilis testing:
Incorrect: Screening for syphilis is recommended only for high-risk individuals, which includes     females receiving care in high-prevalence settings like STI clinics and females who are at high risk for infection (ie, multiple sex partners, transactional sex, drug misuse, history of SΤІ). This patient does not meet the criteria for screening for syphilis.   
✅ Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for gonorrhea and chlamydia:
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Cervical culture for gonorrhea:
Incorrect: A cervical culture may be part of the diagnostic workup of patients with signs or symptoms of gonorrhea; however, culture is not used as a screening test. Screening in patients between 15 to 24 years of age for STIs should include yearly nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for gonorrhea and chlamydia. 
❌ Wet mount for trichomoniasis:
Incorrect: Wet mount for trichomoniasis is an important test for evaluating vaginal discharge, However, screening for trichomoniasis is only recommended for high-risk individuals, such as    females receiving care in high-prevalence settings like STI clinics and females who are at high risk for infection (ie, multiple sex partners, transactional sex, drug misuse, history of SΤІ). This patient does not meet the criteria for screening for trichomonas.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic with a 3-day history of dysuria, low-grade fever, penile discharge, and right testicular pain. He does not have frequency, urgency, or blood in his urine. He has been sexually active with a new partner without the use of barrier protection. He has a history of cryptorchidism of the right testicle that was surgically corrected with orchiopexy at the age of 1. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, there is no abdominal tenderness. The right testicle appears swollen with associated tenderness to palpation of the posterior and superior aspects. The left testicular exam is normal. The patient feels relief from pain with elevation of the right scrotum. There is minimal white penile discharge. Digital rectal examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase and white blood cells.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This man who presents with dysuria, testicular pain, a positive Prehn sign, and a positive urinalysis likely has epididymitis with urethritis. Epididymitis refers to inflammation of the epididymis that is commonly caused by bacterial infections, and by sexually transmitted infections in sexually active men. C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae are the most frequent causes of epididymitis in sexually active males.    

Patients typically have unilateral testicular pain and tenderness as well as palpable swelling of the epididymis. Symptoms can include testicular pain, swelling, erythema, and dysuria and there may be associated urethritis. Frequently, urethritis is asymptomatic. A key clinical finding that may differentiate epididymitis from other causes of testicular pain, is the Prehn sign, which refers to relief of pain upon elevation of the involved scrotum.   

Option Analysis

✅ Epididymitis with urethritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Testicular torsion:
Incorrect: Testicular torsion is a urological emergency caused by the spermatic cord twisting with subsequent loss of blood flow to the testicle. It presents with sudden, severe testicular pain and swelling. Testicular torsion does not cause dysuria. A key clinical distinction between testicular torsion and epididymitis is that lifting the testicle does not relieve pain (Prehn sign) in testicular torsion.  
❌ Cystitis:
Incorrect: Cystitis refers to inflammation of the bladder, often caused by a urinary tract infection. Symptoms include urinary urgency, frequency, and burning with urination. Hematuria and suprapubic pain can also occur. While the patient presents with dysuria, he also has symptoms and physical exam findings consistent with epididymitis.  
❌ Testicular cancer:
Incorrect: Testicular cancer presents as a unilateral mass or painless swelling found incidentally. Acute pain can be seen but is not common. A solid mass is typically present on examination.  
❌ Acute bacterial prostatitis:
Incorrect: This condition is characterized by inflammation of the prostate gland. While it can present with dysuria and fever, symptoms typically include pelvic or perineal pain, urinary frequency and urgency, chills, and malaise. On digital rectal examination, the prostate may feel tender and boggy. This patient’s physical examination suggests an alternate diagnosis.

questions.text: A 21-year-old biologically male college student presents to the urgent care clinic to be evaluated for one week of painful urination. He does not have fever, abdominal pain, sore throat or rectal symptoms. He is currently sexually active with several partners. He does not have chronic medical conditions and has no known drug allergies. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 122/70 mmHg. Chaperoned genital examination reveals clear discharge at the urethral meatus. Testicular examination is non-painful, and no masses are palpated. Nucleic acid amplification testing on a first-catch urine sample is sent out and comes back positive for Chlamydia trachomatis and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The patient had declined empiric treatment at the time of the initial visit. Upon informing the patient of the results, which of the following is the best treatment option at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient’s dysuria and urethral discharge in the setting of having multiple sexual partners is highly concerning for a sexually transmitted infection, and nucleic acid amplification testing has confirmed that the patient has Chlamydia trachomatis. Doxycycline is the first-line choice for treatment of chlamydia infection in non-pregnant adults. Empiric treatment should be offered to symptomatic patients while awaiting test results and to patients with known or confirmed sexual exposure.  

Management of suspected or confirmed Chlamydia trachomatis infection in adults consists of antibiotics, counseling on the recommended duration of abstinence, testing for other sexually transmitted infections, and planning for a test-of-cure visit. All sexual partners should be referred for evaluation and treatment as well. Doxycycline is the preferred antibiotic in non-pregnant adults, and azithromycin is the main alternative. If neither drug can be used, levofloxacin is another option. In pregnant patients, the preferred antibiotic is azithromycin, with amoxicillin as an alternative option. Patients should also receive testing for HIV, gonorrhea, and syphilis, and be counseled to abstain from intercourse for seven days after treatment, until symptoms have resolved, and all partners have been treated.   

Repeat chlamydia testing after treatment is necessary due to high rates of reinfection. For nonpregnant patients, the test-of-cure should be done 12 weeks after treatment. Given the potential for pregnancy complications, pregnant patients should have a test-of-cure four weeks after treatment, with a second test at 12 weeks post-treatment, and a third test in the third trimester.

Option Analysis

✅ Doxycycline :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Levofloxacin:
Incorrect: Levofloxacin is an alternative option for the treatment of chlamydia in patients who cannot take doxycycline.  This patient has no contraindication to doxycycline, which is the preferred regimen. 
❌ Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin is an alternative option for the treatment of chlamydia in pregnant patients who cannot take azithromycin, which is the preferred treatment. It is typically not used in nonpregnant patients for whom doxycycline is preferred.
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone is used to treat gonorrhea.  Although coinfection is common, this patient’s labs indicate that he does not have an infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae at this time. He should be treated with doxycycline, which is the preferred treatment for chlamydia in nonpregnant adults.
❌ Cefotaxime:
Incorrect: Cefotaxime is an alternative antibiotic in the treatment of gonorrhea.  Although coinfection is common, this patient’s labs indicate that he does not have an infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae at this time.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of lower extremity pain and unsteadiness. The pain is severe, stabbing, and rated as 8 out of 10 in severity. These pain episodes last for minutes at a time. Past medical history is significant for Streptococcal pharyngitis, and he developed a severe allergic reaction after being administered penicillin. The patient is sexually active with men and uses condoms inconsistently. Physical examination reveals miotic pupils in normal and low light that do not constrict further when exposed to a bright penlight. There is no direct or consensual pupillary dilation when the penlight is removed. The pupils constrict further when the patient is asked to focus on a nearby object. Neurological examination shows decreased vibration and proprioception sense in the lower extremities, absent lower extremity deep tendon reflexes, and a positive Romberg test. The patient is offered treatment with penicillin after desensitization. However, the patient inquires about alternate treatment options. Which of the following is the most appropriate alternative treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with tabes dorsalis and Argyll-Robertson pupils, which are seen in neurosyphilis. The first-line treatment is intravenous penicillin. Ceftriaxone can be used as an alternative treatment option in patients with penicillin allergies.

It was previously believed that patients with penicillin allergies are at increased risk for cross-sensitivity to cephalosporins. However, recent studies suggest the incidence of a cephalosporin allergy is less than 1% in patients reporting a penicillin allergy without skin testing and approximately 2% in patients with a confirmed positive penicillin skin test. As a result, cephalosporins can generally be safely administered in patients with a penicillin allergy.

Moreover, due to the structural differences from penicillin, cephalosporins are less susceptible to penicillinases produced by Staphylococcal species. Some bacteria, however, develop resistance to cephalosporins via the production of other beta-lactamases that can inactivate drug molecules. Other modes of resistance to cephalosporins include decreased membrane permeability and changes in penicillin-binding protein (PBP) structure.  

Option Analysis

❌ Vancomycin:
Incorrect: Vancomycin is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that is effective against Gram-positive bacteria,  including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. It is not effective in the treatment of neurosyphilis, which is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.  
✅ Ceftriaxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tetracycline:
Incorrect: Tetracycline is a bacterial protein synthesis inhibitor that is effective against bacteria including Borrelia burgdorferi, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and Chlamydia species. It is not effective against Treponema pallidum for the treatment of neurosyphilis.  
❌ Chloramphenicol:
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol has been historically used in the management of meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. It is rarely used in the United States nowadays due to its toxicity profile; in particular its ability to cause dose-dependent aplastic anemia. Moreover, chloramphenicol is not effective in the treatment of neurosyphilis, which is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.  
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: Azithromycin is an alternative treatment option for Streptococcal infections in patients with penicillin allergies. However, it is not effective against Treponema pallidum for the treatment of neurosyphilis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic after recently being diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) following a routine screening test. She reports feeling well and denies any symptoms such as fever, weight loss, night sweats, or gastrointestinal issues. Past medical history is significant for genital herpes. She has had multiple sexual partners in the past, with inconsistent condom use. She has no history of intravenous substance use. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are reviewed and confirm the diagnosis of HIV infection with antibodies to HIV-1 detected on an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. CD4 count is 500 cells/µL. Viral load is pending. Hepatitis B and C and pregnancy testing is negative. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Start two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI)
Perform confirmatory HIV Western blot testing

questions.solution:
The recommended treatment approach for patients with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is to begin antiretroviral therapy (ART) as soon as possible after diagnosis. The goals of therapy are to suppress viral replication, reduce the viral load to undetectable levels, prevent disease progression, and reduce disease transmission. A typical ART regimen includes two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI). This combination targets different parts of the HIV life cycle, enhancing the effectiveness of treatment and reducing the risk of resistance.

Baseline HIV-1 RNA levels (viral load) and CD4 counts should be obtained to assess the stage of the infection and guide treatment decisions. Genotype resistance testing is recommended to identify drug-resistant strains of HIV, allowing for tailored therapy; however, testing should not delay initiation of ART as discussed above, which can be later adjusted based on the results of resistance testing.

Management of HIV also includes vaccination against preventable infections, such as influenza, pneumococcal disease, hepatitis B, and human papillomavirus (HPV). Patient education should emphasize the importance of medication adherence to prevent resistance, safe sex practices to reduce transmission risk, avoidance of intravenous substance use, and regular follow-up appointments to monitor treatment efficacy and manage side effects or complications.   

Option Analysis

❌ Await viral load results and start antiretroviral therapy (ART) if >5000 copies/mL  :
Incorrect: Delaying initiation of antiretroviral therapy is not recommended as early treatment improves clinical outcomes, reduces HIV transmission, and prevents the progression to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).  
❌ Begin protease inhibitor (PI) monotherapy:
Incorrect: Monotherapy with protease inhibitors is not recommended due to the increased risk of developing drug resistance and inferior efficacy compared to combination antiretroviral therapy (ART). 
✅ Start two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Start two non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) :
Incorrect: NNRTIs can be used in combination with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) for initial HIV treatment, but they are not recommended as monotherapy.  
❌ Perform confirmatory HIV Western blot testing:
Incorrect: HIV Western blot testing is no longer recommended for initial or confirmatory testing due to its lower sensitivity compared to modern combination immunoassays and nucleic acid tests.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the obstetrician for evaluation of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Over the past two weeks, the patient has noticed a fishy vaginal odor. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 110/79 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Upon pelvic examination, gray-white discharge is apparent. She has never had a sexually transmitted infection but has recently been sexually active with a new partner. An amine whiff test is performed, which enhances the odor. The patient is started on a medication for the treatment of her symptoms. Three days later, while at a restaurant, she develops flushing, hypotension, nausea, and vomiting after consuming a glass of wine. Which of the following best characterizes the mechanism causing this reaction?
questions.solution:
This patient has a fishy-smelling vaginal odor and gray discharge. These findings are suggestive of bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis. She was most likely prescribed metronidazole, which causes a disulfiram-like reaction after consuming alcohol since the drug leads to acetaldehyde accumulation within the body.

Metronidazole is an antibiotic and antiprotozoal medication. It functions by generating toxic metabolites that damage pathogenic DNA. However, some of these metabolites inhibit the hepatic enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase. Aldehyde dehydrogenase plays a vital role in ethanol metabolism by breaking down acetaldehyde into acetate. As a result, when patients consume alcohol while taking metronidazole, acetaldehyde builds up and produces symptoms of a disulfiram-like reaction (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, flushing, headache).
   

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of alcohol dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis, often treated using metronidazole. Although metronidazole can cause a disulfiram-like reaction if the patient consumes alcohol while taking the drug, it does not inhibit the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase.  
❌ Rapid accumulation of ethanol:
Incorrect: This patient was most likely started on metronidazole to treat bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis. Metronidazole does not directly cause excessive ethanol accumulation.  
❌ Accumulation of acetate:
Incorrect: Acetate is formed via the catalysis of acetaldehyde by the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. Metronidazole inhibits this enzyme and causes the accumulation of acetaldehyde, not acetate.  
✅ Accumulation of acetaldehyde:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deficiency of adequate reducing agents:
Incorrect: This patient was most likely started on metronidazole to treat bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardenrelalla vaginalis. Metronidazole does not deplete reducing agents required for the metabolism of alcohol.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought by ambulance to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status and abdominal and pelvic pain. The patient’s mother arrived at the patient’s house and found her in pain and confused. The patient was recently diagnosed with a sexually transmitted infection and started on oral antibiotics. She has no significant past medical history and takes no daily medications. Temperature is 39°C (102°F), blood pressure is 86/50 mmHg, pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient appears ill and is confused. Physical examination reveals lower abdominal tenderness with guarding and rebound. Pelvic examination demonstrates bilateral adnexal tenderness to palpation, cervical motion tenderness, and mucopurulent cervical discharge. White blood cell count shows leukocytosis.  ESR and CRP are elevated. The patient is started on empiric antibiotics and intravenous fluids. Labs are ordered and pending. Urine HCG is negative for pregnancy. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis
MRI of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient who was recently treated for a sexually transmitted infection is presenting with evidence of sepsis and peritonitis. These findings likely represent a tubo-ovarian abscess (TOA) secondary to PID. A ruptured TOA can be life-threatening, and an emergent gynecology consult should be called for potential exploratory surgery.

Pelvic inflammatory disease, or PID, refers to an inflammatory condition that affects the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and peritoneum. PID is often caused by infection with sexually transmitted organisms such as gonorrhea and chlamydia. However, it may also be caused by microorganisms normally found in the vaginal flora.

The acute management of an unstable patient with PID includes stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. All patients with suspected PID should have an HCG pregnancy test. Unstable patients should have a focused history and physical examination performed, assessing for a history of PID or sexually transmitted infections and associated risk factors (e.g. multiple partners). Patients should have a pelvic examination to assess for the presence of cervical motion, uterine, and adnexal tenderness. Signs of cervicitis and discharge may also be seen. Patients should receive empiric antibiotics. Bloodwork including blood cultures, lactate level, NAAT testing, cbc and cmp should be obtained. A gynecologic surgery consultation should be called for possible exploratory surgery.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gynecological consultation for exploratory surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transvaginal ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Transvaginal ultrasonography is indicated in stable patients with evidence of PID to rule out a tubo-ovarian abscess and decide on appropriate discharge planning. This patient is unstable with sepsis and findings consistent with PID, therefore she requires prompt gynecologic consultation.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient is unstable with clinical findings consistent with PID and sepsis and requires prompt gynecologic consultation.  
❌ General surgery consultation:
Incorrect: This patient's presentation is consistent with PID and sepsis which may be caused by tubo-ovarian abscess. Gynecologic surgery should be consulted over general surgery.  
❌ MRI of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient is unstable with a possible tubo-ovarian abscess and requires prompt gynecologic surgery consultation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of pelvic pain for 2 days. She also has nausea and vomiting. The patient has a past medical history of recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and she is sexually active with multiple partners. She states that her symptoms feel similar to prior episodes of PID. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 126/76 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Abdominal exam is significant for lower abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Pelvic examination demonstrates cervical motion tenderness and mucopurulent cervical discharge. Wet mount and nucleic amplification testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia are pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Call gynecological consultation for surgical intervention
Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs, symptoms, and physical exam findings consistent with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The most appropriate next step in management is to determine her pregnancy status with a urine or serum beta HCG. Beta HCG should be obtained to rule out ectopic pregnancy and complications from an intrauterine pregnancy. PID can occur in early pregnancy and requires hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics.

Patients with a clinical diagnosis of PID should have laboratory evaluations including HCG, microscopy of the vaginal discharge, CBC, chemistries, ESR, CRP, and NAAT for gonorrhea and chlamydia. Although most cases of PID are associated with gonorrhea and chlamydia, other organisms such as Trichomonas vaginalis, bacterial vaginosis, Mycoplasma genitalium, cytomegalovirus, and bacteria that comprise the normal vaginal flora can also cause PID.

Option Analysis

✅ Send urine beta HCG:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform transvaginal ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Pregnancy testing should be done first to rule out ectopic pregnancy or complications of an intrauterine pregnancy.  
❌ Call gynecological consultation for surgical intervention:
Incorrect: Surgical intervention is reserved for cases of PID and sepsis where tubo-ovarian abscess is suspected.  
❌ Administer ampicillin and gentamicin:
Incorrect: Ampicillin and gentamicin are used to treat complicated PID in hospitalized patients. Patients with simple uncomplicated PID, as seen in this patient, can be treated in the outpatient setting with doxycycline and metronidazole after a dose of ceftriaxone.  
❌ Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT of the abdomen and pelvis is not necessary to diagnose PID.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of pelvic pain. She has also had vaginal discharge and nausea and vomiting for the past 3 days. The patient has multiple sexual partners and uses barrier protection inconsistently. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 130/60 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Pelvic examination demonstrates cervical motion tenderness, bilateral adnexal tenderness, and a mucopurulent cervical discharge. Labs including wet mount and nucleic amplification testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia are pending. Urine beta HCG is negative. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics
Administer IM ceftriaxone and discharge on oral doxycycline and metronidazole
CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
