This patient presents with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) and is febrile, nauseous, and vomiting. Therefore she is considered to have severe disease and should be admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Patients with severe or complicated PID should be hospitalized and started on broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and IV fluids. This includes patients with severe illness (fever > 38.5°C [101°F], nausea and vomiting), patients with PID complicated by a pelvic abscess (including TOA) seen on transvaginal ultrasound, pregnant patients, and patients who have not been able to tolerate oral medications.

Patients with suspected TOA should be admitted and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics.  Transvaginal ultrasound should be performed and gynecologic surgery consultation should be called if TOA is confirmed. Any patients with PID who are unstable or have sepsis should have gynecologic surgery consultation for a possible exploratory laparotomy.

Patients with mild to moderate PID who can tolerate oral intake and have a normal transvaginal ultrasound without TOA can be given IM ceftriaxone and treated as outpatients with doxycycline and metronidazole. They should have follow-up within 72 hours to ensure clinical improvement.  

Option Analysis

✅ Admit to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discharge on keflex and metronidazole:
Incorrect: Discharge is inappropriate for this patient who has evidence of severe disease with fever, nausea, and vomiting. She should be admitted to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics.  
❌ Gynecologic surgery consultation:
Incorrect: Gynecological consultation is indicated for complicated PID (e.g. tubo-ovarian abscess, peritonitis, sepsis). This patient has a normal transvaginal ultrasound ruling out complicated disease.  
❌ Administer IM ceftriaxone and discharge on oral doxycycline and metronidazole:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate management for a patient with mild to moderate PID without complications. This patient has severe disease with fever, nausea, and vomiting and should be admitted for IV antibiotics.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT of the abdomen and pelvis is not part of the diagnostic workup or evaluation of PID.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of vaginal discharge and itching for 2 days. The patient is sexually active with one male partner and takes oral contraceptive pills for contraception. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago and was normal. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no other medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genital examination reveals vulvar excoriations. Speculum examination reveals thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge without evidence of a retained foreign body. The cervix appears normal and there is no cervical motion tenderness. A pregnancy test is negative. Potassium hydroxide microscopy reveals pseudohyphae and spores. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with vulvovaginal itching, excoriations, and thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge along with a normal cervical exam most likely has candidiasis. Potassium hydroxide microscopy reveals pseudohyphae and spores, confirming the diagnosis of vulvovaginal candidiasis.

Vaginal discharge is one of the most common reasons biologically female patients present for gynecologic care. Abnormal vaginal discharge can cause significant discomfort and pain, and can adversely affect daily activities, sexual functioning, and self-image. Patients who present with abnormal vaginal discharge should first be assessed for retained vaginal foreign bodies. Suppose there is no evidence of a foreign body. In that case, the next step is to assess the presence of vaginal inflammation or infection, known as vaginitis, and to determine the cause of vaginitis by direct treatment.

Vulvovaginal candidiasis is the second most common form of vaginitis after bacterial vaginosis. Infection with yeast leads to inflammation of the vagina and vulva. The most common cause is infection with Candida albicans. Patients typically report thick, white vaginal discharge and vaginal itching. They may also report vulvar itching, pain, redness, or swelling. The physical exam will typically reveal a thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge. The vulva may appear erythematous and edematous, and there may be excoriations from scratching and fissures may be present. Potassium hydroxide (KOH) microscopy will demonstrate pseudohyphae and spores, confirming the diagnosis. The vaginal pH will typically be between 3.5 to 4.5. Candida PCR or culture can also be used to confirm the diagnosis, but these tests typically take longer for the results to come back.  

Option Analysis

✅ Vulvovaginal candidiasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Physiologic discharge:
Incorrect: Patients with physiologic discharge have discharge without odor and without vaginal and vulvar irritation. Physical examination typically reveals a white or clear vaginal discharge that is viscous and not white and curd-like as seen with candidiasis. Saline microscopy in patients with physiologic discharge would show mature squamous cells and abundant lactobacilli, and potassium hydroxide microscopy would be negative for pseudohyphae and spores.  
❌ Bacterial vaginosis:
Incorrect: Patients with bacterial vaginosis typically report a thin watery discharge with a “fishy” odor, and the physical exam would show a thin gray-white vaginal discharge with clue cells seen on microscopy. Potassium hydroxide microscopy would be negative for pseudohyphae and spores.  
❌ Vaginal trichomoniasis:
Incorrect: Symptomatic patients with trichomoniasis typically report vaginal discharge with odor, vulvar itching, irritation, and dysuria. Physical examination may reveal a yellow, frothy, vaginal discharge as well as vaginal erythema or cervical erythema with petechiae (strawberry cervix). Saline microscopy shows motile trichomonads and many polymorphonucleocytes. Potassium hydroxide microscopy would be negative for pseudohyphae and spores.  
❌ Chlamydia infection:
Incorrect: Symptomatic patients with chlamydia may report thick vaginal discharge, dysuria, non-menstrual or post-coital spotting, and possibly pelvic pain. They may have a history of recent unprotected sexual activity with a new partner. The physical exam can show mucopurulent cervical discharge, a friable cervix, and cervical motion tenderness. Potassium hydroxide microscopy would be negative for pseudohyphae and spores.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of vaginal discharge and itching. The patient is sexually active with biological males, does not use condoms, and her last sexual encounter was one week ago. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She has no significant past medical history, and she does not take any medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows vulvar erythema and a scant amount of thin yellow-green frothy vaginal discharge. The cervix appears erythematous with petechiae. There is no cervical motion tenderness. A pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with thin yellow-green frothy vaginal discharge, vaginal itching, and findings of vulvar erythema and cervical erythema with petechiae most likely has vaginal trichomoniasis. The most appropriate next step is to perform saline microscopy. If saline microscopy shows motile trichomonads, then trichomonas vaginalis can be diagnosed.

Vaginal trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection that is caused by the protozoan parasite, trichomonas vaginalis. Symptomatic patients with trichomoniasis typically report vaginal discharge with an odor that is accompanied by vulvar itching, irritation, and/or dysuria. The physical exam may reveal a yellow, frothy, vaginal discharge as well as vaginal erythema or cervical erythema with petechiae, known as a strawberry cervix. The diagnosis can be made with saline microscopy that shows motile trichomonads and many polymorphonucleocytes. The pH is typically greater than 4.5 and the “whiff” test is typically positive. If no motile trichomonads are seen, then nucleic acid amplification (NAAT) for T. vaginalis can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Saline microscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Candida PCR test:
Incorrect: Patients with vaginal candidiasis typically present with thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge. The initial test of choice, in offices with appropriate equipment, is potassium hydroxide wet mount. For this patient with a thin yellow-green frothy vaginal discharge and findings of vulvar erythema and a strawberry cervix, vaginal trichomoniasis is most likely. Saline microscopy should be performed to look for motile trichomonads.  
❌ Clinical observation:
Incorrect: Clinical observation would be appropriate if the vaginal discharge appears to be physiologic and likely related to ovulation or pregnancy. Given this patient’s clinical findings of vulvar erythema, itching, odorous discharge, and strawberry cervix, she most likely has vaginal trichomoniasis and saline microscopy should be performed to look for motile trichomonads.  
❌ Transvaginal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Transvaginal ultrasound is useful to evaluate vaginal discharge in the setting of pelvic pain or when pelvic inflammatory disease is suspected. This patient does not have signs or findings consistent with PID. Given this patient’s clinical findings of vulvar erythema, itching, odorous discharge, and strawberry cervix, she most likely has vaginal trichomoniasis and saline microscopy should be performed to look for motile trichomonads.  
❌ Oral fluconazole:
Incorrect: Oral fluconazole can be used to treat vulvovaginal candidiasis. However, given this patient’s clinical findings of vulvar erythema, itching, odorous discharge, and strawberry cervix, she most likely has vaginal trichomoniasis and saline microscopy should be performed to look for motile trichomonads.

questions.text: A 24-year-old G1P0 woman at 29 weeks gestation presents to the primary care office for evaluation of three days of malodorous vaginal discharge and vaginal itching. She reports an episode of unprotected intercourse with a new biologically male partner two weeks prior. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals a green, frothy vaginal discharge. There is no cervical motion tenderness or suprapubic pain. The vaginal pH is 4.8.  Saline microscopy of the vaginal fluid reveals motile, pear-shaped microorganisms and many polymorphonuclear white blood cells.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Wait until after delivery of the infant to initiate treatment

questions.solution:
This patient’s vaginal pruritus and frothy green vaginal discharge that began after an episode of unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner is concerning for a sexually transmitted infection.  The presence of motile, pear-shaped microorganisms and many polymorphonuclear white blood cells on saline microscopy confirms Trichomonas vaginalis.  All patients with vaginal trichomoniasis should be treated with antibiotics such as metronidazole, and treatment is especially important in pregnant patients given the potential pregnancy complications associated with the infection. Oral metronidazole is used most commonly, with a seven-day treatment course preferred in both pregnant and non-pregnant women.  

Nitroimidazoles are the class of antibiotics used to treat trichomoniasis. The recommendation for men is treatment with a single high dose of metronidazole.  A single dose of oral tinidazole can also be given to both biologically male and female patients but should be avoided in pregnancy.  All sexual partners should be informed of the diagnosis and encouraged to have testing and treatment.  Reinfection rates are high, and patients should be encouraged to return for any recurrence of symptoms as well as to be retested three months after treatment, regardless of symptom status.  

In addition to antibiotic treatment, patients with vaginal trichomonas should be screened for HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis. Patients should be counseled on lifestyle modifications including avoiding douching and abstaining from intercourse until they, and all sexual partners, are treated and symptom-free.

Option Analysis

✅ Oral metronidazole :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Oral tinidazole:
Incorrect: Tinidazole is a treatment option for trichomoniasis in non-pregnant patients, however it crosses the placenta and has been shown to have adverse effects in animal studies. Therefore, it is not recommended for use in pregnancy.
❌ Topical clotrimazole :
Incorrect: Clotrimazole is a treatment for vaginal candidiasis, which is a fungal infection. This patient has trichomoniasis and needs treatment with an antibiotic such as metronidazole.
❌ Topical fluconazole:
Incorrect: Fluconazole is a treatment for fungal infections. This patient has trichomoniasis and needs treatment with an antibiotic such as metronidazole. Additionally, fluconazole is not generally recommended in pregnancy.
❌ Wait until after delivery of the infant to initiate treatment:
Incorrect: Trichomoniasis is associated with increased pregnancy complications and pregnant patients should be promptly treated with metronidazole.

questions.text: A 20-year-old G1P0 woman at 12 weeks gestation presents to her obstetrician’s office for routine prenatal care. The patient does not have any concerns at this time. She is sexually active with a new partner since becoming pregnant and is not in a committed monogamous relationship. Her medical history is unremarkable, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She smokes cigarettes but does not use alcohol or recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination is normal. Initial sexually transmitted infection screening is ordered and is negative. Which of the following screening tests should be repeated when this patient is in the third trimester?

choices.text: Syphilis, HIV, and herpes simplex virus
Human papillomavirus, HIV, and hepatitis B

questions.solution:
This pregnant patient with high-risk features for sexually transmitted infections (STI) should have repeat screening for chlamydia, gonorrhea, syphilis, HIV, and hepatitis B in the third trimester of her pregnancy.  Having a new sexual partner places her at high-risk of developing STIs.  

Pregnant patients should have baseline screening for sexually transmitted infections at their first prenatal visit. The tests to include in the baseline screening for all pregnant patients who are under age 25 or considered high-risk are syphilis, HIV, hepatitis B and C, gonorrhea, and chlamydia. Patients at increased risk for infections, as well as those who have initially positive screening tests, need to have screening for certain conditions repeated in the third trimester. Human papillomavirus (HPV) screening should follow standard recommendations regardless of pregnancy status. If a pregnant patient is determined to have HIV, screening should then be expanded to include conditions screened for in HIV-positive individuals, such as trichomoniasis and possibly herpes simplex virus (HSV) serology.    

All pregnant women under the age of 25 should have repeat testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia in the third trimester. Repeat testing for chlamydia, gonorrhea, syphilis, HIV and hepatitis B should be done in the third trimester in patients who are considered high-risk. High-risk factors include having new or multiple sexual partners, engaging in transactional sex, having a sexual partner who has other concurrent partners, as well as living in an area with a high prevalence of disease. Repeat screening for hepatitis B and HIV should also be done in the third trimester for any pregnant patients who have recently begun using or currently use intravenous drugs.   

A detailed table adapted from the U.S. Center for Disease Control (CDC) with facts on STI screening in pregnancy can be found below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Chlamydia, gonorrhea, and syphilis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomoniasis :
Incorrect: Chlamydia and gonorrhea should be screened for in the third trimester in this patient with high-risk features. However, screening for trichomoniasis is not recommended in asymptomatic pregnant women. 
❌ Chlamydia, bacterial vaginosis, and syphilis :
Incorrect: Chlamydia and syphilis should be screened for in the third trimester in this patient with high-risk features. However, screening for bacterial vaginosis is not recommended in asymptomatic pregnant women. 
❌ Syphilis, HIV, and herpes simplex virus:
Incorrect: Syphilis and HIV should be screened for in the third trimester in this patient with high-risk features. However, screening for herpes simplex virus is not recommended in asymptomatic pregnant women. 
❌ Human papillomavirus, HIV, and hepatitis B:
Incorrect: HIV and Hepatitis B should be screened for in the third trimester in this patient with high-risk features. However, screening for HPV is not recommended in asymptomatic pregnant women, or in women under age 25.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office because of vulvar pain and dysuria. She does not have increased urinary frequency or flank pain. She has never experienced similar symptoms before and her past medical history is unremarkable. The patient is sexually active and has had 4 sexual partners in the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Current medications include a combined oral contraceptive and a hair vitamin. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows grouped shallow ulcers with erythema on the right labia majora. Right inguinal lymph nodes are tender to palpation. After further evaluation, the patient is started on an oral medication that requires a specific thymidine kinase for activation. Which of the following is an important adverse effect of the medication used in this patient when it is administered intravenously?
questions.solution:
This patient’s physical examination findings of grouped shallow genital ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy are consistent with herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Primary HSV infection is usually treated with acyclovir, which requires thymidine kinase for activation.  

Acyclovir is a guanosine analog that is effective against HSV-1, HSV-2, and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections. When used orally, it is only partially absorbed; therefore, it is used for mild mucocutaneous lesions and genital lesions or for herpes prophylaxis in immunocompromised individuals, such as individuals with AIDS. The oral drug is well tolerated but may cause gastrointestinal (GI) distress and headache. On the other hand, intravenous acyclovir is the treatment of more severe herpes infections, such as HSV encephalitis or neonatal HSV infection. Toxic effects of parenteral administration include delirium, tremor, seizures, hypotension, and nephrotoxicity (obstructive crystalline nephropathy and acute kidney injury). Acyclovir has no effect on latent forms of HSV and VZV. Resistance can involve changes in viral DNA polymerase or a mutation in viral thymidylate kinase.

Option Analysis

❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression is an important side effect of ganciclovir, which is effective against cytomegalovirus. This patient most likely has an HSV infection.
❌ Pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis is an important side effect of didanosine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. Didanosine is not effective against HSV.
✅ Obstructive crystalline nephropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Acute interstitial nephritis:
Incorrect: Acute interstitial nephritis is usually associated with exposure to beta-lactams and proton pump inhibitors. This patient’s HSV infection is most likely being treated with acyclovir.
❌ Disulfiram-like reaction:
Incorrect: Disulfiram-like reactions can occur commonly with metronidazole or griseofulvin, neither of which is effective against HSV.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the outpatient gynecology clinic with a 6-day history of dysuria and green vaginal discharge. The patient is sexually active with one male partner, who travels frequently for work. She has an intrauterine device (IUD) for contraception that was placed three years ago. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/75 mmHg. Genitourinary examination shows an edematous, friable cervix with mucopurulent discharge. An endocervical swab is sent for nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) to confirm the likely diagnosis. A point-of-care HCG pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: IUD removal followed by antibiotic treatment

questions.solution:
This 28-year-old woman presents with a 6-day history of dysuria, green vaginal discharge, and examination findings consistent with Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Antibiotic treatment should be given at the initial visit and should consist of intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral doxycycline (to include coverage for chlamydial coinfection).

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the antibiotic of choice for uncomplicated gonococcal cervicitis.  Because coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis is exceedingly common in cases of gonorrhea, antibiotic coverage should also include oral doxycycline or oral azithromycin for presumptive coinfection. Patients should be treated on-site to ensure compliance, or they should be referred to a sexually transmitted infection (STI) clinic for same-day treatment. If patients do not respond to first-line treatment, cultures should be sent because of increasing antibiotic resistance.

If a biologically female patient with Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection has an intrauterine device (IUD) in place, as in this case, the IUD does not need to be removed as part of the management plan. However, it is important to note that a new IUD should not be placed for patients with current purulent cervicitis.

In addition to treating the patient with empiric antibiotics, all sexual partners should be referred for evaluation and treatment. In cases where a patient’s partners are not available for evaluation and treatment, expedited partner therapy (EPT) can be prescribed, which permits the provider to provide treatment without requiring them to come in for an examination.  Additional screening for other sexually transmitted infections is recommended, including HIV, syphilis, and Chlamydia trachomatis. Pre-exposure prophylaxis for HIV (PrEP) should also be offered to patients who are HIV-negative because it reduces the risk of acquiring HIV. Finally, patients should be counseled to abstain from sexual intercourse for seven days following completion of treatment, as long as symptoms have resolved and all partners have been treated.

If patients’ symptoms resolve following treatment for uncomplicated N. gonorrhoeae infection, they do not need to be tested for a cure. However, since pharyngitis from N. gonorrhoeae is harder to eradicate, patients with oropharyngeal N. gonorrhoeae infections should have a test for cure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intramuscular ceftriaxone plus oral doxycycline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ IUD removal followed by antibiotic treatment:
Incorrect: In female patients who have an IUD in place and suspected Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, removal of the IUD is not required before or after starting antibiotic treatment.  
❌ Intramuscular ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Monotherapy with intramuscular ceftriaxone is not the appropriate treatment in patients with suspected Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been excluded in this case, so treatment should include coverage for both pathogens.  
❌ Oral doxycycline:
Incorrect: Monotherapy with oral doxycycline is not appropriate because it is not sufficiently effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae.  
❌ Oral metronidazole:
Incorrect: Metronidazole targets anaerobic bacteria and protozoa, which makes it appropriate treatment for bacterial vaginosis or trichomoniasis. However, it is not effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is a concern based on this patient’s clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, presents at 20 weeks estimated gestational age for a routine antenatal visit. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated. The patient’s partner was recently diagnosed with genital herpes, and the patient would like to be evaluated. She has no significant past medical history and has not previously had a sexually transmitted infection. She is currently taking a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg. On physical examination, there are no oral lesions. The abdomen is gravid and without tenderness. Genital exam with pelvic speculum examination is performed. Which of the following examination findings would be consistent with a diagnosis of genital herpes?
questions.solution:
This pregnant woman is requesting evaluation for genital herpes after learning that her partner was recently diagnosed. She has no history of sexually transmitted infections; therefore, if she had a primary infection with genital herpes, she would likely have multiple painful erythematous genital vesicles or ulcers.     

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a common sexually transmitted infection. While HSV-2 is more commonly associated with genital ulcers, HSV-1 can also cause genital ulcers. Maternal primary infection during the first trimester of pregnancy can result in several neonatal health issues, such as chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and skin lesions. Maternal primary infection during delivery can lead to transmission of the virus to the neonate and possible disseminated central nervous system disease. As such, HSV outbreaks must be treated aggressively and prevented whenever possible during pregnancy.   

Primary HSV outbreaks typically cause multiple genital vesicles or ulcers on an erythematous base, which are generally painful and may be pruritic. Patients may also have dysuria, fever, tender local inguinal lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms like headache. Some patients experience a prodrome of burning or tingling in the area prior to the appearance of the lesions. Recurrent outbreaks may cause a single mildly painful lesion. Manifestations of genital herpes can be highly variable, and some patients may only have mild disease or may be asymptomatic.   

Patients should be asked about prior HSV outbreaks or known exposures, and testing for HSV antibodies can be conducted. For pregnant women with suspected HSV, inspection of the perineum and genitals with speculum examination can be performed. The examination may reveal the characteristic vulvar lesions, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy on the side of the lesions, and potentially cervical lesions. Serum antibody testing and viral testing of the lesions should be performed. Consider testing for other STIs if genital herpes lesions are seen.    

Option Analysis

✅ Painful vulvar vesicular lesions:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Painless vulvar ulcers:
Incorrect: A painless, well-demarcated vulvar ulcer, especially if it has a clean base and indurated border, is seen in primary syphilis. Patients with primary infection with genital herpes typically present with multiple painful vesicular lesions. 
❌ Thick white vaginal discharge:
Incorrect: Thick white vaginal discharge is typically seen with vaginal candidiasis, which occurs due to disruption of the normal vulvovaginal microbiome. Patients with primary infection with genital herpes typically present with painful vulvar vesicular lesions. 
❌ Thin gray vaginal discharge:
Incorrect: Patients with bacterial vaginosis often present with thin gray vaginal discharge. Patients with primary infection with genital herpes typically present with painful vulvar vesicular lesions. 
❌ Cervical motion tenderness:
Incorrect: The presence of cervical motion tenderness indicates pelvic inflammatory disease, which is typically caused by C. trachomatis or N. gonorrhea and not genital herpes.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 8 days after reporting a sexual assault. The patient reports persistent anxiety but no current physical injury. Medical history is unremarkable, and no medications are taken. There is no history of substance use or prior trauma. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is alert and oriented with no visible injuries. Physical examination reveals mild vaginal erythema without bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Referral to mental health services for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
Empiric treatment for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomonas

questions.solution:
In cases of sexual assault occurring more than 7 days prior, management shifts from immediate post-exposure interventions to addressing potential sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and evaluating the patient for pregnancy. Since prophylactic measures like HIV PEP and emergency contraception are only effective within specific timeframes (72 hours for HIV PEP and 120 hours for emergency contraception), they are not recommended after this period. Instead, patients should be offered comprehensive STI testing and empiric treatment for common pathogens such as chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomonas to prevent long-term complications. Additionally, pregnancy testing should be performed, the patient should be assessed for ongoing safety, and support should be provided.    

Effective management of sexual assault involves a stepwise, evidence-based approach that includes immediate medical assessment and treatment of injuries, testing and empiric treatment for STIs and pregnancy, and providing emotional and social support. It also emphasizes the importance of trauma-informed care, patient autonomy, and connecting patients with appropriate mental health and community resources for long-term recovery.    

If the assault occurred recently, patients should be offered HIV PEP, emergency contraception, and a forensic examination, as appropriate. It is also important to discuss mandatory reporting requirements (e.g. abuse in a minor) with the patient, offer support, and comply with all local legal reporting requirements.    

P.S. If you or someone you know has experienced a sexual assault, you can call RAINN National Sexual Assault Telephone Hotline at 800.656.HOPE (4673) or visit https://rainn.org/ to be connected with a trained staff member from a sexual assault service provider in your area.   

Option Analysis

❌ Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV):
Incorrect: HIV PEP must be started within 72 hours of exposure to be effective. At 8 days post-assault, initiation would not provide benefit. 
❌ Referral to mental health services for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD):
Incorrect: Referral to mental health services is essential but not the most urgent next step in this context. Immediate medical management focuses on addressing potential infections and pregnancy risks. 
❌ Emergency contraception:
Incorrect: Emergency contraception is most effective if administered within 120 hours (5 days) of the assault. Because 8 days have passed, it is no longer indicated or effective in preventing pregnancy. Pregnancy testing should be performed, but empiric sexually transmitted infection (STI) treatment is the priority. 
❌ Sexual assault forensic exam:
Incorrect: Most forensic evidence collection protocols recommend performing the exam within 72 hours of the assault. At 8 days, the likelihood of obtaining useful biological evidence is low, though documentation of findings may still be considered. This is not the most appropriate next step in this case. 
✅ Empiric treatment for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomonas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of one week of vaginal discharge and pain with intercourse. She does not have fever or pelvic pain. She has had a new biologically male sexual partner for two months and they do not use condoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 144/84 mmHg. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals a green, frothy vaginal discharge and cervical petechiae. There is no cervical motion tenderness or suprapubic pain. The vaginal pH is 5.1. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has a new sexual partner, presents with dyspareunia and frothy, green vaginal discharge with an elevated vaginal pH. She should have testing for sexually transmitted infections including trichomoniasis.  Nucleic acid amplification testing is highly sensitive and can confirm a diagnosis of trichomoniasis, as well as test for other common sexually transmitted infections such as gonorrhea and chlamydia.    

Vaginal trichomoniasis is primarily diagnosed with saline microscopy or nucleic acid amplification testing.  Rapid, point-of-care tests are also available for detecting Trichomonas vaginalis. Saline microscopy done on a sample of vaginal fluid is cost-effective and can provide an immediate diagnosis if motile trichomonads and many polymorphonuclear white blood cells are seen. However, not all facilities are equipped for this test.  Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is more expensive and will take longer to receive results, but it is highly sensitive and allows for simultaneous testing for other sexually transmitted infections, candidiasis, and bacterial vaginosis. The vaginal pH can assist in diagnosis as well, as the pH is typically elevated in vaginal trichomoniasis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Nucleic acid amplification testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vaginal culture:
Incorrect: Vaginal cultures can detect Trichomonas vaginalis, but these are rarely used for diagnosis, as NAAT testing has higher sensitivity and better detection rates and is therefore the preferred diagnostic test.
❌ Metronidazole therapy:
Incorrect: There is significant overlap in the presentation of sexually transmitted infections, therefore obtaining an accurate diagnosis is important for selection of the correct antibiotic and for partner notification. Empiric treatment should be considered for gonorrhea and chlamydia depending on patient preference, but it is not typically offered as part of the treatment of trichomonas unless there is a known exposure. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound :
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound can be done when there is clinical concern for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). This patient does not have symptoms or physical exam findings that are concerning for PID. Imaging is not routinely indicated in the management of vaginal trichomoniasis. 
❌ Recommend douching :
Incorrect: Douching is not a treatment for vaginal trichomoniasis, and it actually causes patients to be at higher risk of contracting the infection due to the disruption of normal flora.

questions.text: A 20-year-old biologically female patient presents to the clinic for evaluation of one week of watery vaginal discharge. She has noticed scant vaginal bleeding after vaginal intercourse as well. She has not had abdominal pain, sore throat, difficulty swallowing or fever. She is sexually active with a new partner who is biologically male, and they do not use condoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/74mmHg. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals watery discharge without notable odor.  There is no cervical motion tenderness. A cervical swab is collected for nucleic acid amplification testing. Which of the following additional tests should be done at this time?

choices.text: Pharyngeal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing

questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms of watery vaginal discharge and post-coital bleeding in the setting of having a new sexual partner and lack of use of barrier protection make a sexually transmitted infection such as chlamydia highly likely.  In addition to sending nucleic acid amplification testing, a pregnancy test should always be collected in biologically female patients with reproductive potential who are suspected of having a sexually transmitted infection. Pregnancy status will determine which treatment options are available and the necessary frequency of follow-up testing.    

Chlamydia trachomatis can cause infection in a number of areas of the body including the eyes, pharynx, cervix, vagina, urethra, prostate and epididymis. The gold standard for making a diagnosis is with nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).  A swab can be collected from the affected area, or first-catch urine can be used in suspected genitourinary infections.  Testing the urine is not as sensitive for detecting infection in biologically female patients, and a patient or provider-collected vaginal or cervical swab is preferred.  In addition to NAAT, all biologically female patients with reproductive potential should have a pregnancy test collected at the time the NAAT is done.    

Because of the high incidence of asymptomatic infections, as well as the potential for long-term consequences in untreated patients, screening should be performed at least yearly in high-risk populations, which includes sexually active women under the age of 25 and men who have sex with men.  Biologically female patients over the age of 25 who have risk factors such as new or multiple sexual partners should also be tested yearly. Screening for chlamydia should be done as part of the routine prenatal care for all pregnant women.   

Option Analysis

✅ Urine pregnancy test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vaginal culture:
Incorrect: Vaginal culture was historically used for diagnosis of sexually transmitted infections, but is rarely performed anymore. Rather, nucleic acid amplification tests are used for screening and diagnosis.
❌ KOH test:
Incorrect: A KOH test is useful when evaluating for vaginal candida infections or bacterial vaginosis.  This patient’s sexual history and the nature of her symptoms makes chlamydia and gonorrhea high on the differential. Sending a nucleic acid amplification test for both is the best initial test along with a pregnancy test. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound is useful when pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is suspected.  Although chlamydia infections can cause PID, this patient does not have symptoms of PID or cervical motion tenderness on exam.  Imaging is not necessary in routine cases of chlamydia infection. 
❌ Pharyngeal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing:
Incorrect: Chlamydia infection can occur in the pharynx and any symptomatic location should be swabbed and sent for nucleic acid amplification testing; however, this patient is not reporting symptoms in the throat, therefore it is reasonable to perform focused testing on the vaginal area only.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of increased vaginal discharge and an abnormal odor from the vagina, which has been present for one week. There is no associated pelvic pain or fever. The patient has never been sexually active but reports recently trying douching. She is leaving tomorrow to travel for a semester abroad. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 114/72 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals a thin, grayish-white, watery discharge with a vaginal pH of 4.7. There is no cervical motion tenderness. Which of the following is the best initial diagnostic test?

choices.text: Diagnosis can be made without further testing

questions.solution:
This patient presents with thin, grayish-white vaginal discharge; an abnormal vaginal odor; and a vaginal pH above 4.5 suggesting bacterial vaginosis. She should have saline microscopy of vaginal fluid done next to evaluate for clue cells along with a KOH whiff test. If >20% clue cells are present on microscopy or the whiff test is positive, then three out of four Amsel criteria would be met and the patient can be diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. Douching is a risk factor for developing bacterial vaginosis.    

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) can be diagnosed in a number of ways. The use of Amsel criteria is a low-cost and time-efficient method that can be done in the office and involves meeting at least three of the following four criteria: thin, grayish-white vaginal discharge, vaginal pH above 4.5, a positive whiff test, and identification of clue cells on saline microscopy.  

Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are another way to diagnose bacterial vaginosis and are becoming increasingly more popular as they allow simultaneous testing for other microbes and require less office equipment. However, they are more expensive and take longer to provide results. Nugent scoring is a reliable test for BV but requires a Gram stain of the vaginal discharge and is primarily used in research settings. Choice of which test is best depends on patient factors, such as timing and financial concerns as well as consideration of the resources available in the office at the time of the examination. 

Option Analysis

✅ Saline microscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nucleic acid amplification test:
Incorrect: Nucleic acid amplification can be used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis and sexually transmitted infections, but it is much more expensive and takes more time to reach a diagnosis than saline microscopy. This patient has never been sexually active and will be traveling soon, making saline microscopy and the use of the Amsel criteria the best choice for making a prompt diagnosis. 
❌ Culture of vaginal fluid:
Incorrect: Culture of vaginal fluid may show growth of Gardnerella vaginalis, but this is part of normal flora, so culture alone would not be diagnostic for bacterial vaginosis and would take significant time to get back. The percentage of clue cells seen on saline microscopy is more helpful for making a diagnosis and less costly and time consuming. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound can be performed when there is concern for pelvic inflammatory disease. This patient does not have pelvic pain or cervical motion tenderness and does not report sexual activity, making PID unlikely. Imaging is not indicated for routine cases of bacterial vaginosis. 
❌ Diagnosis can be made without further testing:
Incorrect: In this patient, two of the Amsel criteria are met with the nature of the vaginal discharge and vaginal pH; however, three out of four criteria are needed to make a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Therefore, either clue cells on saline microscopy or a positive whiff test is needed to make the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis in this patient.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is seen for routine evaluation. The patient feels well. She has been sexually active with one male partner in a monogamous relationship for the last year and has been previously treated for human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. She has no other significant medical history. She is currently a resident at a correctional facility. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day but does not regularly consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/82 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and pulse is 84/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following would be an indication to screen this patient for trichomoniasis?
questions.solution:
This sexually active female who is under the age of 25 should be offered appropriate screening for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) as part of a well-check. Patient risk factors determine which tests are indicated. For non-pregnant women without HIV, gonorrhea, and chlamydia, screening should be done annually in all sexually active patients who are less than 25 years old, and in sexually active patients 25 years of age or older who are at increased risk for infection. Trichomonas screening is recommended in patients who are in high-prevalence settings, such as STI clinics and correctional facilities; and for asymptomatic patients at high risk for infection, such as those with multiple sex partners, those who engage in transactional sex or drug use, or those who have a history of STIs or HIV.  

STI screening should be considered in all patients. Factors from the history and physical examination will determine which, if any, tests are indicated. Primary factors to consider are the patient’s age, pregnancy status, HIV status, sexual practices, known exposure to an STI, and symptoms.  When a possible exposure has occurred, important details to gather include timing of sexual exposure, previous screenings or treatment results, and partner’s treatment status.    

The physical examination also plays an important role in determining what tests are indicated.  Cervical or urethral discharge as well as genital lesions should prompt further conversation about possible STI exposures and testing. STIs should be included in the differential for skin rashes as well, as secondary syphilis can cause a variety of skin lesions and rashes that may mimic other conditions.  



Rash on the palms of both hands due to secondary syphilis from Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is licensed under public domain. Accessed 12/26/2023. Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Residence in a correctional facility :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Routine screening for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like gonorrhea and chlamydia is recommended for sexually active patients under the age of 25. However, trichomoniasis is not included in the list of diseases for which women under 25 years of age should be regularly screened.
❌ History of HPV infection:
Incorrect: HPV status does not affect the recommendation for screening for trichomoniasis.
❌ Monogamous sexual partner:
Incorrect: This patient has one sexual partner in a monogamous relationship and does not meet criteria to be screened for trichomoniasis based on this fact. Patients at high risk of infection should be screened, which includes having multiple sexual partners.
❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: Screening for trichomoniasis is indicated for asymptomatic women at high risk for the infection, such as those who use recreational drugs.  Tobacco use is not considered a high-risk activity for contracting this infection.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of malodorous vaginal discharge. The patient reports discharge with an unpleasant fishy smell that is more prominent after vaginal intercourse. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medications. The patient is sexually active with one male partner and has a copper-containing intrauterine device. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a thin, gray discharge that coats the vaginal walls. No erythema or edema is present on the vaginal walls or vulva. There is no cervical or adnexal tenderness. On saline wet-mount examination, clue cells are seen, and no white blood cells or motile organisms are seen. Which is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of gray vaginal discharge with a fishy odor in combination with clue cells on microscopy and the absence of vulvovaginal inflammation is most likely due to overgrowth of the anaerobic bacterium Gardnerella vaginalis leading to bacterial vaginosis (BV). Treatment of symptomatic BV is either metronidazole or clindamycin, regardless of the pregnancy status.  

Clindamycin is a lincosamide that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking the peptide transfer (translocation) at the 50S ribosomal subunit. It is bacteriostatic and can be given perorally, parenterally, or as a topical cream. It is mainly used to treat anaerobic bacterial infections of the oropharynx (e.g. dental abscess) and lungs (e.g. aspiration, abscess), as its spectrum of activity covers Bacteroides, Clostridium perfringens and invasive group A Streptococcus. It can also treat BV. Common side effects include gastrointestinal distress (e.g., nausea, vomiting, diarrhea), the reversible elevation of aspartate aminotransferase and alanine aminotransferase, and skin rashes. Clindamycin use can also cause bacterial superinfection by Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile leading to pseudomembranous colitis. Mechanisms of resistance include methylation of the binding site on the 50S ribosomal subunit and enzymatic inactivation.



Option Analysis

❌ Fluconazole:
Incorrect: Fluconazole is used to manage vulvovaginal candidiasis, which usually presents with thick white vaginal discharge and pseudohyphae seen on microscopy. Predisposing risk factors like corticosteroid use, antibiotic use, or diabetes mellitus are typically present.
✅ Clindamycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir can treat herpes simplex virus infection, which usually presents with painful genital ulcers and not vaginal discharge.
❌ Benzathine penicillin G:
Incorrect: Benzathine penicillin G can be used to manage syphilis, which may present with painless genital lesions (e.g., chancre or condyloma lata). Syphilis does not cause vaginal discharge.
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: Azithromycin is effective against Chlamydia trachomatis cervicitis, which can present with malodorous vaginal discharge. Microscopy, however, shows numerous white blood cells rather than clue cells.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic with a two-week history of dysuria. The patient has also experienced a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, vaginal pruritus, and vaginal discharge. She is sexually active and has had two different male sexual partners in the past four weeks. She does not use condoms. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.3°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 122/79 mmHg. Examination of the oropharynx reveals erythema and cervical lymphadenopathy without pharyngeal exudates. Speculum examination reveals an edematous, friable cervix with mucopurulent discharge. Urine hCG pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation?
questions.solution:
This sexually active 23-year-old woman presents with evidence of pharyngitis and cervicitis with mucopurulent discharge after unprotected sexual intercourse. This constellation of findings is suggestive of gonorrhea, an infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The first step in the evaluation of patients with suspected N. gonorrhoeae infections is to perform nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).

Sexually active biological females presenting with signs and symptoms of cervicitis (as in this case), or with other symptoms suggestive of gonorrhea, should have nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) for diagnosis. This can be performed using self-collected or provider-collected specimens from affected areas (e.g., endocervical swab, first-void urine collection, pharyngeal swab, vaginal swab). NAAT is the most sensitive and preferred diagnostic test for both genital and extragenital gonorrhea infections in males and females. Advantages of NAAT include rapid results, the ability to test asymptomatic patients, and its high sensitivity. Alternatively, samples can be sent for gram stain and culture, which was once the gold standard for diagnosis, but this method is less sensitive than NAAT. It does offer the advantage of antibiotic susceptibility testing if treatment resistance is a concern.

Of note, the majority of gonococcal infections are asymptomatic, particularly in biologically female patients, and annual screening is recommended for high-risk populations, including females under the age of 25 and males who have sex with males.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Complete blood count (CBC):
Incorrect: A CBC may be helpful in assessing a patient with suspected gonococcemia, but it is not useful in the initial evaluation of a patient presenting with acute gonococcal infection. Nucleic acid amplification testing is the preferred diagnostic test for N. gonorrhoeae.  
❌ Gonorrhea culture:
Incorrect: Gonorrhea culture is rarely done, and nucleic acid amplification testing is the preferred diagnostic test for N. gonorrhoeae. Culture may be helpful if resistance is a concern.  
❌ Urinalysis:
Incorrect: A urinalysis can be used to diagnose urinary tract infections, which typically present with dysuria. However, this is not the first step in diagnosing a woman with suspected N. gonorrhoeae infection. Nucleic acid amplification testing is the preferred diagnostic test for N. gonorrhoeae.  
❌ Wet mount microscopy:
Incorrect: Wet mount microscopy is a diagnostic tool used for certain vaginal infections, including bacterial vaginosis or trichomoniasis. However, this patient’s symptoms and examination are more consistent with gonorrhea and nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) should be performed.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal vaginal discharge and odor. The patient is currently 21 weeks pregnant. She describes the discharge as “watery” and the odor as “fishy.” She does not have any chronic medical conditions and currently only takes a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, blood pressure is 122/72 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 20/min. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals a thin, grayish-white discharge. There is no cervical motion tenderness and no suprapubic tenderness. The vaginal pH is 4.7. Saline microscopy shows >20% clue cells and a KOH whiff test is positive. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: No treatment is needed at this time

questions.solution:
This pregnant patient presents with thin, grayish vaginal discharge and a “fishy” vaginal odor with an elevated vaginal pH, clue cells on saline microscopy, and positive whiff test on KOH prep consistent with bacterial vaginosis. The recommended treatment is metronidazole or clindamycin. These antibiotics can be administered either orally or topically during pregnancy. Bacterial vaginosis in pregnancy is associated with increased pregnancy complications, and symptomatic pregnant patients should be treated.    

Treatment of bacterial vaginosis (BV) consists of topical or oral antibiotics and counseling on lifestyle modifications. The antibiotics most commonly used are metronidazole and clindamycin. Patients should be counseled when using topical preparations that they may weaken latex condoms and diaphragms for up to 5 days after completion of treatment. Patients should also be advised to avoid certain hygiene practices, such as douching, as this may increase the risk of recurrence. Although BV is not sexually transmitted, patients with BV are at increased risk for sexually transmitted infections and should be screened for HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis.  

BV can persist despite proper treatment and has a high rate of recurrence; therefore, patients should always be counseled to return if symptoms fail to resolve or recur. When there are three or more distinct episodes in one year, it is considered to be recurrent BV. Options for treatment of recurrent infections include changing the antibiotic or using prolonged antibiotic therapy. Suppressive therapy is also an option, which includes antibiotics twice a week for up to six months.

Option Analysis

✅ Oral metronidazole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Oral tinidazole:
Incorrect: Tinidazole can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis in non-pregnant patients; however, it crosses the placenta and has been shown to have adverse effects in animal studies. Therefore, it is not recommended for use in pregnancy.
❌ Topical miconazole:
Incorrect: Miconazole is a treatment for vaginal candidiasis, a fungal infection. This patient has bacterial vaginosis and needs treatment with an antibiotic, such as metronidazole or clindamycin. 
❌ Topical clotrimazole :
Incorrect: Clotrimazole is a treatment for vaginal candidiasis, a fungal infection. This patient has bacterial vaginosis and needs treatment with an antibiotic, such as metronidazole or clindamycin.
❌ No treatment is needed at this time:
Incorrect: Despite being caused by normal vaginal flora, bacterial vaginosis is associated with increased pregnancy complications, and symptomatic pregnant patients should be treated with oral or topical antibiotics.

questions.text: A 32-year-old biologically female patient presents to the primary care office for an initial visit after learning she is HIV-positive from a screening test. The patient does not have symptoms. Her past medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she does not take medication. The patient is sexually active with one male partner. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following screening tests should be performed at this time?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification testing for trichomoniasis

questions.solution:
This patient who has been newly diagnosed with HIV infection should have screening for trichomoniasis using nucleic acid amplification testing, as well as a baseline screening for other infectious diseases. Continued annual screening for trichomoniasis should be considered for patients with HIV infection.    

The testing for a patient presenting for sexually transmitted infection (STI) screening varies depending on the patient’s risk factors for STIs. HIV infection is an indication to increase the frequency of testing from what is recommended for the general population, as well as to expand the types of tests done beyond what is needed for low-risk patients. Screening for STIs is indicated at the first evaluation following a new diagnosis of HIV and includes testing for gonorrhea, chlamydia, trichomoniasis, syphilis, and hepatitis B and C. Screening for gonorrhea and chlamydia, trichomoniasis, and syphilis are then repeated at least annually. Human papillomavirus (HPV) and cervical cancer screening is based on routine guidelines for individuals with HIV. Herpes serology testing may also be considered in this population.    

Additional factors to consider include patient age (annual for under age 25), pregnancy status, sexual practices including having new or multiple partners and having a sexual partner who has other concurrent partners, as well as living in an area with a high prevalence of disease.  Men who have sex with men should also be screened frequently (at least annually) and in some cases as often as every three to six months.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nucleic acid amplification testing for trichomoniasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatitis B e-antigen:
Incorrect: The recommended screening tests included in the hepatitis B screening panel are: hepatitis B surface antigen, antibody to hepatitis B surface antigen, and total antibody to hepatitis B core antigen.
❌ Vaginal culture for bacterial vaginosis:
Incorrect: Routine screening for bacterial vaginosis (BV) is not recommended. When indicated based on symptoms, the preferred tests for BV are saline microscopy or nucleic amplification testing. 
❌ Treponema pallidum passive particle agglutination  :
Incorrect: This patient should be screened for syphilis (caused by Treponema pallidum) with a non-treponemal test first, either a Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) or Rapid Plasma Reagin (RPR). If that testing is positive, it should be followed by a treponemal test, such as the T. pallidum passive particle agglutination (TP-PA) test.
❌ Anti-Hepatitis A IgM antibodies:
Incorrect: Patients with HIV should be screened for hepatitis B and C and vaccinated against hepatitis A and B. This patient does not have an indication to check hepatitis A antibodies.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to pelvic pain, which has been ongoing for the past three days. She has also had purulent yellowish vaginal discharge that contains trace amounts of blood. The patient has been sexually active with three partners over the past year. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Pain is elicited with palpation of the lower abdomen. Cervical motion tenderness is present. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug that should be prescribed in combination with azithromycin to treat this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibition of initiation complex through binding of the 30S subunit

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge, which are suggestive of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). PID is most frequently caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Treatment should include coverage of both organisms. Azithromycin or doxycycline is used to treat Chlamydia infection, whereas a third-generation cephalosporin is required to treat a gonococcal infection.

Cephalosporins are derivatives of 7-aminocephalosporanic acid and contain a beta-lactam ring attached to a dihydrothiazine ring. They are bactericidal (kills bacteria) and act to inhibit cell wall synthesis via the following steps:
  
  1. Binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) located in the bacterial cytoplasmic membrane 
  2. Inhibiting the transpeptidation reaction that cross-links linear peptidoglycan chain constituents of the cell wall 
  3. Activating autolytic enzymes that cause lesions in the bacterial cell wall 
Cephalosporins vary in their antibacterial activity and are designated first-, second-, third-, fourth-, or fifth-generation drugs according to the spectrum of coverage. Higher generations will have greater Gram-negative coverage.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase:
Incorrect: Sulfonamides inhibit dihydropteroate synthase and thus prevent folate synthesis. Sulfonamides are effective against various Gram-positive and Gram-negative organisms, as well as Chlamydia and Nocardia species. However, it is not indicated in the treatment of pelvic inflammatory disease.  
❌ Inhibition of DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones inhibit prokaryotic enzymes topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV.  They are very effective against Gram-negative bacteria such as Enterobacteriaceae, Haemophilus, Legionella, Neisseria, Moraxella, and even Pseudomonas species. However, fluoroquinolones are rarely used in the treatment of pelvic inflammatory disease.  
❌ Inhibition of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase:
Incorrect: Rifampin inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which is responsible for mRNA synthesis. It is one of the main components of the anti-tuberculosis treatment regime. In contrast, rifampin is not indicated in the treatment of pelvic inflammatory disease.  
❌ Inhibition of initiation complex through binding of the 30S subunit:
Incorrect: Aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin, amikacin, tobramycin) are bactericidal antimicrobial agents that inhibit protein synthesis by blocking initiation complex formation, causing misreading of mRNA, and inhibiting translocation. They are effective against severe Gram-negative rod infections and can be used in the management of pelvic inflammatory disease, but not in combination with azithromycin.  
✅ Inhibition of transpeptidase-mediated peptidoglycan cross-linking:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting for the past 12 hours. The patient is unable to tolerate oral intake. Her last menstrual period was 14 days ago. The patient has had 3 sexual partners in the past 6 months. Past medical history is significant for pelvic inflammatory disease that was treated with antibiotics. The patient has no allergies and takes no medications. Temperature is 39°C (102.2 F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 100/56 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes, and lower abdominal tenderness. Pelvic examination shows normal external genitalia and purulent discharge from the cervical os. Bimanual examination reveals cervical motion tenderness. Laboratory evaluation shows a leukocyte count of 18,000/mm3 with 50% neutrophils. Pregnancy test is negative. Blood cultures are obtained and empiric treatment with clindamycin is initiated. In addition to clindamycin, which of the following antibiotics is indicated in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, purulent cervical discharge, and cervical motion tenderness consistent with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). This condition is typically caused by the organisms Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae and is treated with broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy. This patient requires hospitalization and treatment with parenteral antibiotics due to her associated nausea, vomiting and leukocytosis, and fever. Initial therapy includes intravenous clindamycin in combination with gentamicin (an aminoglycoside).

In addition to complicated PID, aminoglycosides are often indicated in combination with a β-lactam or glycopeptide (vancomycin) in select circumstances:

  • For treatment of healthcare-associated pneumonia or sepsis, against multidrug-resistant gram-negative organisms (P. aeruginosa, Enterobacter sp., Klebsiella sp., and Serratia sp.)  
  • To achieve synergistic bactericidal activity in the treatment of endocarditis due to gram-positive Enterococci sp.  
Other indications for aminoglycosides include urinary tract infections or meningitis caused by gram negative organisms resistant to β-lactams. Streptomycin and amikacin serve as alternative agents for the treatment of infections due to drug-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis or to other nontuberculous mycobacteria. Adverse effects of aminoglycosides include: 
       
  •  Irreversible vestibular and auditory dysfunction  
  •  Nephrotoxicity, especially when co-administered with loop diuretics  
  •  Teratogenicity 
  •  Allergic skin reactions (neomycin) and are contraindicated in patients who are allergic to them  
  •  Neuromuscular blockade and apnea–aminoglycosides should be avoided in patients with  myasthenia gravis or associated neuromuscular disorders.   

Option Analysis

❌ Vancomycin :
Incorrect: Vancomycin is indicated in the management of multidrug-resistant gram-positive organisms including MRSA, S. epidermidis, sensitive Enterococcus sp., and Clostridium difficile. Vancomycin is not indicated in the management of pelvic inflammatory disease. 
✅ Gentamicin :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chloramphenicol :
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol can be used in the treatment of meningitis secondary to Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis or Streptococcus pneumoniae or rickettsial diseases. Chloramphenicol is not effective against Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. 
❌ Linezolid :
Incorrect: Linezolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor used in the treatment of gram-positive bacterial infections (MRSA) and vancomycin resistant organisms. It is not effective against Chlamydia trachomatis (intracellular organism) or Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gram-negative). 
❌ Daptomycin :
Incorrect: Daptomycin is a lipopeptide that disrupts the cell membranes of gram-positive cocci by creating transmembrane channels. It can be used to treat skin infections caused by S. aureus (MRSA), bacteremia, endocarditis and VRE. It is not effective against Chlamydia trachomatis (intracellular organism) or Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gram-negative).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 38-weeks gestation, presents to labor and delivery triage after several hours of contractions. Currently, they are timed about four minutes apart. She does not have fluid leakage, but she noted a small amount of blood on her underwear just before coming into the hospital. The patient was diagnosed with HIV in the first trimester of pregnancy. The patient has been inconsistent with her combination antiretroviral therapy, and her most recent viral load is 15,000 copies/mL. Temperature is 98.9°F (37.1°C), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Pelvic examination in triage reveals a cervix that is three centimeters dilated with a small amount of blood near the introitus. The amniotic fluid sac is tense and palpable. Fetal heart rate tracing is a category I. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Start zidovudine and perform cesarean section

questions.solution:
This patient is at 38-weeks gestation and has regular contractions, cervical dilation, and class I fetal heart tracing. She is HIV positive with a viral load of greater than 1,000 copies/mL. There is an increased risk of vertical transmission of the virus during delivery. Therefore, the next best step in managing this patient is to perform a cesarean section and administer intrapartum zidovudine, which additionally helps reduce the risk of intrapartum transmission.

In contrast, in patients with a viral load of ≤1,000 copies/mL, the risk of vertical transmission is low, and the infant can be delivered vaginally. Intrapartum zidovudine is not required in these patients.

Moreover, infants of mothers with a viral load ≤1,000 copies/mL should receive zidovudine for at least 4-weeks after delivery. In contrast, infants born to mothers with a viral load greater than 1,000 copies/mL should receive combination antiretroviral prophylaxis for at least 6-weeks after delivery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Antiretroviral therapy and delivery vaginally:
Incorrect: Patients with a viral load of fewer than 1000 copies/mL can deliver vaginally because the risk of vertical transmission is low. These patients should continue antiretroviral therapy but do not require additional intrapartum zidovudine. This patient’s viral load is much greater than 1000 copies/mL.  
❌ Perform artificial rupture of membranes:
Incorrect: Artificial rupture of membranes should be avoided in patients with HIV to reduce the risk of vertical transmission of HIV to the fetus.  
✅ Start zidovudine and perform cesarean section:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start oxytocin:
Incorrect: Oxytocin can be administered to strengthen uterine contractions and assist in vaginal delivery of the fetus. However, given the patient’s viral load is far greater than 1000 copies/mL, vaginal delivery should be avoided as it will promote vertical transmission of HIV to the fetus.  
❌ Start misoprostol:
Incorrect: Misoprostol promotes cervical dilation and uterine contractions to induce vaginal delivery. However, given this patient’s elevated viral load, vaginal delivery should be avoided as it may promote vertical transmission of HIV to the fetus. A cesarean section should be performed instead.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of bilateral lower abdominal pain for 3 days and vaginal discharge. Today she developed nausea and vomiting. She states that she has multiple sexual partners with inconsistent use of condoms. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals lower abdominal tenderness, without rebound or guarding. Labs are ordered and pending. Urine HCG is negative for pregnancy. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on physical examination?

choices.text: Thick white discharge on speculum examination

questions.solution:
This patient presents with lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge for 3 days, as well as nausea and vomiting. Given her symptoms, sexual history, and negative pregnancy test, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is the most likely diagnosis. Examination findings characteristic of PID include lower abdominal tenderness and adnexal, cervical motion, and uterine tenderness. A clinical diagnosis of PID can be made if any of the following is present on pelvic exam: cervical motion tenderness, uterine tenderness, or adnexal tenderness in a patient with a clinical picture that is consistent with PID.

Patients with pelvic inflammatory disease may present with lower abdominal or pelvic pain, vaginal discharge, nausea, vomiting; and they may have dysuria and dyspareunia. Patients may have a history of multiple sexual partners and a lack of contraception use. Typical physical examination findings include lower abdominal tenderness. Rebound and guarding may be seen in more severe disease. In addition, pelvic exams will reveal adnexal, uterine or cervical motion tenderness. A friable cervix with muco-purulent discharge may be seen on pelvic exam.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cervical motion tenderness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rovsing sign:
Incorrect: Rovsing sign refers to pain felt in the right lower abdomen upon palpation of the left lower abdomen and suggests appendicitis, not PID which is the likely diagnosis in this patient.  
❌ Thick white discharge on speculum examination:
Incorrect: Thick white discharge on speculum examination is suggestive of candidal vaginitis, not PID, which is the likely diagnosis in this patient and typically presents with mucopurulent discharge.  
❌ Positive fluid wave:
Incorrect: A positive fluid wave indicates the presence of ascites or intra-abdominal fluid. This patient's presentation is more consistent with a diagnosis of PID, which presents with cervical motion, adnexal, or uterine tenderness.  
❌ Vaginal bleeding:
Incorrect: Intermittent post-coital vaginal spotting can occasionally occur in patients with PID; however vaginal bleeding is not commonly seen. The characteristic findings of PID are cervical, motion, adnexal, and uterine tenderness.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of vaginal discharge with a “fishy” odor for 4 days. The patient is sexually active with multiple biologically male partners. She does not use condoms, and her last sexual encounter was one week ago. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows normal-appearing external genitalia with no erythema. Pelvic examination shows thin gray-white vaginal discharge with odor. The cervix appears normal and there is no cervical motion tenderness. A pregnancy test is negative. Vaginal pH is 4.8. Wet mount is shown below. No hyphae are seen on potassium hydroxide preparation. A “whiff” test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with thin gray-white malodorous vaginal discharge that has an elevated vaginal pH (>4.5), a positive “whiff” test, and a wet mount showing the presence of clue cells, most likely has bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis is a dysbiosis or an imbalance of the normal microorganisms in the vagina, resulting in overgrowth of anaerobes. It is the most common cause of abnormal vaginal discharge. Patients typically report a thin watery discharge with an unpleasant odor, and the physical exam is positive for a thin gray-white vaginal discharge with a “fishy” odor. Diagnosis is made by meeting the Amsel criteria, which include:
 
  1.  Thin gray-white vaginal discharge on physical exam 
  2.  Microscopy revealing more than 20% clue cells (epithelial cells covered in bacteria)  
  3.  Vaginal fluid pH greater than 4.5 
  4.  Positive KOH whiff test (i.e. smelling amine odor when KOH is dropped on vaginal discharge).  
If 3 out of the 4 criteria are met, then the patient can be diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. This patient has 4 out of the 4 criteria needed for diagnosis. First line treatment is oral or vaginal metronidazole. Clindamycin can be used as an alternative.  

Option Analysis

❌ Vulvovaginal candidiasis:
Incorrect: Patients with vulvovaginal candidiasis typically report the presence of thick, white vaginal discharge and vaginal itching. The physical exam would reveal a thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge. Potassium hydroxide (KOH) microscopy would show pseudohyphae and spores, and the vaginal pH would be 3.5 to 4.5. This patient with thin gray-white vaginal discharge with an elevated vaginal pH (>4.5) and wet mount showing clue cells most likely has bacterial vaginosis.  
❌ Physiologic discharge:
Incorrect: Patients with physiologic discharge report an increase in a thin viscous discharge without odor. Physical examination will reveal white or clear vaginal discharge. Saline microscopy would show mature squamous cells and abundant lactobacilli, and the pH would be between 3.5 to 4.5. This patient with thin gray-white vaginal discharge with an elevated vaginal pH (>4.5), a positive “whiff” test, and wet mount showing clue cells, most likely has bacterial vaginosis.  
✅ Bacterial vaginosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vaginal trichomoniasis:
Incorrect: Symptomatic patients with trichomoniasis typically report vaginal discharge with odor, and vulvar itching, irritation, and/or dysuria. The physical exam may reveal a yellow, frothy, vaginal discharge as well as cervical erythema with petechiae (strawberry cervix). Saline microscopy shows motile trichomonads and many polymorphonucleocytes. This patient with a thin gray-white vaginal discharge with a “fishy” odor and wet mount showing clue cells most likely has bacterial vaginosis.  
❌ Chlamydia infection:
Incorrect: Symptomatic patients with chlamydia typically report thick vaginal discharge, dysuria, non-menstrual or post-coital spotting, and possibly pelvic pain. The physical exam may reveal mucopurulent cervical discharge, a friable cervix, and possibly pelvic or cervical motion tenderness. This patient with thin gray-white vaginal discharge with a “fishy” odor in the setting of elevated vaginal pH (>4.5) and wet mount showing clue cells most likely has bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of five days of vaginal discharge and itching. She has been sexually active with three different biologically male partners in the last month and has not used condoms. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals yellow, frothy vaginal discharge and cervical petechiae. The vaginal pH is 4.9. A wet mount of a sample of the vaginal discharge is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?


Image by CDC/ Joe Miller is licensed under Public Domain. Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons.
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vaginal itching and yellow, frothy discharge that has an elevated vaginal pH. Flagellated protozoa are seen on wet mount, consistent with a diagnosis of trichomoniasis. The parasites appear as small pear-shaped organisms with four flagella and undulating membranes, which will collectively show motility during the microscopic examination. Multiple sexual partners and unprotected intercourse are risk factors for trichomoniasis.    

Vaginal trichomoniasis is a parasitic infection caused by flagellated protozoa. Patients may be asymptomatic or may present with symptoms such as malodorous vaginal discharge, vaginal pruritus, dyspareunia, and dysuria. Physical examination may show a frothy yellow or green discharge and vaginal or cervical erythema with petechiae (known as “strawberry cervix”).    

Having multiple sexual partners and unprotected intercourse are risk factors. The sharing of sex toys can also lead to infection, since the parasites can spread through vaginal fluid. Hygiene practices, such as douching, which remove some of the bacteria that make up the normal vaginal flora, can increase the risk of overgrowth of infectious pathogens such as Trichomonas vaginalis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Trichomoniasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bacterial vaginosis:
Incorrect: Bacterial vaginosis typically causes thin vaginal discharge that may be gray, white, or green and foul-smelling. However, the wet mount would show clue cells, and not flagellated protozoa seen in this wet mount which is consistent with trichomoniasis.  
❌ Candidiasis:
Incorrect: Vaginal candidiasis typically causes a thick white vaginal discharge with budding yeast or pseudohyphae on microscopy. This patient has flagellated protozoa on wet mount consistent with trichomonas infection. 
❌ Gonorrhea:
Incorrect: Gonorrhea can present with thick vaginal discharge and discomfort. It is caused by gram-negative bacteria, not flagellated protozoa seen on this wet mount, which is consistent with trichomoniasis. 
❌ Chlamydia:
Incorrect: Chlamydia can cause vaginal discharge and discomfort, but it is caused by intracellular bacteria, not flagellated protozoa as seen on this wet mount, which is consistent with trichomoniasis.
